description: GIAC is a registered trademark of the Escal Institute of Advanced Technologies, Inc.  SANS is not affiliated with these courses. GIAC has been an industry leader in information security certifications for years. The GIAC Security Essentials (GSEC) is designed for Security Professionals who want to demonstrate that they are qualified for IT systems hands-on roles with respect to security tasks. GSEC is one of the DoD Approved 8570 Baseline Certifications for IAT Level II.
name: GIAC Security Essentials
subtitle: GSEC

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Mike explore the fundamentals of networking. They discuss the various network types such as local area networks, wide area networks, metropolitan area networks and personal area networks. They will also look at the different types of network topologies such as bus, ring, star, mesh and hybrid networks.
episodes.title: Networking Fundamentals

00:23:15.713 --> 00:23:18.861
I'm not going to be able to make
sense out of what's going on.

451
00:23:18.861 --> 00:23:23.810
I'll lose that, what's a good word for
it, you just can't interpret it.

452
00:23:23.810 --> 00:23:25.630
So you can't read the data.

453
00:23:25.630 --> 00:23:27.620
So basically nobody can communicate again.

454
00:23:27.620 --> 00:23:30.890
>> You know I make the joke here that
you're probably only going to see them in

455
00:23:30.890 --> 00:23:34.318
a museum, but I was watching some of
the earlier days when this was the network

456
00:23:34.318 --> 00:23:35.819
technology on some kind of show.

457
00:23:35.819 --> 00:23:39.786
And one of the earlier inventors,
inventors of this product said, you can

458
00:23:39.786 --> 00:23:43.421
always tell when somebody wanted a break
cuz all they have to do is reach down and

459
00:23:43.421 --> 00:23:45.484
pull one of those
terminators off the line.

460
00:23:45.484 --> 00:23:49.389
And then everybody's faces would slowly
come up from their cubes wondering why's

461
00:23:49.389 --> 00:23:50.310
the network down.

462
00:23:50.310 --> 00:23:53.993
So I can see this would be a fun time at
the office when this network didn't work.

463
00:23:53.993 --> 00:23:55.232
>> And the scary thing was Wes,

464
00:23:55.232 --> 00:23:57.977
what if I broke this cable here
does that bother my network too?

465
00:23:57.977 --> 00:23:59.926
>> It brings the whole network
to still a single cable.

466
00:23:59.926 --> 00:24:02.292
>> That's right cuz this
whole thing you can imagine,

467
00:24:02.292 --> 00:24:04.622
is the signal going out
across all of these cables.

468
00:24:04.622 --> 00:24:07.931
So It's not just a break in the main line.

469
00:24:07.931 --> 00:24:12.248
If Wes wanted that break, [LAUGH]
literally, and breaks the cable there,

470
00:24:12.248 --> 00:24:13.860
yeah, everybody is down.

471
00:24:13.860 --> 00:24:18.070
So buses had their place in history.

472
00:24:18.070 --> 00:24:20.180
You don't see them that often anymore.

473
00:24:20.180 --> 00:24:24.820
Let's move onto a little more modern
layout, a little modern topology.

474
00:24:24.820 --> 00:24:26.990
And that's gonna be our star.

475
00:24:26.990 --> 00:24:27.920
And you can see,

476
00:24:27.920 --> 00:24:32.990
it gets the name from the pattern that it
makes when we kinda draw it out like this.

477
00:24:32.990 --> 00:24:34.640
But the big difference between a bus and

478
00:24:34.640 --> 00:24:39.180
a star is I now have a central
connectivity device.

479
00:24:39.180 --> 00:24:42.430
I have something tying all
of these things together.

480
00:24:42.430 --> 00:24:44.650
So instead of there
being that backbone and

481
00:24:44.650 --> 00:24:48.690
everybody T-ing into
this backbone down here.

482
00:24:48.690 --> 00:24:53.392
We've got this one device in the middle,
and everything plugs into that one device.

483
00:24:53.392 --> 00:24:56.287
And this is what we would
call a star topology.

484
00:24:56.287 --> 00:24:59.047
Now that device in
the middle could be a hub,

485
00:24:59.047 --> 00:25:01.965
could be a switch,
could be a bridge, right?

486
00:25:01.965 --> 00:25:05.170
We'll talk about these
devices as we go along.

487
00:25:05.170 --> 00:25:09.540
Advantages to this layout, well, is
going to be the fact that, what happens,

488
00:25:09.540 --> 00:25:11.440
Wes, if this cable breaks here?

489
00:25:11.440 --> 00:25:14.340
>> Well, with a connectivity device,
I think it isolates just that one

490
00:25:14.340 --> 00:25:17.330
node that's connected to the device
from the rest of the network.

491
00:25:17.330 --> 00:25:18.360
>> That's exactly right.

492
00:25:18.360 --> 00:25:20.250
So that one node would be down.

493
00:25:20.250 --> 00:25:22.180
Nobody could communicate with this node.

494
00:25:22.180 --> 00:25:25.060
This node could communicate with
nobody else, but that's it.

495
00:25:25.060 --> 00:25:28.440
The other three nodes on this network
are still communicating just fine.

496
00:25:28.440 --> 00:25:32.260
So it ends up creating this point-to-point
connection between the node and

497
00:25:32.260 --> 00:25:34.070
that central connectivity device.

498
00:25:34.070 --> 00:25:37.240
Which eliminates my need for
one, for terminators.

499
00:25:37.240 --> 00:25:41.910
And two, the single cable break
brings down the entire network.

500
00:25:41.910 --> 00:25:42.610
Flexibility.

501
00:25:42.610 --> 00:25:46.350
When I need to plug in a new node, as long
as there's an extra port on this guy,

502
00:25:46.350 --> 00:25:48.180
I can just pop a new node out here.

503
00:25:48.180 --> 00:25:51.180
And connect it up, and
we're good to go, all right?

504
00:25:51.180 --> 00:25:56.428
Downside is to connect that node,
I had to make a home run.

505
00:25:56.428 --> 00:25:58.850
And I'm not talking about hitting
it out of the park, right?

506
00:25:58.850 --> 00:26:03.200
I've gotta run a wire from that person's
office, that new computer he just got,

507
00:26:03.200 --> 00:26:04.820
up the wall, over the attic, down in.

508
00:26:04.820 --> 00:26:07.410
Wherever that central
connectivity device is,

509
00:26:07.410 --> 00:26:10.310
I've gotta connect that
machine to it somehow, right?

510
00:26:10.310 --> 00:26:15.950
So a lot more cable involved when we
deal with setting up star topologies.

511
00:26:15.950 --> 00:26:19.009
>> Now it's interesting, and
I think you did this on purpose here.

512
00:26:19.009 --> 00:26:21.100
>> [LAUGH]
>> Now you showed us the first one which

513
00:26:21.100 --> 00:26:24.179
was probably one that we will
never really see anymore.

514
00:26:24.179 --> 00:26:25.690
Because it's just not utilize anymore.

515
00:26:25.690 --> 00:26:27.587
Now this almost is the polar reverse.

516
00:26:27.587 --> 00:26:30.733
How common is this type of
network in today's day and age?

517
00:26:30.733 --> 00:26:32.010
>> This is just about everywhere.

518
00:26:32.010 --> 00:26:34.862
Just about every network you
run into is gonna be switched,

519
00:26:34.862 --> 00:26:36.905
what they call switched Ethernet.

520
00:26:36.905 --> 00:26:41.369
Meaning that we're running star topologies
with a central connectivity device.

521
00:26:41.369 --> 00:26:42.885
Almost always a switch.

522
00:26:42.885 --> 00:26:46.455
Hubs, which we're gonna talk about later,
you rarely see those anymore.

523
00:26:46.455 --> 00:26:49.970
Bridges you really don't see
those much anymore except for

524
00:26:49.970 --> 00:26:51.802
in special needs situations.

525
00:26:51.802 --> 00:26:56.752
But to Wes's point, yeah, just about every
single network is gonna be laid out in

526
00:26:56.752 --> 00:27:00.000
a star using a central
connectivity device.

527
00:27:00.000 --> 00:27:02.760
Well, Mike,
I know we got a lot more to go.

528
00:27:02.760 --> 00:27:06.610
You guys out there that are sharp probably
seen that we've got a lot more of those

529
00:27:06.610 --> 00:27:07.580
diagrams there.

530
00:27:07.580 --> 00:27:08.760
You can see all the little tabs.

531
00:27:08.760 --> 00:27:11.750
But I'll tell you what we
don't have time for right now.

532
00:27:11.750 --> 00:27:12.920
And that's the time on that clock.

533
00:27:12.920 --> 00:27:15.567
So Mike, were you gonna go ahead and
wrap this up?

534
00:27:15.567 --> 00:27:16.670
And come back in a part two, and

535
00:27:16.670 --> 00:27:18.650
we'll continue along in
our network fundamentals?

536
00:27:18.650 --> 00:27:19.570
>> Sounds like a plan.

537
00:27:19.570 --> 00:27:22.170
>> All right, very good, well,
that's a perfect place to stop.

538
00:27:22.170 --> 00:27:23.320
Thank you, Mike, for being here.

539
00:27:23.320 --> 00:27:25.832
We'll see you guys, hopefully,
see you in the next episode.

540
00:27:25.832 --> 00:27:28.895
Signing out for ITProTV,
I have been your host, Wes Bryan.

541
00:27:28.895 --> 00:27:29.590
>> And I'm Mike Rodrick.

542
00:27:29.590 --> 00:27:30.908
>> And we'll see you next time.

543
00:27:30.908 --> 00:27:37.993
[MUSIC]

544
00:27:37.993 --> 00:27:41.195
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

4

5

6

7

8

9
00:00:22.619 --> 00:00:23.827
GSAC here.

10
00:00:23.827 --> 00:00:26.883

11
00:00:26.883 --> 00:00:29.550

12

13

>> Doing great, thanks for having me back.

14
00:00:31.940 --> 00:00:34.530
And yeah, we left off talking

15
00:00:34.530 --> 00:00:36.390
And we're just gonna
dive right back in and

16
00:00:36.390 --> 00:00:38.930
continue our discussion
on number topologies.

17
00:00:38.930 --> 00:00:43.050
So let's jump right back on my screen,
and pick up where we left off.

18
00:00:43.050 --> 00:00:48.000
We began our discussion on star,
that star topology.

19
00:00:48.000 --> 00:00:49.467
We've got that on my screen here.

20
00:00:49.467 --> 00:00:54.543
You can see every device connects back
to that central connectivity device.

21
00:00:54.543 --> 00:00:56.405
Talk about having to add a new node.

22
00:00:56.405 --> 00:00:58.912
We gotta run extra cable to
connect that node back to

23
00:00:58.912 --> 00:01:01.020
that central connectivity device.

24
00:01:01.020 --> 00:01:05.130
We also talked about the upsides of
our star is going to be the fact that

25
00:01:05.130 --> 00:01:08.820
every node has a point-to-point connection
back to that central connectivity device.

26
00:01:08.820 --> 00:01:13.150
So we cut a cable,
the entire network doesn't go down, right,

27
00:01:13.150 --> 00:01:14.900
just that one node goes down.

28
00:01:14.900 --> 00:01:16.090
There is a downside though.

29
00:01:16.090 --> 00:01:19.910
There is a single point of failure
in a star topology, isn't there Wes?

30
00:01:19.910 --> 00:01:22.660
>> Well Mike, I gotta say, looking at
this diagram it's probably gonna be that

31
00:01:22.660 --> 00:01:25.630
central connectivity device that all
the other devices are connected.

32
00:01:25.630 --> 00:01:27.700
I can only imagine that if we lose that,

00:01:27.700 --> 00:01:30.510
well nobody on the network's
gonna communicate, right?

34
00:01:30.510 --> 00:01:31.560
>> That's exactly right.

35
00:01:31.560 --> 00:01:34.410
We take that thing down and
everybody loses connectivity.

36
00:01:34.410 --> 00:01:39.158
So you do end up with a single point
of failure when you're setting up

37
00:01:39.158 --> 00:01:42.921
a basic switch ethernet or
using that star topology.

38
00:01:42.921 --> 00:01:46.119
So it is something that you're
gonna have to be cautious about.

39
00:01:46.119 --> 00:01:48.767
When you think about
you're creating networks,

40
00:01:48.767 --> 00:01:51.928
keep in mind that they can become
a single point of failure.

41
00:01:51.928 --> 00:01:55.295
Now another type of network topology
that we need to be familiar with,

42
00:01:55.295 --> 00:01:56.672
is something called a mesh.

43
00:01:56.672 --> 00:01:58.966
Now start with what's
known as a partial mesh.

44
00:01:58.966 --> 00:02:03.552
And in a partial mesh, what they mean is
that our nodes are connected to more than

45
00:02:03.552 --> 00:02:05.500
one other node, all right?

46
00:02:05.500 --> 00:02:07.563
Example, in this partial mesh,

47
00:02:07.563 --> 00:02:11.776
each one of these nodes is connected
to two partners instead of one.

48
00:02:11.776 --> 00:02:15.660
And the idea is that it provides
a little bit of redundancy, right?

49
00:02:15.660 --> 00:02:21.385
If I lose this cable, I can't go this
way to communicate over to here,

50
00:02:21.385 --> 00:02:26.237
but I could go around the long way and
still communicate, so

51
00:02:26.237 --> 00:02:30.235
I didn't lose complete
contact with that node.

52
00:02:30.235 --> 00:02:34.115
And again, this is what I call a partial
mesh cuz it's not a full mesh.

53
00:02:34.115 --> 00:02:35.590
I'll come to that here in just a second.

54
00:02:35.590 --> 00:02:37.380
I will tell you that
this is not very common.

55
00:02:37.380 --> 00:02:41.580
You're not gonna see this in just
about any corporate environment,

56
00:02:41.580 --> 00:02:45.510
LAN environment,
meshes are not gonna be all that common.

57
00:02:45.510 --> 00:02:48.163
And it's really cuz of
the complexity of setting it up,

58
00:02:48.163 --> 00:02:49.583
and the amount of equipment.

59
00:02:49.583 --> 00:02:53.730
In this one here each one of these
nodes has to have two network adapters.

60
00:02:53.730 --> 00:02:56.780
Each one of these nodes has two
cables running out of the back of it,

61
00:02:56.780 --> 00:02:59.000
back to wherever to connect
to these other nodes.

62
00:02:59.000 --> 00:03:01.440
So it's not very common.

63
00:03:01.440 --> 00:03:05.550
If we take that from a partial to full
you'll really start to see why we don't

64
00:03:05.550 --> 00:03:08.550
use these typically in
a corporate environment.

65
00:03:08.550 --> 00:03:12.162
Here's five nodes, all right,
and this is a full mesh,

66
00:03:12.162 --> 00:03:16.017
now every node is connected to
every other node, all right?

67
00:03:16.017 --> 00:03:20.181
So you can see that each node has four
connections coming out of it because

68
00:03:20.181 --> 00:03:23.525
there's five nodes,
I'm already connected to myself,

69
00:03:23.525 --> 00:03:28.340
I don't need a connection for that so
if there's five nodes I'm one of them.

70
00:03:28.340 --> 00:03:30.420
I need four connections to
connect everybody else.

71
00:03:30.420 --> 00:03:32.203
There's a little formula you can use.

72
00:03:32.203 --> 00:03:38.402
Is n * (n-1)/2, so
I got 5 * (5-1) which is 4,

73
00:03:38.402 --> 00:03:43.992
divided by 2, 5 * 4 is 20,
divided by 2 is 10,

74
00:03:43.992 --> 00:03:50.940
that is 10 connections that I'm
dealing with there, all right?

75
00:03:52.070 --> 00:03:53.600
And where was I going with that?

76
00:03:53.600 --> 00:03:56.370
So yeah,
the complexity is just ridiculous.

77
00:03:57.710 --> 00:03:58.460
I mean one,

78
00:03:58.460 --> 00:04:02.690
when's the last time you saw a client with
four network adapters in it, all right?

79
00:04:02.690 --> 00:04:04.350
What if I add a client?

80
00:04:04.350 --> 00:04:04.890
Now all of a sudden,

81
00:04:04.890 --> 00:04:08.080
I've gotta add another network adapter
to every single machine on my network,

82
00:04:08.080 --> 00:04:11.446
run a new cable from every single machine
on my network, back to that new node,

83
00:04:11.446 --> 00:04:13.530
probably not gonna happen.

84
00:04:13.530 --> 00:04:14.080
>> Yeah, Mike.

85
00:04:14.080 --> 00:04:17.940
The only time I've actually seen
a full mesh, come to think about it,

86
00:04:17.940 --> 00:04:21.470
was in wireless laptop communications
where we didn't have an accent.

87
00:04:21.470 --> 00:04:24.550
We didn't have the central connectivity
device that you showed us in the star, so

88
00:04:24.550 --> 00:04:27.890
we just put the network adapters in a kind
of a mode where they could all talk to

89
00:04:27.890 --> 00:04:30.580
each other, and that's really
the only place I've ever seen it.

90
00:04:30.580 --> 00:04:35.770
>> Yeah, the only other place you'll see
a full mesh is on your WAN side of things.

91
00:04:35.770 --> 00:04:39.767
Here, it is a little more common to do
a full mesh, all right, because one,

92
00:04:39.767 --> 00:04:42.900
I'm typically leasing lines and
they're already there.

93
00:04:42.900 --> 00:04:46.330
I can just say hey, I need
a connection from Seattle to Chicago.

94
00:04:46.330 --> 00:04:51.520
I need a connection from Chicago to
Boston, and I need one from Boston.

95
00:04:51.520 --> 00:04:53.830
And you get the idea.

96
00:04:53.830 --> 00:04:57.220
So here where you can see each one of
these might be a different geographical,

97
00:04:57.220 --> 00:05:01.450
one of my offices in different towns,
each office is connected to each other

98
00:05:01.450 --> 00:05:06.070
office so that if I lose this connection
here, well they could still go

99
00:05:06.070 --> 00:05:11.310
around the bend and communicate
if they absolutely had to, right?

100
00:05:11.310 --> 00:05:14.290
I can have it set up to where it
falls back to that other route,

101
00:05:14.290 --> 00:05:18.520
make that other route little more costly
cuz it's gotta go further along but

102
00:05:18.520 --> 00:05:21.970
at least they've got a backup path
to get to that other location.

103
00:05:21.970 --> 00:05:25.320
So a cable cut,
a loss of connectivity from one ISP,

104
00:05:25.320 --> 00:05:27.470
doesn't necessarily mean
my whole office is down.

105
00:05:27.470 --> 00:05:30.290
>> So when you talked about
administration and complexity,

106
00:05:30.290 --> 00:05:32.630
so if I understand it right, a full mesh,

107
00:05:32.630 --> 00:05:36.290
you're talking about an exponential
increase if I just add one node.

108
00:05:36.290 --> 00:05:38.280
So cost and
maintenance goes through the roof.

109
00:05:38.280 --> 00:05:41.720
But the benefit seems to be as more of
a resiliency to failure, like in the WAN

110
00:05:41.720 --> 00:05:45.620
environment where you're saying, where
one connection to one site goes down,

111
00:05:45.620 --> 00:05:48.640
I still have connection whether it's
through a completely different provider,

112
00:05:48.640 --> 00:05:49.760
but at least I have options.

113
00:05:49.760 --> 00:05:50.800
There so, resiliency.

114
00:05:50.800 --> 00:05:51.460
>> Exactly right.

115
00:05:51.460 --> 00:05:53.430
Resiliency is the key.

116
00:05:53.430 --> 00:05:56.300
We see that, actually,
the Internet is a really good example.

117
00:05:56.300 --> 00:06:02.130
It might not be a full, complete,
100% mesh, but it's definitely a mesh.

118
00:06:02.130 --> 00:06:06.615
When my packets leave my computer and
they're going out to some website,

119
00:06:06.615 --> 00:06:09.730
ABC.com, they don't all
necessarily go the same route.

120
00:06:09.730 --> 00:06:12.420
They take the best route
that they can at the time.

121
00:06:12.420 --> 00:06:15.310
The route that the first packet
took might not be the best route

122
00:06:15.310 --> 00:06:16.380
when the second packet leaves.

123
00:06:16.380 --> 00:06:20.052
It might decide that this is gonna
be a faster route, right, and

124
00:06:20.052 --> 00:06:24.540
because the way the Internet is layed out,
it's kinda like a big spiderweb and

125
00:06:24.540 --> 00:06:28.225
there's many, many routes you can go,
so it is a mesh of sorts.

126
00:06:28.225 --> 00:06:32.623
All right, so we dug in terminology-wise,
mesh network, when you start connecting

127
00:06:32.623 --> 00:06:35.832
all the nodes, all the other nodes,
you can do a partial mesh.

128
00:06:35.832 --> 00:06:39.589
None of these are gonna be very
common inside a LAN unless its

129
00:06:39.589 --> 00:06:44.100
some critical security controls,
or I might see that, yeah, again,

130
00:06:44.100 --> 00:06:46.370
I'm trying to think of something.

131
00:06:46.370 --> 00:06:48.380
I've never seen one inside a LAN.

00:13:37.260 --> 00:13:39.506
93, I think, is when the first RFC,

239
00:13:39.506 --> 00:13:43.810
or one of the first RFCs,
came out about addressing this problem.

240
00:13:43.810 --> 00:13:46.970
No pun intended,
in dealing with our shortage of addresses.

241
00:13:46.970 --> 00:13:50.493
Because companies were getting a class
B address even though they only

242
00:13:50.493 --> 00:13:51.696
had 1,000 nodes.

243
00:13:51.696 --> 00:13:54.950
So there's 64,000 wasted addresses.

244
00:13:54.950 --> 00:13:59.540
We could see, it didn't take
a visionist to see we're gonna run

245
00:13:59.540 --> 00:14:02.500
out before long as the Internet
exploded and all that.

246
00:14:02.500 --> 00:14:06.840
So they came up with something new, and
that was what's called the classless.

247
00:14:06.840 --> 00:14:09.290
We're gonna drop that
whole classful system.

248
00:14:09.290 --> 00:14:11.710
We're gonna go
Classless Inter-Domain Routing.

249
00:14:11.710 --> 00:14:16.357
And what we're gonna do is we're gonna
say, rather than use default subnet masks,

250
00:14:16.357 --> 00:14:21.082
like all Class As use a 255.0.0.0 and
Class Bs, 255.255.0.0.

251
00:14:21.082 --> 00:14:22.015
We said, why?

252
00:14:22.015 --> 00:14:26.000
Why don't we just decide that, hey,
we know it's gonna start with ones.

253
00:14:26.000 --> 00:14:28.920
And then somewhere along the line
it's gonna change to zeros and

254
00:14:28.920 --> 00:14:30.550
it's gonna be zeros
the rest of the way out.

255
00:14:30.550 --> 00:14:35.050
What if I could take that line and not
have to leave it on one of those octets.

256
00:14:35.050 --> 00:14:37.900
What if I could move it around?

257
00:14:37.900 --> 00:14:38.770
All right.

258
00:14:38.770 --> 00:14:41.590
And all I have to do is really
tell you how many ones are there.

259
00:14:41.590 --> 00:14:43.300
>> Because if I tell you there's 18 1s.

260
00:14:43.300 --> 00:14:45.693
Well the first octet's 8.

261
00:14:45.693 --> 00:14:47.100
I was at 10 left.

262
00:14:47.100 --> 00:14:49.080
The second octet's another 8.

263
00:14:49.080 --> 00:14:50.110
So that's 16.

264
00:14:50.110 --> 00:14:51.225
I get two left.

265
00:14:51.225 --> 00:14:54.407
There's gonna be two bits in
that third octet that are 1s.

266
00:14:54.407 --> 00:14:56.270
And then the rest are gonna be 0s.

267
00:14:56.270 --> 00:15:00.945
So all I really had to do,
you know there's 32 numbers, 32 1s and 0s.

268
00:15:00.945 --> 00:15:04.000
If I tell you there are 18 1s,
you write down 18 1s.

269
00:15:04.000 --> 00:15:07.660
And then whatever it takes to
get to 32 numbers for 0s, right?

270
00:15:07.660 --> 00:15:10.470
Just fill the rest of it out,
pad the rest of it, with 0s.

271
00:15:10.470 --> 00:15:12.750
That is classless inter-domain routing.

272
00:15:12.750 --> 00:15:17.485
We're no longer tied to breaking
the subnet mask right on that octet.

273
00:15:17.485 --> 00:15:20.355
And that freed it up because let's
look at my computer again and

274
00:15:20.355 --> 00:15:21.988
think about the logic behind that.

275
00:15:21.988 --> 00:15:26.515
I said there's 65,000
because we have 16 bits,

276
00:15:26.515 --> 00:15:30.398
there's 65,000 possible hosts, well.

277
00:15:30.398 --> 00:15:36.450
So the formula is actually because there's
two, it's a base II numbering system.

278
00:15:36.450 --> 00:15:40.320
So it's 2 to the power
of the number of bits.

279
00:15:40.320 --> 00:15:43.600
So in other words, 2 to the 16th power.

280
00:15:43.600 --> 00:15:45.690
The little 16 above the 2, right?

281
00:15:45.690 --> 00:15:49.544
Is 65,535, or
something right around there.

282
00:15:49.544 --> 00:15:52.080
When I said there was 255 possible hosts.

283
00:15:52.080 --> 00:15:54.810
2 to the power of 8 is 256, right.

284
00:15:55.910 --> 00:15:57.226
So that's how we calculate that out.

285
00:15:57.226 --> 00:16:03.194
So now if I can move this around,
255 wasn't enough, 65,000 was too many.

286
00:16:03.194 --> 00:16:05.401
What if I could move it somewhere in here?

287
00:16:05.401 --> 00:16:07.554
Well, how could I move that number?

288
00:16:07.554 --> 00:16:10.675
How could I put 1s in, say,
the first four digits, well,

289
00:16:10.675 --> 00:16:13.120
let's just say the first two digits,
right?

290
00:16:13.120 --> 00:16:14.910
Move it over just a little bit.

291
00:16:14.910 --> 00:16:21.782
Well, if I turn those first two digits
into 1s, What is this number now?

292
00:16:21.782 --> 00:16:26.388
11000000 is 192.

293
00:16:26.388 --> 00:16:28.159
All right, so there we go.

294
00:16:28.159 --> 00:16:29.447
We got a custom subnet mask.

295
00:16:29.447 --> 00:16:37.298
255.255.192, now the dividing line is
right here where those 1s go to 0s.

296
00:16:37.298 --> 00:16:41.932
Now I only have 8 and 6, that's 14 0s.

297
00:16:41.932 --> 00:16:44.890
So our 14 bits to work with
the host portion of the address.

298
00:16:44.890 --> 00:16:47.670
2 to the 14th is a lot
less than 2 to the 16th.

299
00:16:47.670 --> 00:16:50.620
I don't know what that number is,
Wes, you got it?

300
00:16:50.620 --> 00:16:51.519
>> No, I do not.

301
00:16:51.519 --> 00:16:57.390
>> 2 to the power of 14 is,
[LAUGH] Excel's not calculating for me.

302
00:16:57.390 --> 00:17:02.490
Let's turn on, I turn my whole
sheet into text, there we go.

303
00:17:02.490 --> 00:17:08.795
Equals 2 to the power of 14,
that's 16,384.

304
00:17:08.795 --> 00:17:12.170
It's a lot better that 65,000,
still too many.

305
00:17:12.170 --> 00:17:14.440
I could borrow or
I could take away a few more.

306
00:17:14.440 --> 00:17:17.575
What if I put one more 1 in there, right?

307
00:17:17.575 --> 00:17:21.117
So now, it's 128 plus 64,

308
00:17:21.117 --> 00:17:27.326
which is 192 plus 32,
which will be 224, right?

309
00:17:27.326 --> 00:17:28.382
>> And boy, that bumps it up 32,000.

310
00:17:28.382 --> 00:17:32.434
>> So this number goes to a 1.

311
00:17:32.434 --> 00:17:39.040
And so now, we've only got 8, 9,
10, 11, 12, 13 on the host bits.

312
00:17:41.860 --> 00:17:44.760
So now, only 8,000 possible hosts, right?

313
00:17:44.760 --> 00:17:45.710
That's a lot better.

314
00:17:45.710 --> 00:17:48.680
I'm only getting 8,000
addresses from IANA.

315
00:17:48.680 --> 00:17:51.930
They can give those other
addresses to somebody else, right?

316
00:17:51.930 --> 00:17:53.270
That's the idea behind CIDR.

317
00:17:54.320 --> 00:17:58.220
Classless interdomain routing,
CIDR, and we notate it differently.

318
00:17:58.220 --> 00:18:02.480
Rather than just assuming cuz with
class A, B, and C, if I saw a 10

319
00:18:02.480 --> 00:18:06.690
in the first octet or a 12, I knew it
was a class A, I knew the subnet mask.

320
00:18:06.690 --> 00:18:09.510
We talked about the default subnet masks,
right?

321
00:18:09.510 --> 00:18:12.640
But now if we're talking about
classless interdomain routing,

322
00:18:12.640 --> 00:18:14.920
how do I tell you what my subnet is?

323
00:18:14.920 --> 00:18:19.439
You can't just look at it and go,
that's a Class B, and assume 255.255.0.0.

324
00:18:19.439 --> 00:18:21.700
We're not using the classes anymore.

325
00:18:21.700 --> 00:18:25.870
So what I need to tell you instead is,
how many bits are in my subnet mask,

326
00:18:25.870 --> 00:18:28.250
how many 1s are in there.

327
00:18:28.250 --> 00:18:32.190
So what we do is let's say we wanted
to use this subnet mask, all right.

328
00:18:32.190 --> 00:18:38.430
That's 8 bits plus 8 bits plus three more
1s, that's 16, 17, 18, that's 19 bits.

329
00:18:39.960 --> 00:18:46.849
So I'd write my address
something like this, 172.16.

330
00:18:46.849 --> 00:18:48.403
What can I put in there?

331
00:18:48.403 --> 00:18:55.136
Let's say 128.0/18.

332
00:18:55.136 --> 00:18:59.210
Right, so now you know what my network
address is and what my subnet mask is.

333
00:18:59.210 --> 00:19:00.830
Or if this was an actual host address,

334
00:19:00.830 --> 00:19:06.745
it might look something more like this,
all right?

335
00:19:06.745 --> 00:19:10.500
/18, so
you know what the subnet mask is now.

336
00:19:10.500 --> 00:19:14.100
So that's CIDR, or
Classless Interdomain Routing, and

337
00:19:14.100 --> 00:19:18.440
that extended the lifetime of IP
before by several years because it

338
00:19:18.440 --> 00:19:21.380
freed up a lot of addresses, and
it was backwards compatible.

339
00:19:21.380 --> 00:19:24.580
We didn't have to really change anything
on the way routers worked out on

340
00:19:24.580 --> 00:19:25.265
the Internet.

341
00:19:25.265 --> 00:19:28.600
They could actually start aggregating
routes a little more efficiently.

342
00:19:28.600 --> 00:19:30.990
It was a pretty cool
solution to a problem.

343
00:19:30.990 --> 00:19:35.803
It was meant as a temporary solution, it
was never meant to be a permanent solution

344
00:19:35.803 --> 00:19:40.294
or a fix for IPv4, because the address
space is still too limited in IPv4.

345
00:19:40.294 --> 00:19:45.580
You only have, what did we say, 4 billion,
200 some odd million addresses.

346
00:19:45.580 --> 00:19:49.210
And I think I read something by Cisco
one time, they figured, on average,

347
00:19:49.210 --> 00:19:51.090
people have five or six devices.

348
00:19:51.090 --> 00:19:52.800
And there's how many people in the world?

349
00:19:52.800 --> 00:19:54.175
Multiply that by five?

350
00:19:54.175 --> 00:19:56.060
4 billion addresses isn't gonna cut it.

351
00:19:56.060 --> 00:20:00.770
I can't uniquely identify every machine
out there on the network or in the world.

352
00:20:00.770 --> 00:20:05.200
There's not enough numbers to give
every single node a unique IP address.

353
00:20:05.200 --> 00:20:09.650
So they came up with something else to
add to IPv4 to extend it even more, and

354
00:20:09.650 --> 00:20:12.320
that was something called private ranges.

355
00:20:12.320 --> 00:20:16.710
Within each class, there's actually a
range of addresses that are set aside that

356
00:20:16.710 --> 00:20:20.800
we can use internally, without worrying
about conflicting with anybody else.

357
00:20:20.800 --> 00:20:23.980
Remember, the whole point is these
addresses have to be unique.

358
00:20:23.980 --> 00:20:26.140
I can't use the same address Wes is using.

359
00:20:26.140 --> 00:20:28.110
I can't tell these computers apart.

360
00:20:28.110 --> 00:20:31.929
How do I know what address you're using
at your organization on the other

361
00:20:31.929 --> 00:20:32.940
side of the world?

362
00:20:32.940 --> 00:20:34.070
I have no idea.

363
00:20:34.070 --> 00:20:35.960
I can't just pick a number and
start using it and

364
00:20:35.960 --> 00:20:40.590
hope that nobody else in the entire
world is using that IP address, right?

365
00:20:40.590 --> 00:20:44.380
And do that successfully, guess
a unique number thousands of times for

366
00:20:44.380 --> 00:20:45.840
all the computers on my network.

367
00:20:45.840 --> 00:20:47.550
It's not gonna happen, right?

368
00:20:47.550 --> 00:20:50.140
So what they did was they
said you know what we'll do,

369
00:20:50.140 --> 00:20:53.369
we'll set aside certain numbers
that you can use internally, and

370
00:20:53.369 --> 00:20:56.440
then you don't have to worry
about conflicting with anybody.

371
00:20:56.440 --> 00:21:00.875
Cuz these numbers will never go out to the
Internet, we're gonna tell these boarder

372
00:21:00.875 --> 00:21:05.090
routers if it starts with this, do not
let it go out to the Internet, all right?

373
00:21:05.090 --> 00:21:06.660
And that's what these are, class A,

374
00:21:06.660 --> 00:21:11.351
anything that starts with a 10 is
considered private, non-routable.

375
00:21:11.351 --> 00:21:16.908
Within the class B,
it's 172.16 with a /12.

376
00:21:16.908 --> 00:21:25.244
So 172.16.00 all the way
to 172.31.255.255.

377
00:21:25.244 --> 00:21:28.422
Class C, 192.168.00 /16, so

378
00:21:28.422 --> 00:21:33.950
that's 192.168.00 through 192.168.255.255.

379
00:21:33.950 --> 00:21:36.360
You can use these internally all day long.

380
00:21:36.360 --> 00:21:41.380
You will never conflict with anybody else,
all right, that's not in your same

381
00:21:41.380 --> 00:21:44.690
local area network because those
addresses are never gonna go out.

382
00:21:44.690 --> 00:21:47.740
Now that brings in a whole another
conversation that's another day.

383
00:21:47.740 --> 00:21:53.308
Because if I've got an address on
my device that's 192.168.10.12,

384
00:21:53.308 --> 00:21:55.050
that's not routable.

385
00:21:55.050 --> 00:21:59.230
If I go and open up my browser,
how is it gonna go out to the Internet and

386
00:21:59.230 --> 00:22:00.370
get my web page and

387
00:22:00.370 --> 00:22:04.300
bring it back to me if my IP address is
not allowed to go out on the Internet?

388
00:22:04.300 --> 00:22:06.360
We do something called network
address translation, and

389
00:22:06.360 --> 00:22:10.440
we temporarily translate it into a public
IP address that you can use to go out,

390
00:22:10.440 --> 00:22:13.720
get your web page, come back, and
then you have to give up that address.

391
00:22:13.720 --> 00:22:17.030
It allows me to use very
few public IP addresses,

392
00:22:17.030 --> 00:22:21.550
share them basically, and kind of give
them out to my clients as needed.

393
00:22:21.550 --> 00:22:22.890
And then they give it
up when they're done.

394
00:22:22.890 --> 00:22:26.160
So it's a pretty cool system, but
that's a whole another conversation.

395
00:22:26.160 --> 00:22:30.570
For addressing, I need to make sure
you can recognize a private address,

396
00:22:30.570 --> 00:22:32.210
that's really the big thing here.

397
00:22:32.210 --> 00:22:34.310
If you see an address that
starts with a 192.168,

398
00:22:34.310 --> 00:22:38.600
you need to immediately go,
that's a private address.

399
00:22:38.600 --> 00:22:41.800
There's no wonder you can't get out to the
Internet, cuz you're never gonna get out

400
00:22:41.800 --> 00:22:45.320
with that address unless we implement
some other technology, right?

401
00:22:45.320 --> 00:22:47.060
So that's what I wanna
make sure you understand.

402
00:22:47.060 --> 00:22:49.950
What the private addresses are,
also that CIDR notation,

403
00:22:49.950 --> 00:22:52.040
how we denote that the subnet mask.

404
00:22:52.040 --> 00:22:57.141
We just list the number of 1s
that are in that subnet mask.

405
00:22:57.141 --> 00:23:01.210
All right, Wes,
I think we've pounded IPv4 pretty good.

406
00:23:01.210 --> 00:23:03.500
We've got another addressing
scheme to go through,

407
00:23:03.500 --> 00:23:06.640
but probably not enough time
left to hit it just yet.

408
00:23:06.640 --> 00:23:08.700
>> Yeah, I think you're right.

409
00:23:08.700 --> 00:23:11.795
We've got so much information that we
wanna make sure that you have, but

410
00:23:11.795 --> 00:23:14.550
then again, we can't fit all
sometimes in a half hour segment.

411
00:23:14.550 --> 00:23:17.912
So it does look like we are gonna come
back for another segment here, and

412
00:23:17.912 --> 00:23:20.338
we're gonna come back for
a part four, I believe.

413
00:23:20.338 --> 00:23:22.826
And Mike, do you have anything else
you'd like to throw in this one, or

414
00:23:22.826 --> 00:23:25.140
we're gonna cliff hanger it and
make them wait for the next part?

415
00:23:25.140 --> 00:23:27.285
>> Okay, we'll leave them hanging
on the edge of their seats.

416
00:23:27.285 --> 00:23:30.975
We've still got subnetting and
IPv6 to do, so don't go too far.

417
00:23:30.975 --> 00:23:33.375
>> All right, well Mike,
thanks for being here with us.

418
00:23:33.375 --> 00:23:35.305
And we appreciate you,
the viewer, watching.

419
00:23:35.305 --> 00:23:38.865
We're gonna go ahead and take the time to
sign out for ITProTV, I've been your host,

420
00:23:38.865 --> 00:23:39.555
Wes Bryan.

421
00:23:39.555 --> 00:23:40.345
>> And I'm Mike Roderick.

422
00:23:40.345 --> 00:23:41.962
>> And we'll see you next time.

423
00:23:41.962 --> 00:23:49.120
[MUSIC]

424
00:23:49.120 --> 00:23:52.317
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

All right, we've been talking about IPv4,

16
00:00:40.831 --> 00:00:45.483
we need to cover with IPv4, and then we

17
00:00:45.483 --> 00:00:49.039
All right, so
back to IPv4 we've talked about classful,

18
00:00:49.039 --> 00:00:54.240
we talked about classless, we talked about
the subnet mask and a couple of rules.

19
00:00:54.240 --> 00:00:57.863
Ones from the left until you get to

20
00:00:57.863 --> 00:01:01.939
We talked about how that
subnet mask is responsible for

21

22

We didn't really cover any Binary ANDing.

23
00:01:10.510 --> 00:01:12.710
That's gonna be one that I'm
gonna leave for you guys.

24
00:01:12.710 --> 00:01:15.440
And what you're gonna have to pay
attention to is, when you're using

25
00:01:15.440 --> 00:01:20.000
classless inter domain routing, we start
breaking it in the middle of an octet,

26
00:01:20.000 --> 00:01:23.770
it does become a little more tricky
to figure out what the network ID is.

27
00:01:23.770 --> 00:01:27.280
Because on some of those bits in
the octet are on the network side.

28
00:01:27.280 --> 00:01:30.000
Some of those bits are on the host side.

29
00:01:30.000 --> 00:01:33.980
So when you have a number
like 152 in that octet,

30
00:01:33.980 --> 00:01:35.870
and now you're dividing in the middle.

31
00:01:35.870 --> 00:01:39.011
Think of a binary version of 152.

32
00:01:39.011 --> 00:01:43.835
There's a 1 out there and a 128,
that's gonna be on the network side.

33
00:01:43.835 --> 00:01:47.050
But some of the other bits
are on the node side, right?

34
00:01:47.050 --> 00:01:50.540

00:14:27.700 --> 00:14:34.350
Then we take that and we divide it up
because one string of 32 hexadecimal

258
00:14:34.350 --> 00:14:38.050
characters is still a little bit awkward,
so we're gonna divide that up.

259
00:14:38.050 --> 00:14:40.000
Just like we took our decimal number and

260
00:14:40.000 --> 00:14:45.550
created octets, divided those bits up
into 8 bit chunks with decimal points,

261
00:14:45.550 --> 00:14:50.679
we're gonna take this and divide it
up into 4 hexadecimal characters.

262
00:14:51.740 --> 00:14:57.510
Which would be 16 bits, and we're gonna
divide that up 16 bits at a time,

263
00:14:57.510 --> 00:14:59.540
using colons, not decimals.

264
00:14:59.540 --> 00:15:01.080
We're gonna use a colon.

265
00:15:01.080 --> 00:15:07.840
So, we call this one coloned hexadecimal
versus dotted decimal in our IPv4.

266
00:15:07.840 --> 00:15:12.222
Dotted decimal because we're using dots,
and it's a decimal numbering system.

267
00:15:12.222 --> 00:15:13.400
Coloned hexadecimal,

268
00:15:13.400 --> 00:15:17.930
colons as the separator, hexadecimal
as the numbering system, all right?

269
00:15:17.930 --> 00:15:21.360
So that whole long number here,
this 128 bits,

270
00:15:21.360 --> 00:15:26.110
can actually be represented right
there in hexadecimal, all right?

271
00:15:26.110 --> 00:15:29.084
So that is an IPv6 address.

272
00:15:29.084 --> 00:15:33.000
Now even that is a little bit long, right?

273
00:15:33.000 --> 00:15:36.160
It's kind of awkward to write out.

274
00:15:36.160 --> 00:15:41.870
So there are shortcuts to writing IPv6
addresses and working with IPv6 addresses.

275
00:15:41.870 --> 00:15:43.680
So let's take a look at those next.

276
00:15:45.455 --> 00:15:47.245
All right, so there's a couple
of different tricks we can use

277
00:15:47.245 --> 00:15:48.275
to shorten that up.

278
00:15:48.275 --> 00:15:51.855
I'm gonna zoom in a little bit, so
we can see this a little bit better.

279
00:15:51.855 --> 00:15:54.807
Here's an address, an IPv6 address.

280
00:15:54.807 --> 00:15:58.871
And the first thing we can do
is we can drop leading 0s.

281
00:15:58.871 --> 00:16:03.760
We know that every group has
four hexidecimal digits in it.

282
00:16:03.760 --> 00:16:05.310
Like this second group here is 0db8.

283
00:16:07.180 --> 00:16:08.840
This third one is 0000.

284
00:16:08.840 --> 00:16:11.916
The next one is 0001.

285
00:16:11.916 --> 00:16:15.600
What I can do is I can just
drop off the leading zeros.

286
00:16:15.600 --> 00:16:17.043
Notice how I just have db8.

287
00:16:17.043 --> 00:16:18.570
There's no zero.

288
00:16:18.570 --> 00:16:22.660
All right,
just this next one is just a 0, it's :0:.

289
00:16:22.660 --> 00:16:26.160
I've dropped off the first three zeros.

290
00:16:26.160 --> 00:16:29.930
The next one which was 0001,
becomes just a 1.

291
00:16:29.930 --> 00:16:32.840
I can drop the leading zeros,

292
00:16:32.840 --> 00:16:37.940
because we know we can assume that
there's always four characters, and

293
00:16:37.940 --> 00:16:42.500
if you drop one out it had to have been
a 0, it's the only thing that's allowed.

294
00:16:42.500 --> 00:16:44.600
So, leading zeros can be dropped.

295
00:16:44.600 --> 00:16:49.960
And now, we can see, I have a much
shorter version of that same address.

296
00:16:49.960 --> 00:16:52.080
It can be put back together
easily by saying, wait,

297
00:16:52.080 --> 00:16:53.270
there's only three characters, db8?

298
00:16:53.270 --> 00:16:55.907
There must have been a zero out there.

299
00:16:55.907 --> 00:16:58.430
This one is just a single zero.

300
00:16:58.430 --> 00:17:00.080
There should have been four characters, so

301
00:17:00.080 --> 00:17:02.530
I'll just put three zeros
out in front of it, right?

302
00:17:02.530 --> 00:17:06.000
So we can rebuild it very easily,
computers can rebuild it very easily,

303
00:17:06.000 --> 00:17:09.460
yet it makes it a lot shorter and
easier for us to write.

304
00:17:09.460 --> 00:17:12.863
>> You know Mike, I didn't even really
mention this, but I've seen that the IPV4

305
00:17:12.863 --> 00:17:16.183
was essentially doing the same thing
without even thinking about it, right?

306
00:17:16.183 --> 00:17:22.340
You had a 192.168.10.54 yet,
those are supposed to be three zeros.

307
00:17:22.340 --> 00:17:24.150
But, they don't include them, right?

308
00:17:24.150 --> 00:17:26.380
They don't say 0-54 or 0-0-1.

309
00:17:26.380 --> 00:17:28.860
So, the concept looks like
it's close to the same.

310
00:17:28.860 --> 00:17:29.970
>> Yeah, very, very similar.

311
00:17:29.970 --> 00:17:31.330
Exactly right.

312
00:17:31.330 --> 00:17:33.890
And this one can be shortened to.

313
00:17:33.890 --> 00:17:39.184
Because another cool thing we can do is if
we have multiple blocks of zeros in a row,

314
00:17:39.184 --> 00:17:39.733
right.

315
00:17:39.733 --> 00:17:41.256
Here I've dropped all the leading zeros.

316
00:17:41.256 --> 00:17:46.064
So it's 0:0: 0:1.

317
00:17:46.064 --> 00:17:49.183
Well all these zeros that in a row,

318
00:17:49.183 --> 00:17:53.925
I can simply drop them out and
leave the outer colon.

319
00:17:53.925 --> 00:17:57.839
So notice what I did here,
right there if you can see that.

320
00:17:57.839 --> 00:17:59.250
It's 2001:db8:0:1::1.

321
00:17:59.250 --> 00:18:00.190
All right?

322
00:18:00.190 --> 00:18:08.372
And why does that work?

323
00:18:08.372 --> 00:18:15.290
Well because we know the rules say there
are eight groups in an IPv6 address.

324
00:18:15.290 --> 00:18:22.540
There is only one, two, three, four, five
in the address I've have written here.

325
00:18:22.540 --> 00:18:28.320
So that colon colon must represent
the three missing groups of zeros, right?

326
00:18:28.320 --> 00:18:29.280
It's that simple.

327
00:18:29.280 --> 00:18:33.950
If you got blocks of zeros in a row,
you can just leave them all out.

328
00:18:33.950 --> 00:18:35.790
Just put colon, colon and

329
00:18:35.790 --> 00:18:40.230
I can figure out how many zeros should've
been there by what's still there.

330
00:18:40.230 --> 00:18:44.410
Five groups left that means there's three
groups missing, they were all zeros.

331
00:18:44.410 --> 00:18:47.700
>> Mike, now if I'm looking at
an IPv6 address let's say on an exam.

332
00:18:47.700 --> 00:18:48.610
I'm sitting on that hot seat.

333
00:18:48.610 --> 00:18:53.680
Man, I'm sweating it and I see an IPv6,
what I think is an IPv6 question,

334
00:18:53.680 --> 00:18:56.880
and it's got two of
the colon colons there.

335
00:18:56.880 --> 00:18:58.270
Is that a valid IPv6 address?

336
00:18:58.270 --> 00:19:00.900
>> That's a great question, and it is not.

337
00:19:00.900 --> 00:19:01.510
Let's take a look.

338
00:19:01.510 --> 00:19:04.985
Well let's talk about why and
we'll take a look as well as why or

339
00:19:04.985 --> 00:19:07.098
I'll show you why you can't do that.

340
00:19:07.098 --> 00:19:09.776
Here's another address,

341
00:19:09.776 --> 00:19:15.710
2001:db8:0:0:1234:0:0:1.

342
00:19:15.710 --> 00:19:20.460
And you might think to yourself,
blocks of zeroes in a row, I can just drop

343
00:19:20.460 --> 00:19:24.140
those zeros out and leave the outer colons
so we could do something like this.

344
00:19:24.140 --> 00:19:31.214
2001:db8:: representing those
first set of continuous zeroes,

345
00:19:31.214 --> 00:19:38.750
1234:: representing the second block
of contiguous zeros and then a 1.

346
00:19:38.750 --> 00:19:40.470
Well, that's following your rules Mike.

347
00:19:40.470 --> 00:19:43.700
You said if I had zeros in a row,
I could just drop them all out and

348
00:19:43.700 --> 00:19:46.230
leave the outer two colons and
we're good to go.

349
00:19:46.230 --> 00:19:51.100
The problem is when you try to rebuild
it you don't know where the zeros go.

350
00:19:51.100 --> 00:19:52.490
Yes, I do.

351
00:19:52.490 --> 00:19:55.200
No, you don't know how
many zeroes go where.

352
00:19:55.200 --> 00:19:56.400
That's the problem.

353
00:19:56.400 --> 00:19:59.540
If you just had this, didn't have
any of the other information, and

354
00:19:59.540 --> 00:20:06.920
I said put that address back, write it out
all 128 or all 32 accessible characters.

355
00:20:06.920 --> 00:20:08.040
How would you do it?

356
00:20:08.040 --> 00:20:10.430
Well how many blocks do I have left?

357
00:20:10.430 --> 00:20:14.560
One, two, three, four, so
there's four missing blocks.

358
00:20:14.560 --> 00:20:18.356
We know those are blocks of zeros.

359
00:20:18.356 --> 00:20:20.670
I've got two colons here and
I've got two colons here.

360
00:20:20.670 --> 00:20:26.770
The problem is, was it three blocks of
zeroes here and one block of zeros here?

361
00:20:26.770 --> 00:20:31.500
Or was it one block of zeros here,
and three blocks of zeros here?

362
00:20:31.500 --> 00:20:33.721
Or was it two here and two here?

363
00:20:33.721 --> 00:20:38.027
You have no way of knowing, there's
nothing left to help you figure that out,

364
00:20:38.027 --> 00:20:40.290
so it cannot be put back together.

365
00:20:40.290 --> 00:20:44.370
So you can only do the colon
colon once in an address.

366
00:20:44.370 --> 00:20:47.740
Even if you have two separate
areas of contiguous zeros,

367
00:20:47.740 --> 00:20:49.540
you have to pick which one, all right.

368
00:20:49.540 --> 00:20:53.010
Usually, the longer of the two is the one
I'm going to do the colon colon for

369
00:20:53.010 --> 00:20:55.520
cuz its less typing and
less writing, all right.

370
00:20:55.520 --> 00:20:58.109
So, both of these would be acceptable.

371
00:20:58.109 --> 00:21:00.205
Oops, we wanna get out of that.

372
00:21:00.205 --> 00:21:05.689
2001:db8::1234, since I've
already used the colon colon,

373
00:21:05.689 --> 00:21:08.956
I cannot use the colon
colon to replace this.

374
00:21:08.956 --> 00:21:11.730
So, :0:0:1.

375
00:21:11.730 --> 00:21:18.111
Or I could have gone the other way,
2001 db8:0:1234::1.

376
00:21:18.111 --> 00:21:22.110
So you can only do the colon colon
once in a single IPv6 address.

377
00:21:22.110 --> 00:21:23.170
>> I see what you did there.

378
00:21:23.170 --> 00:21:25.310
So you say, okay, if it's easier to type,

379
00:21:25.310 --> 00:21:29.850
I'll take, in this case, the majority
of the blocks that I can shorten.

380
00:21:29.850 --> 00:21:33.120
But I can also still abbreviate cuz
like you said, with the leading zeros,

381
00:21:33.120 --> 00:21:34.738
we can go a little bit farther than that.

382
00:21:34.738 --> 00:21:35.547
>> Yep.
>> It's just really up to us.

383
00:21:35.547 --> 00:21:39.020
>> Yeah, exactly.

384
00:21:39.020 --> 00:21:44.677
Look at the first one we did up here,
2001:dv8:0:1:0:0:0:1.

385
00:21:44.677 --> 00:21:49.610
I could have put the colon, colon right
here and drop this block of zeros.

386
00:21:49.610 --> 00:21:51.490
But then I'd have to write
all three of these zeros cuz

387
00:21:51.490 --> 00:21:53.250
I can't do the colon colon again.

388
00:21:53.250 --> 00:21:56.520
So I said, you know what,
it's easier if I drag this zero and

389
00:21:56.520 --> 00:21:59.660
use the colon colon to
represent these three zeros.

390
00:21:59.660 --> 00:22:03.720
It's much less typing to do,
much less entry to do, right?

391
00:22:03.720 --> 00:22:06.400
So those are a couple of
tricks you can do with IPv6.

392
00:22:06.400 --> 00:22:11.200
Drop your leading zeros,
condense a block of zeros to a single

393
00:22:11.200 --> 00:22:14.560
zero which is basically the same
thing of dropping your leading zeros.

394
00:22:14.560 --> 00:22:18.330
And then use colon colon for
multiple blocks of zeros in a row.

395
00:22:19.390 --> 00:22:19.940
But only once.

396
00:22:20.970 --> 00:22:24.630
Next with IPv6, let's talk about prefixes.

397
00:22:26.260 --> 00:22:30.030
IPv6 doesn't use subnet masks
like we talked about with IPv4.

398
00:22:31.450 --> 00:22:33.260
Which is a good thing.

399
00:22:33.260 --> 00:22:37.960
It basically takes that CIDR notation and
brings that over with it.

400
00:22:37.960 --> 00:22:43.240
What we're gonna do with IPv6 is we're
gonna use that similar notation,

401
00:22:43.240 --> 00:22:45.220
a slash and then a number,

402
00:22:45.220 --> 00:22:49.940
to represent how many bits are part
of what's called the prefix.

403
00:22:51.850 --> 00:22:54.200
An IPv6 address is 128 bits.

404
00:22:54.200 --> 00:22:57.050
And really it's divided in a half.

405
00:22:57.050 --> 00:23:04.460
The first 64 bits are for network ID,
routing, subnet IDs all that staff.

406
00:23:04.460 --> 00:23:07.900
The last 64 bits are for your host.

407
00:23:07.900 --> 00:23:13.102
Therefore, identifying a unique host,
those will always be unique, the last 64.

408
00:23:13.102 --> 00:23:15.710
So we're really basically
dividing it into half

409
00:23:15.710 --> 00:23:20.680
which means most IPv6 addresses are gonna
be written down with a slash 64.

410
00:23:20.680 --> 00:23:23.902
Indicating that the first 64
bits are on that side and

411
00:23:23.902 --> 00:23:28.710
they're gonna represent things like
routing prefix, global routing prefix or

412
00:23:28.710 --> 00:23:34.130
company ID, or subnet mask or, I'm sorry
not subnet mask, subnet ID, network ID.

413
00:23:34.130 --> 00:23:38.130
The last 64 are gonna be for
your host portion.

414
00:23:38.130 --> 00:23:42.410
There are a few prefixes that
we should really just know.

415
00:23:42.410 --> 00:23:44.587
And that's what I've got
up on my screen here.

416
00:23:44.587 --> 00:23:46.720
These are our special numbers.

417
00:23:46.720 --> 00:23:49.539
Like in IPv4, we have special numbers.

418
00:23:49.539 --> 00:23:53.343
We know that a 0.0.0.0 is
an unspecified address,

419
00:23:53.343 --> 00:23:56.601
we know that 127001 is
a loop back address,

420
00:23:56.601 --> 00:24:01.201
we know that a 169254 something,
something is APIPA, right?

421
00:24:01.201 --> 00:24:05.491
So there are special numbers
in IPv4 Also in IPv6.

422
00:24:05.491 --> 00:24:09.103
::1/128.

423
00:24:09.103 --> 00:24:10.968
Wow, what does that mean?

424
00:24:10.968 --> 00:24:15.008
Well, :: that means everything is a zero,
except for the very last lock.

425
00:24:15.008 --> 00:24:20.955
So that's basically 127 0s and
a 1 for the last bit.

426
00:24:20.955 --> 00:24:24.117
And it's saying 128,
they're saying the entire number,

427
00:24:24.117 --> 00:24:25.679
none of its ever gonna change.

428
00:24:25.679 --> 00:24:27.158
The whole thing is your prefix.

429
00:24:27.158 --> 00:24:31.500
That is your loopback address in IPv6 ::1,
alright?

430
00:24:31.500 --> 00:24:33.735
Unspecified is ::/128.

431
00:24:33.735 --> 00:24:41.238
::, no numbers at all, that means you
got 128 0s, and that's it, right?

432
00:24:41.238 --> 00:24:48.167
In IPv4 it was easy, we could type 0.0.0.0
to specify an unspecified address, wow.

433
00:24:48.167 --> 00:24:49.485
>> That's redundancy.

434
00:24:49.485 --> 00:24:52.883
>> That is.
To indicate an unspecified address.

435
00:24:52.883 --> 00:24:58.207
Try doing 0000:0000:0000:000,

436
00:24:58.207 --> 00:25:01.450
until you have 132 0s.

437
00:25:01.450 --> 00:25:02.750
Well, that's ridiculous.

438
00:25:02.750 --> 00:25:04.800
So how about just ::, right?

439
00:25:04.800 --> 00:25:07.570
That means they're all zeros,
it's unspecified.

440
00:25:07.570 --> 00:25:13.720
Any IPV6 address that starts with
an FE80 is considered link local.

441
00:25:13.720 --> 00:25:17.800
And that means it's the same thing
as a private IP address in IPV4.

442
00:25:19.060 --> 00:25:19.690
All right?

443
00:25:19.690 --> 00:25:22.550
We got those private,
non-routeable addresses that

444
00:25:22.550 --> 00:25:25.180
are not allowed to go out to the Internet
that you can use internally.

445
00:25:25.180 --> 00:25:27.820
And they won't conflict with anybody else.

446
00:25:27.820 --> 00:25:28.850
We have the same thing IPv6.

447
00:25:28.850 --> 00:25:30.500
It's an FE80.

448
00:25:30.500 --> 00:25:34.570
Anything that starts with FE80 is not
allowed to go out to the Internet.

449
00:25:34.570 --> 00:25:38.740
It's considered local to
that particular subnet.

450
00:25:38.740 --> 00:25:42.065
We also have unique locals that
can be routed internally but

451
00:25:42.065 --> 00:25:43.470
not out to the Internet.

452
00:25:43.470 --> 00:25:45.260
Those are fc00.

453
00:25:45.260 --> 00:25:49.310
Multicast is anything
that starts with an FF00.

454
00:25:49.310 --> 00:25:53.130
Global Unicasts start with 2000,
all right?

455
00:25:53.130 --> 00:25:56.590
A Global Unicast address,
this is one that can be routed.

456
00:25:56.590 --> 00:26:00.380
This is like an IPv4 public IP address.

457
00:26:00.380 --> 00:26:03.540
It has to be unique throughout
the entire world and

458
00:26:03.540 --> 00:26:05.620
it is routeable out there on the internet.

459
00:26:06.820 --> 00:26:08.600
And then there's one for documentation.

460
00:26:08.600 --> 00:26:14.810
When you read things about IPv6,
when you go read the RFCs from the IETF or

461
00:26:14.810 --> 00:26:17.480
something like that which I know
everybody out there is doing.

462
00:26:17.480 --> 00:26:19.950
I know I love to do that.

463
00:26:19.950 --> 00:26:21.826
They'll use example addresses.

464
00:26:21.826 --> 00:26:28.180
2001:db8 is set aside for that purpose,
so that anytime you see that, you know

465
00:26:28.180 --> 00:26:32.795
this is an example and I need to replace
it with actual IPv6 addresses, right?

466
00:26:32.795 --> 00:26:38.679
So 2001:db8::, means the rest of its 0s,
is gonna be for documentation.

467
00:26:40.130 --> 00:26:41.820
All right.
Last thing we're going to talk

468
00:26:41.820 --> 00:26:44.410
about with IPv6 is going to be subnetting.

469
00:26:45.940 --> 00:26:47.350
But unfortunately,

470
00:26:47.350 --> 00:26:51.110
it's going to take me more than the time
that Wes is telling me that I've got left.

471
00:26:51.110 --> 00:26:52.860
So I'm going to turn it back over to Wes.

472
00:26:52.860 --> 00:26:53.540
Let him close it out.

473
00:26:53.540 --> 00:26:57.457
We're going to have to come back for yet
another part of network fundamentals.

474
00:26:57.457 --> 00:27:00.060
>> Well what can you say about that,

So that's a great place to wrap up, we do
appreciate, Mike, as always you being here

476
00:27:04.432 --> 00:27:07.860
in the studio with us and

not be as fast in those places.

446
00:25:17.150 --> 00:25:20.190
Now Mike, it does look like we're
coming to the end of another episode.

447
00:25:20.190 --> 00:25:23.904
But before we sign out, do you have any
additional advice you'd like to give in

448
00:25:23.904 --> 00:25:25.934
general about networking fundamentals,

449
00:25:25.934 --> 00:25:28.432
or maybe even additional
information about IPv6?

450
00:25:28.432 --> 00:25:31.706
>> I would say play around with it,
take a look at it.

451
00:25:31.706 --> 00:25:36.390
Like I said, experiment on your home
network, do some IP config or IF config.

452
00:25:36.390 --> 00:25:38.720
See if you've got IPv6 there.

453
00:25:40.220 --> 00:25:44.680
The main thing is, don't be scared of it,
it's a much bigger number, but

454
00:25:44.680 --> 00:25:47.130
in the end, binary is binary.

455
00:25:47.130 --> 00:25:49.200
Doing the way we subnet,

456
00:25:49.200 --> 00:25:53.030
it's still the same, binary math,
we're not doing it quite the same way.

457
00:25:53.030 --> 00:25:58.690
But in the end, it's just a bigger
address base, and because it's

458
00:25:58.690 --> 00:26:04.160
mostly automated, it's actually easier to
work with than IPv4, in my humble opinion.

459
00:26:04.160 --> 00:26:08.512
Because I can set it, set my advertisement
up with my company prefix, and

460
00:26:08.512 --> 00:26:11.340
then let the nodes do all
the rest of the work themselves.

461
00:26:11.340 --> 00:26:13.699
We can still statically
map nodes with IPv6.

462
00:26:15.050 --> 00:26:19.010
So just start getting used to it, because
it's gonna be here sooner than you think,

463
00:26:19.010 --> 00:26:19.880
you're gonna have to use it.

464
00:26:19.880 --> 00:26:22.460
>> All right, well, that's a wealth of
knowledge on networking fundamentals.

465
00:26:22.460 --> 00:26:24.140
Remember, review those videos.

466
00:26:24.140 --> 00:26:27.726
Going ahead and signing out for ITProTV,
I've been your host, Wes Bryan.

467
00:26:27.726 --> 00:26:28.724
>> And I'm Mike Roderick.

468
00:26:28.724 --> 00:26:31.673
>> And we'll see you next time.

469
00:26:31.673 --> 00:26:37.734
[MUSIC]

470
00:26:37.734 --> 00:26:40.625
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Mike dive into one of the most important services in networking known as the domain naming system or DNS. They look at the architecture, service, records as well as explaining the process of name resolution within networks today.
episodes.title: Understanding DNS
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:06.673
Welcome to ITProTV,
I'm your host [CROSSTALK]

2
00:00:06.673 --> 00:00:08.298
[MUSIC]

3
00:00:08.298 --> 00:00:12.949
>> You're watching ITProTV
>> Welcome back to

4
00:00:12.949 --> 00:00:15.115
another exciting episode here at ITProTV.

5
00:00:15.115 --> 00:00:17.831
I'm your host, Wes Bryan,
and in today's episode,

6
00:00:17.831 --> 00:00:21.120
we're continuing through our
GIAC security fundamentals.

7
00:00:21.120 --> 00:00:22.950
And we're going to be talking
about a service right now,

8
00:00:22.950 --> 00:00:25.610
that is one of the most important
services out there in the Internet,

9
00:00:25.610 --> 00:00:28.990
that lets us find just about everything.

10
00:00:28.990 --> 00:00:31.600
And joining us in the studios
is none other than Mike Roger.

11
00:00:31.600 --> 00:00:32.510
Mike, how are you doing, sir?

12
00:00:32.510 --> 00:00:33.320
>> I'm doing great, Wes.

13
00:00:33.320 --> 00:00:35.570
Thanks for having me, and you're right.

14
00:00:35.570 --> 00:00:39.340
One of my favorite topics, and I know I
say that about several different topics,

15
00:00:39.340 --> 00:00:43.940
but it is, it's definitely up there in
my top 5 because DNS is, as Wes said,

16
00:00:43.940 --> 00:00:45.570
just an extremely important service.

17
00:00:45.570 --> 00:00:48.340
It really allows our networks
to function like they do.

18
00:00:48.340 --> 00:00:50.600
Without it, we'd have a difficult time.

19
00:00:50.600 --> 00:00:54.170
I mean, it wouldn't be impossible but
it would be much more difficult.

20
00:00:54.170 --> 00:00:54.870
Why is that?

21
00:00:54.870 --> 00:01:01.970
Well, let's talk about what DNS is, what
it does for us that makes it so important.

22
00:01:01.970 --> 00:01:03.960
First, let's define the acronym, right?

23
00:01:03.960 --> 00:01:08.200
DNS is Domain Name System and
the idea behind DNS is.

24
00:01:08.200 --> 00:01:11.500
This is, what's a good way to say this?

25
00:01:11.500 --> 00:01:15.290
Computers deal with numbers, ones and
zeros is really all they care about.

26
00:01:15.290 --> 00:01:18.630
They don't care what you call your
computer, they wanna know it's IP address,

27
00:01:18.630 --> 00:01:19.820
for example, right?

28
00:01:19.820 --> 00:01:23.180
And we've seen that,
we write it in decimal or hex, but

29
00:01:23.180 --> 00:01:25.510
it gets broken down to ones and
zeros in the end.

30
00:01:25.510 --> 00:01:27.510
So computers deal with numbers, right?

31
00:01:27.510 --> 00:01:31.570
But as humans, we deal with names
much better than we do with numbers.

32
00:01:31.570 --> 00:01:35.040
And I can give you a great example,
look at your phone, right?

33
00:01:35.040 --> 00:01:37.180
If I go to call my father,
I don't know about you Wes,

34
00:01:37.180 --> 00:01:40.600
but if I need to call my dad, I go to
my contacts, and I look him up by name.

35
00:01:40.600 --> 00:01:43.070
There's dad and I touch him,
I don't know his phone number.

36
00:01:43.070 --> 00:01:46.870
I honestly don't even know my own father's
phone number, but he's in my contacts.

37
00:01:46.870 --> 00:01:50.020
I can look him up by name, got all
these contacts that I look up by name.

38
00:01:50.020 --> 00:01:53.930
I don't need to memorize everybody's phone
number, cuz I've got a system on my phone,

39
00:01:53.930 --> 00:01:58.210
my contact app, that when I tell
it what name I'm trying to call,

40
00:01:58.210 --> 00:01:59.790
it can look it up in its little table.

41
00:01:59.790 --> 00:02:02.280
And say okay,
that name is this phone number, and

42
00:02:02.280 --> 00:02:03.920
it can call that phone number, right?

43
00:02:03.920 --> 00:02:05.930
And now I can connect to my dad,
and we can talk.

44
00:02:05.930 --> 00:02:10.090
Well DNS is doing the same thing for us
when it comes to resources on our network.

45
00:02:10.090 --> 00:02:14.240
It allows us to connect to resources
by name, because names are easier for

46
00:02:14.240 --> 00:02:15.250
us to remember.

47
00:02:15.250 --> 00:02:19.290
Even though in the end,
it's all done by IP address.

48
00:02:19.290 --> 00:02:23.880
When you connect to your favorite search
engine or your favorite shopping site,

49
00:02:23.880 --> 00:02:29.180
what do you type in
the address bar up there?

50
00:02:29.180 --> 00:02:31.080
You're not typing 12.1.47.142, right?

51
00:02:31.080 --> 00:02:33.281
You're typing www.google.com or

52
00:02:33.281 --> 00:02:36.750
www.newegg.com, or
whatever the case may be.

53
00:02:36.750 --> 00:02:39.380
Well your computer can
not connect to a name,

54
00:02:39.380 --> 00:02:41.180
there's no way it can connect to a name.

55
00:02:41.180 --> 00:02:46.940
So what it has to do is take that name
you've typed in and somehow resolve it,

56
00:02:46.940 --> 00:02:52.259
look it up and figure out what the IP
address is for www.google.com.

57
00:02:52.259 --> 00:02:55.207
That means somewhere there's
this list of names and

58
00:02:55.207 --> 00:03:00.040
IP addresses, that it can look it up in,
and figure out what the IP address is.

59
00:03:00.040 --> 00:03:01.550
And that's what DNS does.

60
00:03:01.550 --> 00:03:04.200
DNS is our phone book for our computers.

61
00:03:04.200 --> 00:03:09.690
It's a mapping of host names, fully
qualified domain names to be specific,

62
00:03:09.690 --> 00:03:13.950
fully qualified domain names,
or FQDMs, to IP addresses.

63
00:03:13.950 --> 00:03:17.490
So when you type that in, what's happening
in the background is your computer is

64
00:03:17.490 --> 00:03:22.470
sending out a query, and a query, or
a DNS query is just a question that's

65
00:03:22.470 --> 00:03:27.480
given to a DNS server, says hey, my user's
trying to connect to www.google.com.

66
00:03:27.480 --> 00:03:29.690
What the heck is the IP address of that?

67
00:03:29.690 --> 00:03:32.870
Your server, or
that DNS server that you're talking to,

68
00:03:32.870 --> 00:03:37.480
is gonna go through a series of
steps to locate that name and

69
00:03:37.480 --> 00:03:40.670
find that IP address and
then return it to your machine.

70
00:03:40.670 --> 00:03:45.460
And your browser magically
goes to www.google.com.

71
00:03:45.460 --> 00:03:46.830
That's what DNS is all about.

72
00:03:46.830 --> 00:03:49.970
And without it,
could I still connect to Google?

73
00:03:49.970 --> 00:03:51.170
Absolutely.

74
00:03:51.170 --> 00:03:53.760
If I know the IP address, right.

75
00:03:53.760 --> 00:03:55.140
You can try it.

76
00:03:55.140 --> 00:03:55.750
Ping something.

77
00:03:55.750 --> 00:03:57.710
Open up a command prompt, or here.

78
00:03:57.710 --> 00:03:59.380
I say try it,
why don't I try it and show you.

79
00:03:59.380 --> 00:04:00.190
How about that?

80
00:04:00.190 --> 00:04:04.110
Let me open up a command prompt here,
on my machine.

81
00:04:05.630 --> 00:04:08.040
All right, so first let me make
this a little bit bigger so

82
00:04:08.040 --> 00:04:11.210
it's gonna be easier for
my old eyes to see.

83
00:04:11.210 --> 00:04:14.900
We'll bump that up and change my layout so
it still fits on the screen.

84
00:04:14.900 --> 00:04:21.650
Something like that,
hopefully it will work, all right.

85
00:04:21.650 --> 00:04:22.830
I don't think you guys can see out there.

86
00:04:22.830 --> 00:04:27.890
I'm gonna ping Google,
if I could spell it .com.

87
00:04:27.890 --> 00:04:32.240
And I'm not really worried about the pings
as much as what's happening here.

88
00:04:32.240 --> 00:04:36.770
I typed in a name, computers cannot
connect to a name, they can't ping a name,

89
00:04:36.770 --> 00:04:41.800
so my computer had to take that name I
typed in, and turn it into an IP Address.

90
00:04:41.800 --> 00:04:44.320
So it used DNS to do that.

91
00:04:44.320 --> 00:04:47.570
Well now I've got the IP Address
of Google, so let's do this.

92
00:04:47.570 --> 00:04:49.330
Let me open up a browser.

93
00:04:49.330 --> 00:04:54.323
We'll switch to a different page, MSN.com.

94
00:04:54.323 --> 00:04:58.049
And let's see what happens if
I go to my address bar and

95
00:04:58.049 --> 00:05:03.261
type in 4.59.90.247.

96
00:05:05.120 --> 00:05:05.810
Now look it there.

97
00:05:05.810 --> 00:05:06.760
I went to Google.

98
00:05:06.760 --> 00:05:09.020
So by typing that ip address
I was able to get to it.

99
00:05:09.020 --> 00:05:14.030
So the point to that little exercise
was you can get by without DNS.

100
00:05:14.030 --> 00:05:17.230
If you know the ip address of every
resource you want to connect to.

101
00:05:17.230 --> 00:05:18.770
But therein lies the rub.

102
00:05:18.770 --> 00:05:20.810
How many IP Addresses do you know?

103
00:05:20.810 --> 00:05:22.930
Right?
Do you know the IP Address of Newegg,

104
00:05:22.930 --> 00:05:26.210
Facebook or
whatever other website you wanna go to.

105
00:05:26.210 --> 00:05:29.430
Of your mail server of your
company's Internet portal.

106
00:05:29.430 --> 00:05:31.830
Well those are all members
that now I have to memorize.

107
00:05:31.830 --> 00:05:36.340
With DNS, I can remember google means
search and new egg means computer parts.

108
00:05:36.340 --> 00:05:37.380
Easy for me.

109
00:05:37.380 --> 00:05:40.780
I can't remember that google has 4 dots,
I can't even remember

110
00:05:40.780 --> 00:05:44.744
typing it in 30 seconds ago,
I'm going to have to look again for

111
00:05:44.744 --> 00:05:47.920
that 59.90.47 that's one of their many,
many IP Addresses.

112
00:05:47.920 --> 00:05:50.470
So, the point is DNS
makes it much easier for

113
00:05:50.470 --> 00:05:54.610
us because we can type in
friendly human readable names and

114
00:05:54.610 --> 00:05:59.180
in the background DNS can convert that
into an IP Address and we can connect.

115
00:05:59.180 --> 00:06:02.440
>> Now Mike, is this something that
we have to set up if we're gonna

116
00:06:02.440 --> 00:06:04.160
be working with our networks?

117
00:06:04.160 --> 00:06:06.090
Is this something we're
gonna have to set up, and

118
00:06:06.090 --> 00:06:08.790
is there a certain level of infrastructure
that we might need to be aware of,

119
00:06:08.790 --> 00:06:11.610
to kind of understand the ins and
outs of what's going on here?

120
00:06:11.610 --> 00:06:14.660
>> There definitely is, and
in this particular series,

121
00:06:14.660 --> 00:06:17.390
we're not getting super in depth into DNS.

122
00:06:17.390 --> 00:06:19.675
We've got some other shows in our library.

123
00:06:19.675 --> 00:06:22.580
We definitely cover that in our
server classes and things like that.

124
00:06:22.580 --> 00:06:25.370
We've got a DNS tech skills
show that you can check out.

125
00:06:25.370 --> 00:06:32.060
For GIAC and for specifically
if I can say that the GSEB exam.

126
00:06:32.060 --> 00:06:36.280
They want a high level understanding
of the DNS architecture.

127
00:06:36.280 --> 00:06:40.340
So, we just need to understand the big
pieces of DNS and how it works.

128
00:06:40.340 --> 00:06:42.680
So, lets talk about it in a general way.

129
00:06:42.680 --> 00:06:46.350
So we've said that DNS is
basically a phone book.

130
00:06:46.350 --> 00:06:50.700
One of the cool things about DNS
is how incredibly scalable it is.

131
00:06:50.700 --> 00:06:52.730
The Internet could
double in size tomorrow,

132
00:06:52.730 --> 00:06:55.620
and in some cases it almost does,
it seems like.

133
00:06:55.620 --> 00:07:00.000
And DNS would keep on trucking,
it wouldn't even skip a beat.

134
00:07:00.000 --> 00:07:03.740
It's really an amazingly
well thought-out plan.

135
00:07:03.740 --> 00:07:05.320
It's just organized.

136
00:07:05.320 --> 00:07:10.660
DNS is a what we call a distributed,
hierarchical database, all right,

137
00:07:10.660 --> 00:07:11.980
which means that it's distributed.

138
00:07:11.980 --> 00:07:15.550
There's not just one server out there
that hosts all this information.

139
00:07:15.550 --> 00:07:17.610
It's distributed and it's hierarchical.

140
00:07:17.610 --> 00:07:21.250
There's different levels,
it's like a pyramid if you will almost.

141
00:07:21.250 --> 00:07:25.130
So let's start locally and
then we're gonna jump to the top and

142
00:07:25.130 --> 00:07:26.900
work our way down of this pyramid.

143
00:07:26.900 --> 00:07:30.120
So first of all, in your organization,
you're responsible for

144
00:07:30.120 --> 00:07:33.010
your own computer's names and
IP Addresses.

145
00:07:33.010 --> 00:07:37.390
In other words, what that means is as
an organization like ITProTV here,

146
00:07:37.390 --> 00:07:40.780
we are gonna run our own DNS server,
all right.

147
00:07:40.780 --> 00:07:42.440
Now when I say you're responsible,

148
00:07:42.440 --> 00:07:46.250
you might run it in house,
this might be out in the cloud.

149
00:07:46.250 --> 00:07:49.570
This might be through a third party
provider that's hosting your DNS

150
00:07:49.570 --> 00:07:51.350
information for you.

151
00:07:51.350 --> 00:07:52.810
But you are responsible.

152
00:07:52.810 --> 00:07:55.343
Whether you pay somebody to do it or
you do it yourself,

153
00:07:55.343 --> 00:07:58.327
your organization is gonna
maintain your own DNS information.

154
00:07:58.327 --> 00:08:02.036
So for all the different devices
on our network here at ITProTV,

155
00:08:02.036 --> 00:08:03.420
there's a DNS server.

156
00:08:03.420 --> 00:08:07.806
That hosts what's called a zone,
a portion of the namespace,

157
00:08:07.806 --> 00:08:10.966
for all those devices
that end in itpro.tv.

158
00:08:10.966 --> 00:08:14.710
Like my computer's name
is mikeslaptop.itpro.tv.

159
00:08:14.710 --> 00:08:20.527
Wes's laptop, I don't know what
it's called, deathstar.itpro.tv.

160
00:08:20.527 --> 00:08:24.895
So all those computers,
all those devices that end in itpro.tv.

161
00:08:24.895 --> 00:08:27.451
I've got a server that has a zone file.

162
00:08:27.451 --> 00:08:32.210
And in there are all those names and
all their IP addresses.

163
00:08:32.210 --> 00:08:36.210
So if I'm looking for anything on my
network, I can talk to our DNS server.

164
00:08:36.210 --> 00:08:39.040
And I can say,
what's the IP address of Wes's laptop?

165
00:08:39.040 --> 00:08:40.340
It can look it up and it can find it.

166
00:08:41.470 --> 00:08:44.760
So each organization is gonna do that.

167
00:08:44.760 --> 00:08:46.494
And this is why I say the Internet
could double tomorrow.

168
00:08:46.494 --> 00:08:48.815
We could have hundreds of
thousands of new companies.

169
00:08:48.815 --> 00:08:53.742
And the DNS infrastructure really doesn't
see that big of a workload increase.

170
00:08:53.742 --> 00:08:57.833
Because all those new companies
are running their own DNS servers,

171
00:08:57.833 --> 00:09:00.380
hosting their portion of the namespace.

172
00:09:00.380 --> 00:09:03.741
So far, we've got our own
DNS server with our names.

173
00:09:03.741 --> 00:09:06.196
So if I need to look up any
other device on our network,

174
00:09:06.196 --> 00:09:09.640
I can talk to my DNS server and
I can get that IP address.

175
00:09:09.640 --> 00:09:14.030
But I sometimes need to connect to
resources that aren't part of my network,

176
00:09:14.030 --> 00:09:17.070
like Google or Microsoft or Technet.

177
00:09:17.070 --> 00:09:22.517
Or in my off time, we start going to
Newegg and to other places like that.

178
00:09:22.517 --> 00:09:24.390
And those are outside my organization.

179
00:09:24.390 --> 00:09:28.660
And Newegg has their own DNS server
with all the names of their devices and

180
00:09:28.660 --> 00:09:30.200
their IP addresses.

181
00:09:30.200 --> 00:09:32.220
Microsoft has their own DNS server.

182
00:09:32.220 --> 00:09:37.260
My DNS server doesn't know
anything about www.microsoft.com.

183
00:09:37.260 --> 00:09:39.197
It doesn't end in itpro.tv.

184
00:09:39.197 --> 00:09:42.060
I maintain my own little
portion of the namespace.

185
00:09:42.060 --> 00:09:46.600
Microsoft has their DNS servers that
handle their portion of the namespace.

186
00:09:46.600 --> 00:09:51.150
So if I wanna connect
to www.microsoft.com,

187
00:09:51.150 --> 00:09:54.290
what I really need to do is talk
to Microsoft's DNS servers.

188
00:09:54.290 --> 00:09:57.320
Cuz my DNS server is not
gonna know the answer.

189
00:09:57.320 --> 00:09:59.230
So then the question becomes,

190
00:09:59.230 --> 00:10:03.430
how do I find out the IP address
of Microsoft's DNS server?

191
00:10:03.430 --> 00:10:07.260
Because the only way I can
connect to it is by IP address.

192
00:10:07.260 --> 00:10:10.675
So how do I find it?

193
00:10:10.675 --> 00:10:15.950
And that's where that distributed
hierarchical structure comes into play.

194
00:10:15.950 --> 00:10:20.140
So let's take a look at my screen here and
we'll see what I mean by that.

195
00:10:20.140 --> 00:10:22.890
So here's my organization down
here in the bottom right.

196
00:10:22.890 --> 00:10:26.562
I've got my little DNS server,
itpro.tv DNS.

197
00:10:26.562 --> 00:10:31.096
And so nodes here on my network can
find other nodes on my network by

198
00:10:31.096 --> 00:10:33.083
talking to this DNS server.
