00:29:37.990 --> 00:29:41.260
And yes, you're the one that you're trying
to capture that data, if you're trying to

553
00:29:41.260 --> 00:29:45.180
capture your own data, which kinda
seem silly because it's your data.

554
00:29:45.180 --> 00:29:46.570
You don't really need to capture it.

555
00:29:47.790 --> 00:29:50.577
I don't know.
Anyway, my point is on switched ethernet,

556
00:29:50.577 --> 00:29:52.571
you do have to take additional steps.

557
00:29:52.571 --> 00:29:57.058
And that means a lot of times a switch can
be configured to do what they call port

558
00:29:57.058 --> 00:30:01.824
mirroring, or when it dumps all traffic
out of a particular port specifically for

559
00:30:01.824 --> 00:30:04.030
the purpose of monitoring.

560
00:30:04.030 --> 00:30:07.623
You might have to do something like
that in order to see that traffic.

561
00:30:07.623 --> 00:30:08.775
I know for a while,

562
00:30:08.775 --> 00:30:12.820
for example, one of the companies
I worked for, we did just that.

563
00:30:12.820 --> 00:30:17.970
We had one of the ports acting as
a monitoring port on the switch and

564
00:30:17.970 --> 00:30:19.360
all traffic was mirrored.

565
00:30:19.360 --> 00:30:23.188
The traffic would go to its normal port,
and when I'm saying port,

566
00:30:23.188 --> 00:30:27.130
it's in switch port,
not port as in TCP/IP port, right?

567
00:30:27.130 --> 00:30:29.520
The traffic was destined for
Mike's computer.

568
00:30:29.520 --> 00:30:32.050
Then the switch would allow it to go
out the port that Mike's computer was

569
00:30:32.050 --> 00:30:32.940
hooked up to.

570
00:30:32.940 --> 00:30:35.970
But it would duplicate it and
also send it to that mirroring port.

571
00:30:35.970 --> 00:30:38.840
All right, so
that the boss could capture that data and

572
00:30:38.840 --> 00:30:41.934
see what webpages I was going
to in the middle of the day.

573
00:30:41.934 --> 00:30:43.145
Yeah, not good.
Almost got fired over that, no,

574
00:30:43.145 --> 00:30:43.688
I'm kidding.

575
00:30:43.688 --> 00:30:48.603
But that's the idea, is in switched
you're gonna have to figure out a way

576
00:30:48.603 --> 00:30:51.550
to be able to get in-between that traffic.

577
00:30:51.550 --> 00:30:55.350
Another solution would be to take a hub,
and get in between your router and

578
00:30:55.350 --> 00:30:57.680
the switch, and put a hub in there, right.

579
00:30:57.680 --> 00:31:01.780
And then plug your monitoring computer
Into that hub, cuz you're basically seeing

580
00:31:01.780 --> 00:31:06.240
all the data before it gets to the switch
or after it leaves the switch.

581
00:31:06.240 --> 00:31:09.770
So you're just getting to a point in
the network where you can see all that

582
00:31:09.770 --> 00:31:10.960
traffic, right?

583
00:31:10.960 --> 00:31:14.220
So something you've gotta think about
when you're running your active captures,

584
00:31:14.220 --> 00:31:15.530
whatever you're trying to do,

585
00:31:15.530 --> 00:31:19.270
you gotta get to where you
can see the actual traffic.

586
00:31:19.270 --> 00:31:23.490
So you've gotta understand how hubs work,
how switches work, how routers work.

587
00:31:23.490 --> 00:31:26.100
Cuz that's gonna determine what
traffic you get to see or not.

588
00:31:26.100 --> 00:31:28.890
>> Mike, that's a lot of great
information, but I know one thing.

589
00:31:28.890 --> 00:31:33.040
You started running the packet capture
utility, but you still haven't showed us.

590
00:31:33.040 --> 00:31:33.676
But-
>> [LAUGH]

591
00:31:33.676 --> 00:31:35.221
>> I have to tell you we're probably

592
00:31:35.221 --> 00:31:36.827
gonna have to go into a part three.

593
00:31:36.827 --> 00:31:39.708
And we're gonna have to leave everybody
just waiting on the edge of their seat if

594
00:31:39.708 --> 00:31:41.353
they've never see what
a packet looks like.

595
00:31:41.353 --> 00:31:43.419
So what do you say we go ahead and
we'll stop it here.

596
00:31:43.419 --> 00:31:47.868
We'll go into a part three maybe, and
then come back and you can kind of show us

597
00:31:47.868 --> 00:31:51.580
the DNA, if you will,
of a packet that you've been capturing.

598
00:31:51.580 --> 00:31:52.820
>> Sounds like a plan to me.

599
00:31:52.820 --> 00:31:55.200
>> All right, well,
that's a perfect place to wrap this up.

600
00:31:55.200 --> 00:31:57.180
Mike, as always,
we appreciate you being here.

601
00:31:57.180 --> 00:31:59.050
We appreciate you, the viewer, watching.

602
00:31:59.050 --> 00:32:01.490
Signing out for ITProTV,
I've been your host, Wes Bryan.

603
00:32:01.490 --> 00:32:02.220
>> And I'm Mike Roderick.

604
00:32:02.220 --> 00:32:03.390
>> And we'll see you next time.

605
00:32:03.390 --> 00:32:10.819
[MUSIC]

606
00:32:10.819 --> 00:32:12.635
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: In this show, Mike and Cherokee begin disusing network perimeter security by describing the functions of different types of firewalls. They also discuss where and how to implement a firewall. Lastly, they explain the role of a proxy.
episodes.title: Network Security
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.103 --> 00:00:01.550
Welcome to ITProTV, I'm your host.

2
00:00:01.550 --> 00:00:06.445
[CROSSTALK].

3
00:00:06.445 --> 00:00:08.273
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:08.273 --> 00:00:12.142

5

GIAC Security Essentials show.

6
00:00:16.210 --> 00:00:18.220
I'm your host, Cherokee Boose.

7
00:00:18.220 --> 00:00:21.300
In this particular episode we'll
be focusing on network security.

8
00:00:21.300 --> 00:00:24.190
And who better than to help us
with this topic, other than Mr.

9
00:00:24.190 --> 00:00:27.280
Mike Rodrick himself, thank you for

10

>> Thanks for having me back.

11

I'm sure there's a few other
people that might be better.

12
00:00:30.932 --> 00:00:31.860
[LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH]

13
00:00:31.860 --> 00:00:32.760
>> That I'd like to learn from,

14
00:00:32.760 --> 00:00:33.850
no, I'm kidding.

15
00:00:33.850 --> 00:00:37.923
Excited to be here, yeah, continuing
on with our GAIC Security Essentials.

16
00:00:37.923 --> 00:00:42.270
And, as Cherokee said, we're gonna be
talking about network security in general.

17
00:00:42.270 --> 00:00:45.834
Really looking at a couple of
different things that when we think

18
00:00:45.834 --> 00:00:48.810
about network security,
what are we talking about?

19
00:00:48.810 --> 00:00:52.370
And usually we're talking about the
different types of appliances that we can

20
00:00:52.370 --> 00:00:56.480
put in place to help keep our networks
secure and just other general methods that

21
00:00:56.480 --> 00:00:59.380
we can do to secure our
network communications, right?

22
00:00:59.380 --> 00:01:03.020
Because when we think about it,
all of our data, our usernames and

23
00:01:03.020 --> 00:01:07.025
passwords, all of that is traveling
back and forth across our network.

24
00:01:07.025 --> 00:01:09.830
And we've gotta keep that
safe from the bad guy,

25
00:01:09.830 --> 00:01:13.730
both external and internal, one of those
things we don't wanna forget about.

26
00:01:13.730 --> 00:01:17.010
So, yeah, in this module, again, just
looking at some of the basic devices we

27
00:01:17.010 --> 00:01:19.890
can use to help keep our network secure.

28
00:01:19.890 --> 00:01:23.234
And that's gotta start with, any
conversation that deals with securing our

29
00:01:23.234 --> 00:01:26.025
networks, almost always has to
start with firewalls, right?

30
00:01:26.025 --> 00:01:30.630
Cuz those are one of the most basic
things we can put in place to

31
00:01:30.630 --> 00:01:32.805
help keep our network safe.

32
00:01:32.805 --> 00:01:36.258
And they've been around for
a long time, but they act really,

33
00:01:36.258 --> 00:01:40.980
our first line of defense in most cases,
as far as keeping our networks secure.

34
00:01:40.980 --> 00:01:44.410
>> Well, if you think about it logically,
that is just the actual design and

35
00:01:44.410 --> 00:01:45.470
the layouts.

36
00:01:45.470 --> 00:01:48.170
That's what people come
in contact with first,

37
00:01:48.170 --> 00:01:50.850
or users trying to
connect to your network.

38
00:01:50.850 --> 00:01:53.790
>> Yeah, exactly, so
we call it our perimeter defense, and

39
00:01:53.790 --> 00:01:57.410
that's not to say that we won't use
firewalls in other places, right?

40
00:01:57.410 --> 00:01:59.340
But one of the most common placements for,
and

41
00:01:59.340 --> 00:02:02.280
if you're going to have one firewall for
your network,

42
00:02:02.280 --> 00:02:05.670
that's where it's most likely gonna go,
is on the border of your network.

43
00:02:05.670 --> 00:02:10.040
But we talk about putting firewalls
in place between trusted and

44
00:02:10.040 --> 00:02:14.980
untrusted networks, which is usually our
corporate network and the Internet, right,

45
00:02:14.980 --> 00:02:17.090
the outside world, everybody else.

46
00:02:17.090 --> 00:02:23.440
But that also, not to take away from using
them internally where I might have more or

47
00:02:23.440 --> 00:02:27.930
less trusted portions of my network,
I can definitely put a firewall there.

48
00:02:27.930 --> 00:02:31.652
So, we're really talking about,
firewalls usually separate trust levels.

49
00:02:31.652 --> 00:02:34.900
All right, when we're talking
about networks which segregate out

50
00:02:34.900 --> 00:02:38.218
based on our trust or
our security requirements.

51
00:02:38.218 --> 00:02:43.480
So you might have a firewall in
between your client network and

52
00:02:43.480 --> 00:02:45.210
some of your more sensitive servers,

53
00:02:45.210 --> 00:02:49.070
which controls that traffic that's allowed
to reach in there and talk to those guys.

54
00:02:49.070 --> 00:02:52.730
And maybe I've got servers that users
don't directly talk to but they've got

55
00:02:52.730 --> 00:02:56.310
an application that is allowed to retrieve
data from these servers back there.

56
00:02:56.310 --> 00:03:00.760
So I can set up a firewall what only
allows traffic from the application and

57
00:03:00.760 --> 00:03:03.950
not from a user just
browsing to say a share or

58
00:03:03.950 --> 00:03:05.860
something like that on those machines.

59
00:03:05.860 --> 00:03:10.600
So don't get to focused and say
firewalls only go on the perimeter, but

60
00:03:10.600 --> 00:03:13.510
that is the most common placement for
them.

61
00:03:13.510 --> 00:03:17.300
We also have network based firewalls and
host based firewalls all right.

62
00:03:17.300 --> 00:03:20.770
Most of our operating systems
now come with firewalls that we

63
00:03:20.770 --> 00:03:23.250
can run on an individual machine.

64
00:03:23.250 --> 00:03:26.430
And the concept is the same but

65
00:03:26.430 --> 00:03:29.410
a network based firewall is kind
of protecting the entire network.

66
00:03:29.410 --> 00:03:34.490
Whereas a host based firewall would
only be protecting that individual host.

67
00:03:34.490 --> 00:03:38.960
Honestly, though, we see the only issue
you run into, right, like running host

68
00:03:38.960 --> 00:03:42.960
based firewalls, is let's say I've gotta
make an exception for an application.

69
00:03:42.960 --> 00:03:45.450
Now I've gotta do it on
that host based firewall or

70
00:03:45.450 --> 00:03:49.000
multiple host based firewalls and
on my network based firewall.

71
00:03:49.000 --> 00:03:53.879
So when you run them on a host, it's
usually one that needs an extra layer of

72
00:03:53.879 --> 00:03:58.930
protection above and beyond maybe what
that network firewall is giving you.

73
00:03:58.930 --> 00:04:02.390
All right, so
firewalls what the heck is a firewall?

74
00:04:02.390 --> 00:04:04.876
It's not a wall of fire
although that would be cool and

75
00:04:04.876 --> 00:04:06.876
it would stop most packets from coming in.

76
00:04:06.876 --> 00:04:11.009
>> It's kind of confusing Mike because if
your boss were to give you a budget and

77
00:04:11.009 --> 00:04:13.981
say okay I need you to design
a portion of our network and

78
00:04:13.981 --> 00:04:17.493
said I want you to pick up some
firewalls and just left it at that.

79
00:04:17.493 --> 00:04:20.385
It's kind of like going to a car lot and
picking out a car, there's so many

80
00:04:20.385 --> 00:04:23.730
different features and you really need
to know what you're looking for, right.

81
00:04:23.730 --> 00:04:27.440
>> It really is, yes, and when we talk
about firewalls, we can talk about first

82
00:04:27.440 --> 00:04:32.210
generation, second generation,
third generation, next generation.

83
00:04:32.210 --> 00:04:36.270
And each one is really just adding
capabilities to what that firewall can do.

84
00:04:36.270 --> 00:04:40.900
So let's talk about,
as far as the objectives go for this exam,

85
00:04:40.900 --> 00:04:45.300
they wanna talk about the different types
of firewalls that we might run into.

86
00:04:45.300 --> 00:04:50.070
And so we should talk about packet
filters, circuit level filters or

87
00:04:50.070 --> 00:04:54.140
circuit level gateways,
stateful inspection, application gateways,

88
00:04:54.140 --> 00:04:58.240
deck generation firewalls, all these
would be different types of firewalls.

89
00:04:58.240 --> 00:05:01.250
And packet filtering, right,
and we'll come back and

90
00:05:01.250 --> 00:05:04.790
we'll talk about a couple of these
concepts like stateful versus packet

91
00:05:04.790 --> 00:05:08.040
filtering and in-depth of what
they are in just a minute.

92
00:05:08.040 --> 00:05:10.030
But let's talk about firewalls in general.

93
00:05:10.030 --> 00:05:12.320
When we say we've got
a packet level firewall,

94
00:05:12.320 --> 00:05:15.050
this is what we would call
a first gen firewall.

95
00:05:15.050 --> 00:05:18.480
This is what firewalls did in the very
beginning, that was all they did.

96
00:05:18.480 --> 00:05:22.430
And it was a lot, don't get me wrong, it
was a very important part of our security.

97
00:05:22.430 --> 00:05:26.630
But basic firewalls filter
traffic based on rules, right.

98
00:05:26.630 --> 00:05:29.210
As those packets are coming
in in that firewall,

99
00:05:29.210 --> 00:05:32.730
that firewall is the entry
way into your network.

100
00:05:32.730 --> 00:05:36.030
And as each one of those packets comes in,
they're inspected.

101
00:05:36.030 --> 00:05:39.990
They're looked at by the firewall, by the
software that's running on that firewall.

102
00:05:39.990 --> 00:05:45.040
And based on a set of rules that
we've configured on that firewall,

103
00:05:45.040 --> 00:05:49.760
they're gonna decide whether to allow or
drop, allow those packets to go through or

104
00:05:49.760 --> 00:05:53.790
drop those packets and
not allow them to come through.

105
00:05:53.790 --> 00:05:58.230
And with a first gen firewall or
what we call a packet filtering firewall,

106
00:05:58.230 --> 00:06:02.800
all we really did was look at the source
and destination IP address and

107
00:06:02.800 --> 00:06:03.740
the port numbers as well.

108
00:06:03.740 --> 00:06:06.810
There's a little bit more, and
we'll talk about that in a minute but

109
00:06:06.810 --> 00:06:09.772
that was really all they were looking at,
it was very basic.

110
00:06:10.830 --> 00:06:15.380
Who's this coming from,
who's it going to, type of information.

111
00:06:15.380 --> 00:06:18.230
Which was good, it still helped, right?

112
00:06:18.230 --> 00:06:22.870
This allowed me to do things like, there's
a known bad network out there that's been,

113
00:06:22.870 --> 00:06:27.940
let's say we've been getting scanned,
and we had some attacks on our network,

114
00:06:27.940 --> 00:06:30.350
and they've come from this
one IP address range.

115
00:06:30.350 --> 00:06:34.600
We can then make a rule on our firewall
that says look drop all packets

116
00:06:34.600 --> 00:06:38.070
from this particular IP address or
this particular IP range.

117
00:06:38.070 --> 00:06:40.120
And those packet filtering
firewalls could do that.

118
00:06:40.120 --> 00:06:43.780
They look at the packet they read
the TCP header they see the source of

119
00:06:43.780 --> 00:06:46.990
IP address and
they say no we're dropping that.

120
00:06:46.990 --> 00:06:50.970
Or looking at private IP addresses
coming from my outside of my network,

121
00:06:50.970 --> 00:06:53.180
where private IP address
shouldn't be coming from.

122
00:06:53.180 --> 00:06:55.162
Internal, non routable, right?

123
00:06:55.162 --> 00:06:58.820
We've talked,
we know about those classes within our IP

124
00:06:58.820 --> 00:07:01.740
address ranges that are private,
non routable addresses.

125
00:07:03.190 --> 00:07:05.970
What the bad guys will do is
that they will try to spoof

126
00:07:05.970 --> 00:07:08.530
an address to get past
your firewall rules.

127
00:07:08.530 --> 00:07:11.640
So, from an outside facing
port on your firewall,

128
00:07:11.640 --> 00:07:16.150
in comes a packet that has a source IP
address of 192.168, something, something.

129
00:07:16.150 --> 00:07:17.890
We know that shouldn't be happening,
right?

130
00:07:17.890 --> 00:07:20.070
That's an example of an attack
that somebody's trying to do.

131
00:07:20.070 --> 00:07:24.166
And a packet filter could catch that,
could stop that from happening.

132
00:07:24.166 --> 00:07:28.054
All right,
you've got circuit level gateways and

133
00:07:28.054 --> 00:07:33.570
circuit level gateways really
monitor the TCP handshake process.

134
00:07:33.570 --> 00:07:35.640
They're going to watch the syn.

135
00:07:35.640 --> 00:07:39.040
We should know at this point
about the TCP three-way handshake

136
00:07:39.040 --> 00:07:42.290
that occurs when you
establish a TCP connection.

137
00:07:42.290 --> 00:07:46.480
You've got your syn packet that goes out
when you request to make the connection.

138
00:07:46.480 --> 00:07:50.274
The other end is supposed to respond with
a syn-ack with acknowledgement of your

139
00:07:50.274 --> 00:07:51.627
synchronization request.

140
00:07:51.627 --> 00:07:54.777
And the synchronization requests
on their own, of their own,

141
00:07:54.777 --> 00:07:57.104
and then a final
acknowledgement going back.

142
00:07:57.104 --> 00:07:59.824
Acknowledging their
synchronisation request and

143
00:07:59.824 --> 00:08:03.790
those three packets are known
as the TCP three way handshake.

144
00:08:03.790 --> 00:08:06.750
And a circuit level
gateway can monitor and

145
00:08:06.750 --> 00:08:11.410
see that established connection and
then keep track of that.

146
00:08:11.410 --> 00:08:15.450
And I say, okay this is a connection that
has been established between host and

147
00:08:15.450 --> 00:08:19.270
host are two different nodes,
and now all subsequent traffic,

148
00:08:19.270 --> 00:08:22.250
I can allow through without having
to do any further inspection,

149
00:08:22.250 --> 00:08:25.200
it's an established TCP connection.

150
00:08:25.200 --> 00:08:26.790
Then you've got stateful inspections.

151
00:08:26.790 --> 00:08:31.570
And this really where we came into
the second generation, all right.

152
00:08:31.570 --> 00:08:36.630
This was the next evolution in our
firewalls that started out as simply

153
00:08:36.630 --> 00:08:40.110
packet filters, and
now we're gonna give them the ability to

154
00:08:40.110 --> 00:08:45.440
look inside the packet, take a look
at the content of the packet itself.

155
00:08:45.440 --> 00:08:48.940
They can also monitor the TCP handshake or
the TCP connection,

156
00:08:50.260 --> 00:08:54.680
which actually, in the end reduces a
little bit of overhead on those firewalls,

157
00:08:54.680 --> 00:08:57.560
because what they do is they look for
the SIM packets.

158
00:08:57.560 --> 00:08:59.950
The packet where the acknowledgement
packet is not raised or

159
00:08:59.950 --> 00:09:03.310
set to zero,
they know that's the initial packet.

160
00:09:03.310 --> 00:09:07.920
They can watch that, see that connection
established, and now any other

161
00:09:07.920 --> 00:09:11.590
packets that come through that are part of
that conversation can be allowed because

162
00:09:11.590 --> 00:09:14.580
they already know it's part of
an established successful connection.

163
00:09:14.580 --> 00:09:16.681
>> By looking at that information,

164
00:09:16.681 --> 00:09:20.966
would they be able to prevent any
kind of hijacking attack session?

165
00:09:20.966 --> 00:09:22.796
>> Yes, a little bit, they can.

166
00:09:22.796 --> 00:09:24.927
When we talk about, well,

00:21:31.490 --> 00:21:34.670
A proxy typically performs many services.

395
00:21:34.670 --> 00:21:37.350
Network address translation
being one of them.

396
00:21:37.350 --> 00:21:39.590
But usually, we see proxies being used,

397
00:21:39.590 --> 00:21:43.960
if we're talking about forward proxies,
normal proxies.

398
00:21:43.960 --> 00:21:46.530
Didn't have to say that until they
came out with reverse proxies and

399
00:21:46.530 --> 00:21:48.640
now we've got to specify, forward proxy.

400
00:21:48.640 --> 00:21:52.527
But a proxy is one that we funnel all
of our internet based traffic through.

401
00:21:52.527 --> 00:21:58.045
Like from our corporate network, any user,
any machine that needs internet access,

402
00:21:58.045 --> 00:22:01.839
we configure the proxy server
in their internet settings.

403
00:22:01.839 --> 00:22:03.985
And instead of sending it
to the default gateway,

404
00:22:03.985 --> 00:22:06.890
basically the proxy server
becomes the default gateway.

405
00:22:06.890 --> 00:22:09.040
For your nodes, your end users.

406
00:22:09.040 --> 00:22:13.360
And when that packet gets there,
the proxy server can do several things.

407
00:22:13.360 --> 00:22:14.690
It can do packet inspection.

408
00:22:14.690 --> 00:22:18.660
It can look inside that packet and see
what web request you're trying to do and

409
00:22:18.660 --> 00:22:21.957
say, no, Facebook is not allowed,
and drop the packet, and

410
00:22:21.957 --> 00:22:23.382
not let you go any further.

411
00:22:23.382 --> 00:22:27.755
So, you see proxies being used to
control what portion of the web my users

412
00:22:27.755 --> 00:22:29.057
are allowed to go to.

413
00:22:29.057 --> 00:22:33.472
It also, as I said, does network
translation I can use private internal IP

414
00:22:33.472 --> 00:22:38.326
addresses, non routable IP addresses
internally, we are talking about IPD4.

415
00:22:38.326 --> 00:22:43.119
And when I send my request to the proxy
server it's gonna remove my non

416
00:22:43.119 --> 00:22:45.200
routable IP address.

417
00:22:45.200 --> 00:22:48.940
Place its publicly routable
IP address in its place,

418
00:22:48.940 --> 00:22:51.220
send the request out to say Google.

419
00:22:51.220 --> 00:22:54.280
Comes back not to me but
to the proxy, because remember,

420
00:22:54.280 --> 00:22:55.780
my address has been removed.

421
00:22:55.780 --> 00:22:56.930
Google knows nothing about me,

422
00:22:56.930 --> 00:23:00.370
it thinks the proxy server
is requesting the web page.

423
00:23:00.370 --> 00:23:03.860
So it sends it back to the proxy,
then the proxy through using a table,

424
00:23:03.860 --> 00:23:06.440
he wrote down my IP address
before he took it off.

425
00:23:06.440 --> 00:23:10.990
And I gave it, basically, a random
port number to remember who was what.

426
00:23:10.990 --> 00:23:13.830
And it says Google, yeah, that was Mike.

427
00:23:13.830 --> 00:23:17.880
Let me take my IP address off and put his
back on there and allow it to go back

428
00:23:17.880 --> 00:23:20.930
through the network and I get Google,
but Google's not aware of me.

429
00:23:20.930 --> 00:23:24.415
It's a way to obfuscate your
internal network design.

430
00:23:24.415 --> 00:23:27.401
My IP addresses, they're non-routable
anyway, they're not gonna go out.

431
00:23:27.401 --> 00:23:30.934
But even if they were public,
they would be translated and so

432
00:23:30.934 --> 00:23:34.380
it would hide my internal
network infrastructure.

433
00:23:34.380 --> 00:23:39.475
Plus, give me the ability, again,
to control where my users are able to go.

434
00:23:39.475 --> 00:23:41.585
I see proxies, well,
just about everywhere now.

435
00:23:41.585 --> 00:23:45.384
But a few years ago, they were mostly
used in schools and governments,

436
00:23:45.384 --> 00:23:47.931
anywhere where they had
to have tight control.

437
00:23:47.931 --> 00:23:52.155
I don't need my students browsing to
certain sites, if you know what I mean.

438
00:23:52.155 --> 00:23:56.739
So we can use that proxy to just stop
those requests before they ever even Leave

439
00:23:56.739 --> 00:23:57.595
our network.

440
00:23:57.595 --> 00:24:00.754
You go out to the VA and do some
training and Facebook's not allowed,

441
00:24:00.754 --> 00:24:02.420
eBay's not allowed.

442
00:24:02.420 --> 00:24:07.658
All those places, those are not supposed
to be monitoring their option at work.

443
00:24:07.658 --> 00:24:10.702
So those sites are blocked and
they're using a proxy to do that.

444
00:24:10.702 --> 00:24:14.160
>> Now, Mike, We don't really have
to have a dedicated device to this.

445
00:24:14.160 --> 00:24:17.720
Some of the firewalls that you spoke of
may even have network address translation

446
00:24:17.720 --> 00:24:19.730
as a feature integrated, built-in.

447
00:24:19.730 --> 00:24:22.108
So don't get confused by that, right?

448
00:24:22.108 --> 00:24:26.059
>> Yeah, and in fact, if you guys,
most everybody out there,

449
00:24:26.059 --> 00:24:30.631
on their home network, probably has
a little D-Link or Linksys, and

450
00:24:30.631 --> 00:24:34.960
you're gonna call it a wireless
access point, right?

451
00:24:34.960 --> 00:24:37.060
But it's really a multi-function device.

452
00:24:37.060 --> 00:24:41.430
When you look at those devices, you look
at the back of it, you got a WAN port and

453
00:24:41.430 --> 00:24:42.870
then four LAN ports.

454
00:24:42.870 --> 00:24:44.301
So there's a one port switch.

455
00:24:44.301 --> 00:24:44.900
There's a one port router.

456
00:24:44.900 --> 00:24:45.618
>> Like a switch, a wireless access point.

457
00:24:45.618 --> 00:24:48.835
>> I'm sorry, yeah, there's a there's
a one port router going on in there.

458
00:24:48.835 --> 00:24:50.724
There's a four port
switch going on in there.

459
00:24:50.724 --> 00:24:52.835
There's a wireless access
point going on there.

460
00:24:52.835 --> 00:24:54.143
That was my signal for antennas.

461
00:24:54.143 --> 00:24:55.025
>> [LAUGH]
>> Sticking up.

462
00:24:55.025 --> 00:24:56.007
Those are little antennas
if you didn't know.

463
00:24:56.007 --> 00:24:57.008
>> Okay.
[LAUGH]

464
00:24:57.008 --> 00:24:57.767
>> And it's doing

465
00:24:57.767 --> 00:25:01.919
network address translation because we're
using private addresses internally,

466
00:25:01.919 --> 00:25:03.905
yet we still have Internet access.

467
00:25:03.905 --> 00:25:08.105
And it's probably doing DHCP
on top of being a firewall and

468
00:25:08.105 --> 00:25:10.200
doing port forwarding and
things like that.

469
00:25:10.200 --> 00:25:12.257
So, Cherokee, you're absolutely right.

470
00:25:12.257 --> 00:25:16.800
An ad is typically not deployed on
its own, it's part of another device.

471
00:25:16.800 --> 00:25:19.200
And nowadays, with these newer firewalls,

472
00:25:19.200 --> 00:25:23.110
it might be that that one device
does everything like our little.

473
00:25:23.110 --> 00:25:23.680
It's kind of funny you think about it,

474
00:25:23.680 --> 00:25:26.890
our home devices have had all of this
rolled up into one for a long time.

475
00:25:27.990 --> 00:25:30.540
But those aren't quite
enterprise level devices.

476
00:25:30.540 --> 00:25:34.550
They can't handle the amount of traffic
that we would see in an enterprise.

477
00:25:34.550 --> 00:25:38.399
But now you look at these next generation
firewalls and they are beefy enough.

478
00:25:38.399 --> 00:25:42.923
They've got the processing power and
the RAM to be able to perform all

479
00:25:42.923 --> 00:25:47.790
of those functionalities and
not degrade our performance too bad.

480
00:25:47.790 --> 00:25:50.640
That is one thing you look at,
when you're doing a firewall set-up or

481
00:25:50.640 --> 00:25:53.170
you're buying a firewall, is performance.

482
00:25:53.170 --> 00:25:57.077
The deeper the inspection I do on the
packets, the more time it's gonna take.

483
00:25:57.077 --> 00:26:01.176
And if you're talking about every
single packet coming into that network,

484
00:26:01.176 --> 00:26:03.490
that's a lot of work, right?

485
00:26:03.490 --> 00:26:08.058
So it can really slow your network down,
if you try to do too much on an older

486
00:26:08.058 --> 00:26:11.318
device, or
the device just wasn't designed to do.

487
00:26:11.318 --> 00:26:15.233
And you look at some of those stateful
inspection firewalls and they

488
00:26:15.233 --> 00:26:19.500
were on the edge of their performance,
and they would slow traffic down.

489
00:26:19.500 --> 00:26:23.613
And so you could step back what it was
doing as far as the packet inspection,

490
00:26:23.613 --> 00:26:25.656
kind of help with your performance.

491
00:26:25.656 --> 00:26:29.905
>> While also talking about performance,
when you're talking about proxies,

492
00:26:29.905 --> 00:26:34.088
something else that's pretty cool as
far as helping increase performance or

493
00:26:34.088 --> 00:26:38.395
decrease latency within your network would
be that if an end user went to go out to

494
00:26:38.395 --> 00:26:42.575
the Internet to grab and pull down a
catalog, maybe they had to order parts for

495
00:26:42.575 --> 00:26:45.960
inventory for
a production company or something.

496
00:26:45.960 --> 00:26:49.520
And maybe I got to work first,
and then Mike got to work second.

497
00:26:49.520 --> 00:26:53.220
But we wouldn't necessarily need Mike to
go all the way out to the Internet because

498
00:26:53.220 --> 00:26:55.310
that proxy could also
cache that information,

499
00:26:55.310 --> 00:26:59.130
thus speeding up that internal
communications, so there's another, yeah.

500
00:26:59.130 --> 00:27:00.416
>> Yeah, that's a big benefit.

501
00:27:00.416 --> 00:27:04.296
Cuz, I mean, most of your users, as you
say, are going to a lot of the same pages,

502
00:27:04.296 --> 00:27:06.880
especially if they're work-related pages.

503
00:27:06.880 --> 00:27:09.950
So by caching those on the proxy,
you never even leave the network.

504
00:27:09.950 --> 00:27:10.750
It's fantastic.

505
00:27:10.750 --> 00:27:13.372
So they can definitely
help with performance.

506
00:27:13.372 --> 00:27:16.100
All right, Cherokee,
I know we've got more to talk about,

507
00:27:16.100 --> 00:27:17.766
but I see you giving me that signal.

508
00:27:17.766 --> 00:27:18.635
>> Uh-huh.
It happens.

509
00:27:18.635 --> 00:27:19.722
>> [LAUGH]
>> Sorry, Mike.

510
00:27:19.722 --> 00:27:21.260
But we are out of time.

511
00:27:21.260 --> 00:27:25.520
But, ladies and gentlemen, stay tuned
we do have more GIAC headed your way.

512
00:27:25.520 --> 00:27:27.110
But for this show we'll go ahead and
sign off.

513
00:27:27.110 --> 00:27:28.376
Remember, I'm Cherokee Boose.

514
00:27:28.376 --> 00:27:28.933
>> And I'm Mike Rodrick.

515
00:27:28.933 --> 00:27:30.439
>> See you next time here at ITProTV.

516
00:27:30.439 --> 00:27:38.181
[MUSIC]

517
00:27:38.181 --> 00:27:40.210
>> Thank you you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: In this show, Cherokee and Mike begin discussing  Virtual Private Networks (VPNs). Mike explains why and how they may be utilized. They also discuss the associated tunneling and encryption protocols. Several other topics such as web application security, active content, attacks, defenses, wireless security and misconceptions.
episodes.title: Network Security Part 2
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:02.033
>> Welcome to ITProTV,
I'm your host Don Pezet.

2
00:00:02.033 --> 00:00:06.262
[CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:06.262 --> 00:00:12.210
>> You're watching ITProTV.

4
00:00:12.210 --> 00:00:15.772
>> Welcome to your
GIAC Security Essentials series.

5
00:00:15.772 --> 00:00:18.025
I'm your show host Cherokee Boose.

6
00:00:18.025 --> 00:00:21.836
This is actually a part two where we will
be continuing looking at different types

7
00:00:21.836 --> 00:00:22.914
of network security.

8
00:00:22.914 --> 00:00:25.504
With us today in studios,
we have Mr. Mike Rodrick.

9
00:00:25.504 --> 00:00:26.762
Thank you for joining us today, Mike.

10
00:00:26.762 --> 00:00:27.566
>> Hey, Cherokee.

11
00:00:27.566 --> 00:00:30.437
Thanks for having me back,
excited to be here.

12
00:00:30.437 --> 00:00:32.391
So in this episode, as Cherokee said,

13
00:00:32.391 --> 00:00:36.245
we're continuing on with our network
security, looking at different types

14
00:00:36.245 --> 00:00:40.478
of devices that we've put in place to keep
our network safe as well as technologies.

15
00:00:40.478 --> 00:00:42.677
And that's kinda where
we're gonna go next.

16
00:00:42.677 --> 00:00:47.109
We wanna talk about VPNs or
virtual private networks.

17
00:00:47.109 --> 00:00:51.518
They call out on our objectives that
we're gonna need to have a high-level

18
00:00:51.518 --> 00:00:54.676
understanding of VPNs or
virtual private networks.

19
00:00:54.676 --> 00:00:56.121
And so, let's do.

20
00:00:56.121 --> 00:00:59.684
Let's talk about them, so
we can have that high-level understanding.

21
00:00:59.684 --> 00:01:03.671
When we talk about a VPN or a virtual
private network, I guess first, we have to

22
00:01:03.671 --> 00:01:07.792
think about why we need them, and then
we'll talk about where we might put them.

23
00:01:07.792 --> 00:01:12.357
And the reason we have these virtual
private networks is because we

24
00:01:12.357 --> 00:01:17.345
are taking advantage of unprotected
public network to transport data.

25
00:01:17.345 --> 00:01:22.759
For example, let's say I work with company
XYZ and I'm allowed to go home and

26
00:01:22.759 --> 00:01:26.945
then connect back to the work network and
do work from home.

27
00:01:26.945 --> 00:01:30.996
The problem is,
I'm connected to the Internet at home.

28
00:01:30.996 --> 00:01:32.860
My work is connected to the Internet.

29
00:01:32.860 --> 00:01:36.740
The Internet's one big fat mesh network,
so it makes sense that I should be able to

30
00:01:36.740 --> 00:01:38.949
connect to my work network form home,
right?

31
00:01:38.949 --> 00:01:40.128
The wiring is there,

32
00:01:40.128 --> 00:01:44.330
the electrical signal can make it from
my house to work no matter where it is.

33
00:01:44.330 --> 00:01:51.907
But the problem is I'm sending that signal
over public networks out of my control.

34
00:01:51.907 --> 00:01:54.546
And there's other people
on those networks and

35
00:01:54.546 --> 00:01:58.783
those people might not be as scrupulous or
as nice as we would like them to be.

36
00:01:58.783 --> 00:02:02.254
And so that means if I'm not protecting
that data that I'm sending across there,

37
00:02:02.254 --> 00:02:04.484
somebody could potentially
see that information.

38
00:02:04.484 --> 00:02:09.786
Capture it and have access to my data.

39
00:02:09.786 --> 00:02:10.996
So we wanna protect it.

40
00:02:10.996 --> 00:02:13.901
We want to encapsulate it.

41
00:02:13.901 --> 00:02:16.160
We basically, when we say,
making a tunnel.

42
00:02:16.160 --> 00:02:18.134
We say, virtual private network.

43
00:02:18.134 --> 00:02:20.677
We're gonna create a private network,
but it's virtual.

44
00:02:20.677 --> 00:02:24.453
We're not actually running
a cable from my house to work.

45
00:02:24.453 --> 00:02:29.146
We're using a protocol that's going
to encapsulate those normal TCP

46
00:02:29.146 --> 00:02:31.780
packets inside a tunneling protocol.

47
00:02:31.780 --> 00:02:34.758
And that's what's giving us the tunnel,
if you will.

48
00:02:34.758 --> 00:02:39.182
So those packets are protected as
they travel across the network,

49
00:02:39.182 --> 00:02:45.320
giving us in a sense a private network
between my house and my corporate network.

50
00:02:45.320 --> 00:02:48.115
That's the idea behind a VPN.

51
00:02:48.115 --> 00:02:50.649
When we look at VPNs,
we can really set them up one of two ways.

52
00:02:50.649 --> 00:02:54.973
The one I was just describing is what
we would call a remote access VPN,

53
00:02:54.973 --> 00:02:59.977
because I'm accessing the internal
corporate network from a remote location.

54
00:02:59.977 --> 00:03:01.272
Be that my house.

55
00:03:01.272 --> 00:03:08.065
Be that Starbucks or the airport, or
wherever I might have internet access.

56
00:03:08.065 --> 00:03:10.879
I can try to establish this
remote access connection.

57
00:03:10.879 --> 00:03:14.970
But they can also be used in what we call
a site-to-site connection, where I have

58
00:03:14.970 --> 00:03:18.885
a corporate office and a branch office,
for example, and people at the branch

59
00:03:18.885 --> 00:03:23.069
office need to make a connection back to
the corporate office to access resources.

60
00:03:23.069 --> 00:03:26.022
That's where most of my file
servers are and that information,

61
00:03:26.022 --> 00:03:28.054
they don't have that at the branch office.

62
00:03:28.054 --> 00:03:32.364
So they're gonna run across the public
network to my corporate office.

63
00:03:32.364 --> 00:03:36.969
Well, I don't want each user having to
establish their own VPN connection back to

64
00:03:36.969 --> 00:03:38.316
the corporate office.

65
00:03:38.316 --> 00:03:40.948
What we can do is we can
establish a permanent or

66
00:03:40.948 --> 00:03:43.385
semi-permanent tunnel between the two.

67
00:03:43.385 --> 00:03:46.479
We'll have VPN endpoints
at the corporate office and

68
00:03:46.479 --> 00:03:50.544
the branch office, and then we
establish a VPN tunnel between those.

69
00:03:50.544 --> 00:03:52.973
And then my users at the branch office,

70
00:03:52.973 --> 00:03:57.021
their traffic goes unprotected
across the branch area network,

71
00:03:57.021 --> 00:04:01.806
to the VPN endpoint, then through
the tunnel between the two VPN endpoints,

72
00:04:01.806 --> 00:04:06.016
and then gets stripped out of,
the encapsulation gets ripped off.

73
00:04:06.016 --> 00:04:08.766
It's a normal TCP packet on
the other end as it travels

74
00:04:08.766 --> 00:04:11.285
across the corporate
network on the other side.

75
00:04:11.285 --> 00:04:15.488
So we have established this tunnel between
two endpoints where the data is protected

76
00:04:15.488 --> 00:04:18.046
as it travels across that
public infrastructure.

77
00:04:18.046 --> 00:04:21.997
>> Now, Mike, this seems like a better
option than something that we'd see in

78
00:04:21.997 --> 00:04:24.851
the past, like an always-on circuit or
a lease line.

79
00:04:24.851 --> 00:04:28.828
Because using those protocols, I can
go ahead and build up that tunnel for

80
00:04:28.828 --> 00:04:32.114
communication and
then tear it down on an as-needed basis.

81
00:04:32.114 --> 00:04:36.647
So I don't have that always on ping by the
what usually mileage and then bandwidth,

82
00:04:36.647 --> 00:04:37.894
it's pretty costly.

83
00:04:37.894 --> 00:04:40.699
But now we see a more efficient,
like a more effective,

84
00:04:40.699 --> 00:04:43.516
more cost-effective mechanism
that we can use today.

85
00:04:43.516 --> 00:04:45.742
>> Yeah, and
the VPN can really be setup, by the way.

86
00:04:45.742 --> 00:04:50.250
It could be a demand dial-type
connection that you're setting up or

87
00:04:50.250 --> 00:04:55.551
it could be as you said, a more permanent
solution between those two endpoints.

88
00:04:55.551 --> 00:04:58.078
Now, let's see where
we're gonna do with this.

89
00:04:58.078 --> 00:05:00.150
So we were talking about
the types of VPNs that we have.

90
00:05:00.150 --> 00:05:02.190
Really again, for this exam,

91
00:05:02.190 --> 00:05:06.748
let's just focus in on remote
access VPNs and site-to-site VPNs.

92
00:05:06.748 --> 00:05:10.766
Now, technologies that we use, they
list a few of them that I wanna go over.

93
00:05:10.766 --> 00:05:13.554
The first one, we're actually
gonna come back to the first one.

94
00:05:13.554 --> 00:05:18.694
The first one is IPsec or Internet
Protocol Security, shortened up to IPsec.

95
00:05:18.694 --> 00:05:23.442
They also talk about L2TP,
which is a Layer 2 Tunneling Protocol.

96
00:05:23.442 --> 00:05:27.485
Talk about PPTP, which is our
Point to Point Tunneling Protocol.

97
00:05:27.485 --> 00:05:31.824
We also have SSH, TLS.

98
00:05:31.824 --> 00:05:35.531
We have,
what's the other one I wanna mention?

99
00:05:35.531 --> 00:05:37.734
I already said,
Point-to-Point Tunneling Protocol.

00:22:05.563 --> 00:22:09.758
the old capital P switch that
we used to use is now N.

415
00:22:09.758 --> 00:22:13.718
But what this is doing is I'm telling
Nmap to take every IP address

416
00:22:13.718 --> 00:22:18.615
on the 10.0.100.0/24 networks,
so 255, 256 addresses,

417
00:22:18.615 --> 00:22:24.330
and it's pinging them, and it's gonna
come back and tell me which ones respond.

418
00:22:24.330 --> 00:22:27.680
Keep in mind it doesn't necessarily
mean a host is up or down, right.

419
00:22:27.680 --> 00:22:31.460
If it's up and not responding to pings,
it might change my results.

420
00:22:31.460 --> 00:22:35.120
There's other things you can do with
an Nmap or TCP connect scans and

421
00:22:35.120 --> 00:22:39.040
things like that, stealth scans,
other types of scans you can do.

422
00:22:39.040 --> 00:22:42.160
Just wanted to show you one
here to kinda get you the idea.

423
00:22:42.160 --> 00:22:44.420
But I can see it came
back with some results.

424
00:22:44.420 --> 00:22:46.320
So what do I have?

425
00:22:47.930 --> 00:22:54.160
There's one, host is up,
and that was this one here.

426
00:22:54.160 --> 00:22:56.601
So ten I got zero or 100.10.

427
00:22:56.601 --> 00:22:58.832
I got 100.200.

428
00:22:58.832 --> 00:23:01.489
I got 100.201.

429
00:23:01.489 --> 00:23:05.193
And I got 100.15 is up.

430
00:23:05.193 --> 00:23:07.387
It take about 30 seconds to scan.

431
00:23:07.387 --> 00:23:12.168
So it's showing me, helping me discover
devices out there on my network.

432
00:23:12.168 --> 00:23:17.440
If I wanna do a port scan with Nmap,
I can take one of those live hosts now and

433
00:23:17.440 --> 00:23:22.530
I can say Nmap, let's just do a It'll

434
00:23:22.530 --> 00:23:26.500
take it a minute but
we'll let it finish while we talk.

435
00:23:27.990 --> 00:23:33.270
So I'm taking the IP address cuz
I saw that it was up, right?

436
00:23:33.270 --> 00:23:38.496
And I'm gonna do a -A, which does
a combination of several different things.

437
00:23:38.496 --> 00:23:43.010
It's gonna do a port scan,
it's also gonna do OS detection,

438
00:23:43.010 --> 00:23:46.390
it's also gonna do versioning on
the different ports that are open.

439
00:23:46.390 --> 00:23:48.730
Trying to figure out not
only is that port open but

440
00:23:48.730 --> 00:23:52.220
what service that is
running behind that port.

441
00:23:52.220 --> 00:23:53.550
So we'll go ahead and we'll let that run.

442
00:23:54.820 --> 00:23:58.830
While we continue to talk I'll make
that a little bit bigger there.

443
00:23:58.830 --> 00:24:01.520
We'll let that go.
That will take it a minute doing that -A

444
00:24:01.520 --> 00:24:02.694
against that host.

445
00:24:02.694 --> 00:24:06.934
Should take it While,
Let's see what else we've got to do.

446
00:24:06.934 --> 00:24:09.990
The last thing I want to talk about while
we're waiting for this scan to finish, and

447
00:24:09.990 --> 00:24:11.150
we talked about NMAP.

448
00:24:11.150 --> 00:24:14.560
Remember, NMAP can do limited
vulnerability scanning.

449
00:24:14.560 --> 00:24:19.650
Really, you're usually talking about
things like Nessus or openvas or

450
00:24:19.650 --> 00:24:25.020
Microsoft Baseline Security Analyzer when
it comes to doing vulnerability scans.

451
00:24:25.020 --> 00:24:28.502
NMAP primarily does your port scans,
like I said,

452
00:24:28.502 --> 00:24:31.370
it is got some pretty cool capabilities
and it being a scripting language,

453
00:24:31.370 --> 00:24:36.080
you can really pretty much do
whatever you want with it.

454
00:24:36.080 --> 00:24:37.180
Penetration testing.

455
00:24:37.180 --> 00:24:41.570
I do want to take a second to
mention penetration testing and

456
00:24:41.570 --> 00:24:45.450
talk about the difference because a lot
of people will try to use the term

457
00:24:45.450 --> 00:24:49.850
vulnerability scanning and
penetration testing interchangeable.

458
00:24:49.850 --> 00:24:52.610
And they're not,
they're not the same thing, all right.

459
00:24:52.610 --> 00:24:57.370
A vulnerability scan is scanning for
a known set of vulnerabilities.

460
00:24:57.370 --> 00:25:01.260
It's got a definition or database
that's storing these definitions and

461
00:25:01.260 --> 00:25:05.410
scanning those and it's telling you yes or
no, if any of those match.

462
00:25:05.410 --> 00:25:07.150
That's it, it's not going any further,

463
00:25:07.150 --> 00:25:11.760
it's not trying to capitalize on
the vulnerability that it found.

464
00:25:11.760 --> 00:25:13.610
>> Use social engineering.

465
00:25:13.610 --> 00:25:17.340
>> Yes, it's not putting anything
together exactly Cherokee, and

466
00:25:17.340 --> 00:25:19.780
that's the thing with penetration testing.

467
00:25:19.780 --> 00:25:23.392
Penetration testing, vulnerability
scanning is a part of penetration testing,

468
00:25:23.392 --> 00:25:26.800
but that's not all penetration
testing is about, right?

469
00:25:26.800 --> 00:25:29.760
Penetration testing is now gonna say, hey,

470
00:25:29.760 --> 00:25:33.180
can I take that vulnerability and
get somewhere with it?

471
00:25:33.180 --> 00:25:36.845
I see that you've got a server facing
the outside that has a vulnerability

472
00:25:36.845 --> 00:25:39.485
now I'm going to see if I can
exploit that vulnerability and

473
00:25:39.485 --> 00:25:42.465
get access to your web server and
how far can I get there.

474
00:25:42.465 --> 00:25:43.425
And, like Cherokee said,

475
00:25:43.425 --> 00:25:46.415
it doesn't bring in the human
element whereas pen testing does.

476
00:25:46.415 --> 00:25:49.581
Vulnerability scanning might find
that you have this vulnerability.

477
00:25:49.581 --> 00:25:54.325
Penetration testing, I'm gonna be
able to say, you know, we've got that

478
00:25:54.325 --> 00:25:59.630
vulnerability and this vulnerability and
combined with a little social engineering,

479
00:25:59.630 --> 00:26:03.340
I might be able to take all three of
these things and perform an attack.

480
00:26:03.340 --> 00:26:06.430
But the vulnerability scan is never
gonna show you that vulnerability,

481
00:26:06.430 --> 00:26:11.600
the one that took the human thinking or
problem-solving to find, all right.

482
00:26:11.600 --> 00:26:15.655
So penetration testing is much more
thorough than vulnerability scanning is

483
00:26:15.655 --> 00:26:17.970
gonna be, very important part
of maintaining our network.

484
00:26:17.970 --> 00:26:22.670
All right, let's take a look at
the results of my NMAP scan,

485
00:26:22.670 --> 00:26:25.370
here's where I ran that command.

486
00:26:25.370 --> 00:26:29.480
And I can see where it's come back, and
it's showing me the different ports that

487
00:26:29.480 --> 00:26:34.020
are opened and it's also showing me
what it thinks is behind those ports.

488
00:26:34.020 --> 00:26:39.080
A lot of times, you can guess by

489
00:26:39.080 --> 00:26:44.190
seeing port 3389, by seeing 53,
by seeing 389, and 636.

490
00:26:44.190 --> 00:26:49.060
I'm like, okay this is probably a Windows
machine running active directory, 389,

491
00:26:49.060 --> 00:26:53.810
636 are my active directory and
secure active directory connections.

492
00:26:53.810 --> 00:26:58.754
DNS on port 53, 389 is my default
remote desktop protocol of Windows,

493
00:26:58.754 --> 00:27:02.322
so I'm pretty sure this is
probably a Windows device.

494
00:27:02.322 --> 00:27:05.360
You know, it's giving me information
about the operating system.

495
00:27:06.990 --> 00:27:09.660
>> So all this is really focusing
on that one particular machine, and

496
00:27:09.660 --> 00:27:11.130
we could call it fingerprinting.

497
00:27:11.130 --> 00:27:15.380
Whereas obtaining network
information would be footprinting.

498
00:27:15.380 --> 00:27:16.790
>> Yep, absolutely.

499
00:27:16.790 --> 00:27:20.350
I can see it's done some
OS guessing down here.

500
00:27:20.350 --> 00:27:23.570
It's funny how down here it says it might
be Windows 10, it might be Windows 7,

501
00:27:23.570 --> 00:27:26.770
it might be Windows 7 Service Pack 1.

502
00:27:26.770 --> 00:27:31.440
Up here it's really sure
that it's 2016 data center,

503
00:27:31.440 --> 00:27:34.670
it's nailed it down to the build number,
right?

504
00:27:34.670 --> 00:27:40.870
So you can get an idea of just doing
the OS guessing versus combining that with

505
00:27:40.870 --> 00:27:45.430
port scanning and then versioning on those
port scans and doing a verbose option.

506
00:27:45.430 --> 00:27:47.340
>> More definitive outcome there?

507
00:27:47.340 --> 00:27:52.270
>> Absolutely, and really this is where it
found a lot of it, was SMB OS discovery.

508
00:27:52.270 --> 00:27:54.710
Now this is actually
the name of the script

509
00:27:54.710 --> 00:27:55.920
that it's running in the background.

510
00:27:55.920 --> 00:28:01.190
It ran two different SMB scripts,
SMB security mode and SMB OS discovery.

511
00:28:01.190 --> 00:28:04.911
And I could run those scripts on their
own, I could do an nmap-script--

512
00:28:04.911 --> 00:28:10.130
smb-os-discovery and just run that script
against the particular IP address.

513
00:28:10.130 --> 00:28:13.370
The capital A happens to
include those scripts.

514
00:28:13.370 --> 00:28:16.030
But you can see, it's pulling
back information about the name,

515
00:28:16.030 --> 00:28:19.180
about the domain I belong to,
the account use.

516
00:28:19.180 --> 00:28:21.860
So it looks like I've got guest access for
SMB enabled.

517
00:28:23.240 --> 00:28:28.250
So that's the idea of doing a port scan,
we already solved the results

518
00:28:28.250 --> 00:28:33.430
from my reports and we got to see
the end results of a vulnerability scan.

519
00:28:33.430 --> 00:28:35.050
So, a couple different tools and

520
00:28:35.050 --> 00:28:37.480
a lot of information there
about vulnerability scanning.

521
00:28:37.480 --> 00:28:39.500
>> Well, thank you for
explaining that to us today, Mike.

522
00:28:39.500 --> 00:28:42.460
And thank you, ladies and gentlemen for
tuning in, but stay tuned,

523
00:28:42.460 --> 00:28:45.160
we do have more GIAC headed your way.

524
00:28:45.160 --> 00:28:47.180
For this show we're gonna go ahead and
sign-off.

525
00:28:47.180 --> 00:28:48.302
Remember, I'm Cherokee Boose.

526
00:28:48.302 --> 00:28:49.558
>> And I'm Mike Rodrick.

527
00:28:49.558 --> 00:28:53.142
>> See you next time here on ITProTV.

528

>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Cherokee and Mike compare and contrast Intrusion Detection and Prevention systems (IDSs and IPSs). They not only share the pros and cons  of each, they also discuss how to logically place them within a network to suite your needs.
episodes.title: IDS and IPS
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.580 --> 00:00:06.461
Welcome to your ITVProTV,
I'm your host [CROSSTALK]

2
00:00:06.461 --> 00:00:08.126
[MUSIC]

3
00:00:08.126 --> 00:00:12.142
>> You're watching ITVProTV.

4
00:00:12.142 --> 00:00:15.720
>> Welcome to your
GIAC Security Essentials series.

5
00:00:15.720 --> 00:00:17.850
I'm your show host, Cherokee Boose.

6
00:00:17.850 --> 00:00:20.380
In this episode we'll be
looking at intrusion detection

7
00:00:20.380 --> 00:00:22.490
in intrusion prevention systems.

8
00:00:22.490 --> 00:00:25.010
With us today we have Mr.
Mike Rodrick in studios.

9
00:00:25.010 --> 00:00:26.310
Than you for joining us today, Mike.

10
00:00:26.310 --> 00:00:27.926
>> Thanks for having me here so formal.

11
00:00:27.926 --> 00:00:28.492
>> [LAUGH]
>> Mr.

12
00:00:28.492 --> 00:00:29.831
Mike Rodrick, I like it.

13
00:00:29.831 --> 00:00:31.700
All right, but thanks for having me back.

14
00:00:31.700 --> 00:00:33.310
Glad to be here, excited as always.

15
00:00:33.310 --> 00:00:36.380
We're doing our GIAC G-Sec certification.

16
00:00:36.380 --> 00:00:39.420
Or I guess that's a little redundant,
since GSEC includes GIAC.

17
00:00:39.420 --> 00:00:41.480
But you guys know why you're here.

18
00:00:41.480 --> 00:00:43.212
And Cherokee is absolutely right.

19
00:00:43.212 --> 00:00:46.763
We're gonna be talking about IDS and
IPS in this particular episode.

20
00:00:46.763 --> 00:00:49.810
And we'll even do a bit
of a demonstration, or

21
00:00:49.810 --> 00:00:52.930
a very simple demonstration
on an IDS system.

22
00:00:52.930 --> 00:00:56.810
So let's define those terms, make sure
we're familiar with what those acronyms

23
00:00:56.810 --> 00:01:01.700
stand for and the difference between them,
cuz I think that is a confusing point for

24
00:01:01.700 --> 00:01:04.270
people that are newer to
this type of technology,

25
00:01:04.270 --> 00:01:08.852
trying to understand what the difference
is between an IDS and an IPS.

26
00:01:08.852 --> 00:01:12.220
And we'l talk about some pros and
cons of the systems.

27
00:01:12.220 --> 00:01:15.260
And also some deployment considerations,

28
00:01:15.260 --> 00:01:18.730
where we wanna think about
putting these in our network.

29
00:01:18.730 --> 00:01:20.990
So let's start by again
defining those terms.

30
00:01:20.990 --> 00:01:23.013
As Cherokee told you
in the very beginning,

31
00:01:23.013 --> 00:01:27.069
we're talking about intrusion detection
systems and intrusion prevention systems.

32
00:01:27.069 --> 00:01:33.040
So IDS, intrusion detection system,
IPS, intrusion prevention system.

33
00:01:33.040 --> 00:01:38.420
Very similar, but there is a subtle, yet
very important difference between the two.

34
00:01:38.420 --> 00:01:41.270
When we talk about
an intrusion detection system,

35
00:01:41.270 --> 00:01:45.060
we're talking about something that we can
place on our network or on a host and

36
00:01:45.060 --> 00:01:48.400
it's going to detect Intrusions, right?

37
00:01:48.400 --> 00:01:52.045
Now if we think about that word,
detect, what do you think Cherokee?

38
00:01:52.045 --> 00:01:54.310
Does that mean anything to you?

39
00:01:54.310 --> 00:01:57.010
>> Sound the alarm, let someone know.

40
00:01:57.010 --> 00:01:57.750
>> Yes, exactly.

41
00:01:57.750 --> 00:01:59.420
>> [LAUGH]
>> It's doing just that.

42
00:01:59.420 --> 00:02:03.210
It's gonna watch for us or with us,
that's probably a better term.

43
00:02:03.210 --> 00:02:08.120
And it's going to give us an alert
in the event that something matches

44
00:02:08.120 --> 00:02:12.280
one of its definitions of what
it should be looking for, right?

45
00:02:12.280 --> 00:02:18.030
If we're looking for at signs of attack,
malware, things like that.

46
00:02:18.030 --> 00:02:20.120
But we wanna think about when
we talk about detect, and

47
00:02:20.120 --> 00:02:22.630
we say that it can alert you.

48
00:02:22.630 --> 00:02:27.100
What I want you to really think about is,
this means it's a passive system.

49
00:02:27.100 --> 00:02:34.050
It will detect or it can detect an attack,
or attack behavior, or malware.

50
00:02:34.050 --> 00:02:35.764
And it can log that information.

51
00:02:35.764 --> 00:02:39.760
That's it, it's a passive system.

52
00:02:39.760 --> 00:02:43.790
It doesn't do anything
to contain the attack or

53
00:02:43.790 --> 00:02:46.690
try to mitigate the attack or
anything like that.

54
00:02:46.690 --> 00:02:49.820
All it's going to do is say hey,
Cherokee, there's an attack.

55
00:02:49.820 --> 00:02:54.330
Your DNS server was scanned ten
times in the last two minutes.

56
00:02:54.330 --> 00:02:55.400
You know?
Or

57
00:02:55.400 --> 00:02:57.950
there was this sort of
behavior occurring here.

58
00:02:57.950 --> 00:02:59.340
It's gonna let you know that it happened.

59
00:02:59.340 --> 00:03:01.900
You're gonna have a record
of what happened.

60
00:03:01.900 --> 00:03:06.730
But it's already happened and this isn't
gonna know a thing to help you stop it.

61
00:03:06.730 --> 00:03:08.580
All right?
That doesn't mean it's not a good thing.

62
00:03:08.580 --> 00:03:10.260
Don't get me wrong, it's very important.

63
00:03:10.260 --> 00:03:15.629
We like our IDS's and we still use them
and sometimes in combination with IPS's.

64
00:03:16.700 --> 00:03:19.370
And I'll talk about why,
and where we might do that.

65
00:03:19.370 --> 00:03:21.950
So they're very useful items.

66
00:03:21.950 --> 00:03:25.840
I don't wanna make it sound like I'm
saying that these aren't any good,

67
00:03:25.840 --> 00:03:26.970
because all they do is detect.

68
00:03:26.970 --> 00:03:29.620
That's a very important part of it.

69
00:03:29.620 --> 00:03:35.052
As a security personnel
working with cyber security,

70
00:03:35.052 --> 00:03:40.020
we have a lot of data to sift through,
log files.

71
00:03:40.020 --> 00:03:44.430
There's a ton of information coming at us
from all different sources, server logs,

72
00:03:44.430 --> 00:03:49.790
client logs, router logs,
firewall logs, network activity logs.

73
00:03:49.790 --> 00:03:51.350
I mean it's just coming from everywhere.

74
00:03:51.350 --> 00:03:55.000
So anything that I can do to help automate
that process using an IDS to help me

75
00:03:55.000 --> 00:03:59.930
monitor those kind of things and alert
me when something goes on is a very good

76
00:03:59.930 --> 00:04:03.400
thing, because there's gonna be a lot of
information that's not an alert, right?

77
00:04:03.400 --> 00:04:06.700
Looking at log files, we know that
the majority of the information in the log

78
00:04:06.700 --> 00:04:10.000
files is gonna be normal activity
that's supposed to be occurring.

79
00:04:10.000 --> 00:04:13.230
And we gotta sift through there and find
the details of when there's something that

80
00:04:13.230 --> 00:04:16.410
was, out of normal or
should not be occurring.

81
00:04:16.410 --> 00:04:19.120
So IDS's are good, but
they are passive system.

82
00:04:19.120 --> 00:04:21.600
So we gotta understand what
their capabilities are.

83
00:04:21.600 --> 00:04:24.080
When we're making our plan,
what we wanna put?

84
00:04:24.080 --> 00:04:25.620
How we're gonna protect our system?

85
00:04:25.620 --> 00:04:29.050
We've got to understand if I put
an IDS in, this is what it's gonna do.

86
00:04:29.050 --> 00:04:31.520
I can't expect anymore out of it.

87
00:04:31.520 --> 00:04:33.790
As I've said it's a passive system.

88
00:04:33.790 --> 00:04:36.120
They can be placed either in line.

89
00:04:36.120 --> 00:04:41.021
Meaning that all traffic can flow through
the IDS, or they can be placed what

90
00:04:41.021 --> 00:04:45.996
they call out of band, or where we have
almost like a, well, you can hook it up

91
00:04:45.996 --> 00:04:50.742
to a switch with a port bearing port so
that all traffic is sent as normal but

92
00:04:50.742 --> 00:04:55.185
also goes out to the IDS system,
to where it's seeing all traffic but

93
00:04:55.185 --> 00:04:59.200
the traffic is not flowing
specifically through the device.

94
00:04:59.200 --> 00:05:01.790
And that's an important
thing to think about.

95
00:05:01.790 --> 00:05:04.860
When we talk about IDS's and IPS's and

96
00:05:04.860 --> 00:05:08.010
we talk about performance,
right, if all of my network.

97
00:05:08.010 --> 00:05:11.760
Let's say I decide to put
this right behind my firewall

98
00:05:11.760 --> 00:05:12.840
at the edge of my network.

99
00:05:12.840 --> 00:05:16.290
That means all traffic that's coming
into my network is going through there.

100
00:05:16.290 --> 00:05:19.660
Now, can that device handle
that amount of bandwidth?

101
00:05:19.660 --> 00:05:21.730
How much traffic do I have coming in?

102
00:05:21.730 --> 00:05:25.010
And it's not doing like a firewall
might be just looking at source and

103
00:05:25.010 --> 00:05:28.450
destination, and deciding whether
it's gonna pass it or drop it.

104
00:05:28.450 --> 00:05:29.020
You know?

105
00:05:29.020 --> 00:05:33.110
It's doing inspections on these packets,
and that's very in sense of process and

106
00:05:33.110 --> 00:05:33.850
it can slow things down.

107
00:05:33.850 --> 00:05:36.700
It can become a bottle neck, so
we do have to be careful with that.

108
