just leave your network.

473
00:25:07.930 --> 00:25:08.991
I mean, if they leave your network,
that could be a good thing.

474
00:25:08.991 --> 00:25:10.262
>> Good to go, yeah.

475
00:25:10.262 --> 00:25:13.631
>> But if you're trying to capture
details so that you can prosecute or

476
00:25:13.631 --> 00:25:16.980
defend your network,
I need them to stick to that honey pot.

477
00:25:16.980 --> 00:25:20.339
I don't want them hitting the honey
pot going ew, this is a honey pot.

478
00:25:20.339 --> 00:25:22.628
I mean, this one's not, let me get this.

479
00:25:22.628 --> 00:25:26.949
But we'll put it,
we might have servers at 10.1, 10.2, 10.3,

480
00:25:26.949 --> 00:25:31.735
my honey pot's 10.4, and then the rest
of them are 10.5, 10.6 and so on.

481
00:25:31.735 --> 00:25:35.410
So you try to mix it in, you don't
make it obvious that it's a honey pot.

482
00:25:35.410 --> 00:25:37.940
You put fake data on there
that looks realistic.

483
00:25:37.940 --> 00:25:42.470
If I'm a healthcare provider,
I don't put financial data on there,

484
00:25:42.470 --> 00:25:44.610
I put healthcare information on there.

485
00:25:44.610 --> 00:25:47.590
Make it look like the real thing,
deter those attacks.

486
00:25:47.590 --> 00:25:49.930
Pull them away from your
production servers.

487
00:25:49.930 --> 00:25:53.440
You get information on their
methodology that you're using.

488
00:25:53.440 --> 00:25:57.250
Like I said, they're configured to be
vulnerable but not too vulnerable.

489
00:25:57.250 --> 00:25:59.640
You can build your own,
there are many out there.

490
00:25:59.640 --> 00:26:04.039
You can go to honey, what is it,
honeynet.org or honey project.

491
00:26:04.039 --> 00:26:08.900
There's several of them out there that
you can download that are pre-built.

492
00:26:08.900 --> 00:26:12.040
You can also do honey networks,
which are entire virtual networks,

493
00:26:12.040 --> 00:26:15.920
not just one machine that
can offer services and

494
00:26:15.920 --> 00:26:18.960
provide services to the other
machines on your honey net.

495
00:26:18.960 --> 00:26:22.740
Cuz that's one thing you'll find in a
honey pot might be offering services, but

496
00:26:22.740 --> 00:26:23.830
nobody's using them.

497
00:26:23.830 --> 00:26:26.010
Because your users, you have to control.

498
00:26:26.010 --> 00:26:29.330
Make sure your users aren't
hitting your honey pot, right?

499
00:26:29.330 --> 00:26:32.230
You don't want that to happen because
then they can become a target off of

500
00:26:32.230 --> 00:26:33.280
the honey pot.

501
00:26:33.280 --> 00:26:37.140
You also have to make sure that
your honey pot cannot get out.

502
00:26:38.850 --> 00:26:40.460
People are gonna attack your honey pot,

503
00:26:40.460 --> 00:26:43.380
they're gonna compromise it because
it's intentionally vulnerable.

504
00:26:43.380 --> 00:26:46.960
You don't want that being a platform
of attack for the rest of your network.

505
00:26:46.960 --> 00:26:49.170
So you have to have really secure rules.

506
00:26:49.170 --> 00:26:50.357
>> Fully segmented?

507
00:26:50.357 --> 00:26:53.180
>> Yes, there needs to be a firewall
between your honey pot and the network.

508
00:26:53.180 --> 00:26:55.410
You need to make sure that
there are rules that say yes,

509
00:26:55.410 --> 00:26:57.100
it can talk to the outside maybe.

510
00:26:57.100 --> 00:26:59.977
But nobody on the intranet,
none of the other servers.

511
00:26:59.977 --> 00:27:02.650
I mean,
you really have to tighten this down.

512
00:27:02.650 --> 00:27:07.890
Another thing you have to worry about is
using it as an attack platform, right?

513
00:27:07.890 --> 00:27:11.550
This is where again some of the legal
questions come into play with honey pots

514
00:27:11.550 --> 00:27:13.390
and honey nets.

515
00:27:13.390 --> 00:27:17.058
I'm setting up this honey pot
to do what we've talked about.

516
00:27:17.058 --> 00:27:22.520
An attacker compromises it, I know he's in
there, but I don't do anything about it.

517
00:27:22.520 --> 00:27:26.260
Because I want to log as much information
as I can, so I can prosecute him later.

518
00:27:26.260 --> 00:27:28.890
Or so I can do research on
his attack methodology.

519
00:27:28.890 --> 00:27:29.530
So I let him go.

520
00:27:30.560 --> 00:27:32.120
And in the meantime,

521
00:27:32.120 --> 00:27:37.390
he uses my honey net platform to launch
an attack against another organization.

522
00:27:37.390 --> 00:27:40.910
Now that organization is facing downtime,
they were under attack.

523
00:27:40.910 --> 00:27:46.168
They're gonna come back to me and say
it's because you facilitated his attack.

524
00:27:46.168 --> 00:27:49.970
You gave him a platform to
launch the attack against us.

525
00:27:49.970 --> 00:27:54.220
And so now there might be some
legal ramifications against me.

526
00:27:54.220 --> 00:27:56.730
So things you gotta think about
when you're setting these up.

527
00:27:56.730 --> 00:27:59.130
Last thing I'll say is honey tokens.

528
00:27:59.130 --> 00:28:04.680
This is a term that really just refers
to the information on a honey pot.

529
00:28:04.680 --> 00:28:08.760
So anything other than the honey pot
itself could be considered a honey token.

530
00:28:08.760 --> 00:28:12.270
We might put usernames and
passwords in there.

531
00:28:12.270 --> 00:28:16.150
Files with usernames and passwords,
email addresses on web pages.

532
00:28:16.150 --> 00:28:18.574
And they're fake,
they're all fake usernames and passwords,

533
00:28:18.574 --> 00:28:19.828
they're fake email addresses.

534
00:28:19.828 --> 00:28:22.139
But when that person steals
those credentials and

535
00:28:22.139 --> 00:28:25.495
then tries to connect to one of my web
servers using those credentials and

536
00:28:25.495 --> 00:28:29.230
those credentials are now logged,
I know where he got them from, right?

537
00:28:29.230 --> 00:28:32.861
So it's a way to track the activity of
this attacker as he goes through your

538
00:28:32.861 --> 00:28:36.720
network by putting these little honey
tokens all over your honey pot.

539
00:28:36.720 --> 00:28:41.160
And then he tries to use those elsewhere,
we can where they're going and

540
00:28:41.160 --> 00:28:41.860
what they're doing.

541
00:28:42.980 --> 00:28:46.860
>> Interesting terminology there,
our little use of the word token there.

542
00:28:46.860 --> 00:28:47.527
A honey, what did you say?

543
00:28:47.527 --> 00:28:50.722
>> Honey token.
>> Honey token, I like it, yeah.

544
00:28:50.722 --> 00:28:52.970
You gotta be key to some of these terms.

545
00:28:52.970 --> 00:28:55.610
Actually, someone here in the chat
they said put it in the DMZ

546
00:28:55.610 --> 00:28:59.135
about our honey pots and
honey nets for our demilitarized zone.

547
00:28:59.135 --> 00:29:04.272
I've also seen the term screen subnet,
so just depending on which vendor or

548
00:29:04.272 --> 00:29:07.170
whom you're talking to, they might
call it something different there.

549
00:29:07.170 --> 00:29:08.714
>> Yep, absolutely, and you're very right,

550
00:29:08.714 --> 00:29:10.965
David I think put that comment out there,
David Beam.

551
00:29:10.965 --> 00:29:13.470
That's a great place, it depends on
what you're trying to capture, right?

552
00:29:13.470 --> 00:29:17.934
If you're trying to capture attacks
that are taking place from the external,

553
00:29:17.934 --> 00:29:21.938
from the untrusted into your network,
you might put it out in the DMZ.

554
00:29:21.938 --> 00:29:23.720
You might have another one internal.

555
00:29:23.720 --> 00:29:27.460
What if somebody does make it through your
firewall and into your internal network?

556
00:29:27.460 --> 00:29:31.270
And now they've scanned your network and
they're prioritizing their targets.

557
00:29:31.270 --> 00:29:34.910
Maybe you want that honey
pot there to attract them,

558
00:29:34.910 --> 00:29:39.290
hopefully set off some IDS before they
make their way to the real servers, right.

559
00:29:39.290 --> 00:29:42.190
So you might have more than one running.

560
00:29:42.190 --> 00:29:45.480
Just understand that you don't
take a honey pot, set it up and

561
00:29:45.480 --> 00:29:46.670
forget about it, right.

562
00:29:46.670 --> 00:29:48.330
Thinking there we go, that's my trap,

563
00:29:48.330 --> 00:29:52.520
all the bad guys will stick to it
like flypaper and we're good to go.

564
00:29:52.520 --> 00:29:55.054
You have to monitor it continuously.

565
00:29:55.054 --> 00:29:59.374
Otherwise, it just becomes an attack
platform that they can launch attacks from

566
00:29:59.374 --> 00:30:02.920
on the rest of your network or
other organizations.

567
00:30:02.920 --> 00:30:05.705
>> Well, I think you've done a really
great job in the past couple of episodes.

568
00:30:05.705 --> 00:30:08.665
We started with the perimeter, and
we're even still talking about it.

569
00:30:08.665 --> 00:30:12.545
But you've also explained the different
deployment styles depending on placement

570
00:30:12.545 --> 00:30:15.575
and different areas that we
might wanna conceal or protect.

571
00:30:15.575 --> 00:30:18.765
So thank you for that and thank you
ladies and gentlemen for tuning in.

572
00:30:18.765 --> 00:30:21.655
But stay tuned,
we do have more information to cover.

573
00:30:21.655 --> 00:30:23.545
So we're gonna go ahead and
sign out for this show.

574
00:30:23.545 --> 00:30:24.865
Remember I'm Cherokee Boose.

575
00:30:24.865 --> 00:30:25.675
>> And I'm Mike Rodrick.

576
00:30:25.675 --> 00:30:28.964
>> See you next time here at ITProTV.

577
00:30:28.964 --> 00:30:34.852
[MUSIC]

578
00:30:34.852 --> 00:30:36.880
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: Cherokee and Mike begin this discussion by explaining authentication and password management. They explain the difference between the AAAs (authentication, authorization, and accountability. They also discuss the CIA (confidentiality, integrity, and availability) as well as a couple of access control methods.
episodes.title: Access Control
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.280 --> 00:00:01.180
Welcome to ITProTV.

2
00:00:01.180 --> 00:00:06.089
I'm your host, Don Pezet, coming at you
live from San Francisco [CROSSTALK].

3
00:00:06.089 --> 00:00:11.978
>> [SOUND] You're watching ITProTV.

4
00:00:11.978 --> 00:00:14.830
>> Welcome to your
GIAC Security Essentials Series.

5
00:00:14.830 --> 00:00:18.040
I'm your show host, Cherokee Boost.

6
00:00:18.040 --> 00:00:20.820
In this episode we'll be
looking at access controls.

7
00:00:20.820 --> 00:00:22.290
While the concept seems simple,

8
00:00:22.290 --> 00:00:25.780
there are really several different
ways we can implement access controls.

9
00:00:25.780 --> 00:00:29.550
So with us today we have Mr. Mike Rodrick
in studio to explain those techniques.

10
00:00:29.550 --> 00:00:30.970
Thank you for joining us today, Mike.

11
00:00:30.970 --> 00:00:32.250
>> You're welcome,
thanks for having me back.

12
00:00:32.250 --> 00:00:34.070
Excited as always.

13
00:00:34.070 --> 00:00:35.400
All right, so access control.

14
00:00:35.400 --> 00:00:38.730
We're gonna talk about a little bit
of theory here, and eventually we'll

15
00:00:38.730 --> 00:00:42.430
come up with a couple demos and
maybe the next part two on this guy.

16
00:00:42.430 --> 00:00:45.230
But we do need to start off with
that foundational knowledge.

17
00:00:45.230 --> 00:00:47.610
What they're gonna test us on the exam.

18
00:00:47.610 --> 00:00:50.170
So when we talk about
access control theory,

19
00:00:50.170 --> 00:00:53.180
there is a few different terms that
would need to be familiar with and

20
00:00:53.180 --> 00:00:56.968
understand, some concepts
that are very important.

21
00:00:56.968 --> 00:01:02.930
So, access control kind of defines itself
if you just reverse the words, right?

22
00:01:02.930 --> 00:01:05.030
We're gonna control access.

23
00:01:05.030 --> 00:01:07.930
Who is allowed to access what?

24
00:01:07.930 --> 00:01:11.200
Without access control, we basically say,
hey, anybody can access anything,

25
00:01:11.200 --> 00:01:11.728
it's all good.

26
00:01:11.728 --> 00:01:13.410
>> Free range!
>> Yeah, you wanna come and

27
00:01:13.410 --> 00:01:15.310
see Mike's health records.

28
00:01:15.310 --> 00:01:17.040
There you go, there they are, right?

29
00:01:17.040 --> 00:01:18.550
Bank statements, whatever.

30
00:01:18.550 --> 00:01:20.177
>> Obviously we don't-
>> Very underwhelming

31
00:01:20.177 --> 00:01:22.260
if you're trying to look
at my info [LAUGH].

32
00:01:22.260 --> 00:01:24.220
>> I was gonna say mine, too.

33
00:01:24.220 --> 00:01:26.180
Look he's got $200 in his bank account.

34
00:01:26.180 --> 00:01:28.150
Woo woo.
>> [LAUGH] Moving on

35
00:01:28.150 --> 00:01:29.150
>> Yeah, so

36
00:01:29.150 --> 00:01:33.030
when we talk about access control,
obviously we are trying to control access.

37
00:01:33.030 --> 00:01:35.790
And it's a very important
part of what we do.

38
00:01:35.790 --> 00:01:41.260
I mean, in IT, access control is one of
our bigger jobs that we have to play.

39
00:01:41.260 --> 00:01:44.740
And when it comes to IT security,

40
00:01:44.740 --> 00:01:48.810
it's still a big part of what we do and
in making sure that it's enforced,

41
00:01:48.810 --> 00:01:51.710
deciding how we're going
to go about enforcing that.

42
00:01:51.710 --> 00:01:53.116
What policies do we have in place?

43
00:01:53.116 --> 00:01:57.140
What technologies are we using
to do the access control?

44
00:01:57.140 --> 00:02:01.500
We might not be the ones that decide on
some of higher level policy stuff, but

45
00:02:01.500 --> 00:02:02.990
we have to implement it, right?

46
00:02:02.990 --> 00:02:07.390
They come up with the policies, we're
the ones that enforce those policies.

47
00:02:08.830 --> 00:02:11.060
So let's start with data classification.

48
00:02:11.060 --> 00:02:13.940
And data classification is
something that more and

49
00:02:13.940 --> 00:02:16.020
more organizations are starting to do.

50
00:02:16.020 --> 00:02:21.150
And it's a very good reason for that,
because all of our resources that we have,

51
00:02:21.150 --> 00:02:25.300
not all of them need the same
level of protection, right?

52
00:02:25.300 --> 00:02:29.130
And we can't apply the same level
of protection to everything.

53
00:02:29.130 --> 00:02:30.730
It's too resource intensive.

54
00:02:30.730 --> 00:02:32.650
It's too costly.

55
00:02:32.650 --> 00:02:36.410
So we want to make sure we're
prioritizing and picking and

56
00:02:36.410 --> 00:02:39.870
choosing where we're
implementing these solutions.

57
00:02:39.870 --> 00:02:43.240
Cuz some things are meant for
public consumption, right?

58
00:02:43.240 --> 00:02:44.090
So we don't encrypt them.

59
00:02:44.090 --> 00:02:45.290
We don't put them behind firewalls.

60
00:02:45.290 --> 00:02:48.340
We don't password protect them,
or whatever the case may be.

61
00:02:48.340 --> 00:02:50.690
Other things are, and we have to.

62
00:02:50.690 --> 00:02:55.870
But without data classification, I don't
know what needs what level of protection,

63
00:02:55.870 --> 00:02:59.720
or it's a little bit of a guessing game,
or a hit or miss type thing.

64
00:02:59.720 --> 00:03:01.310
Whereas with property of classification,

65
00:03:01.310 --> 00:03:05.300
it's obvious what level of
protection a certain resource needs.

66
00:03:05.300 --> 00:03:07.939
Because it's basically stamped on there,
if you will, all right?

67
00:03:07.939 --> 00:03:12.610
So data classification's important to
ensure that data is protected properly.

68
00:03:12.610 --> 00:03:15.300
Because we understand what level it is,

69
00:03:15.300 --> 00:03:17.545
and therefore what level
of protection it needs.

70
00:03:17.545 --> 00:03:21.210
And it can also help us
with legal requirements

71
00:03:21.210 --> 00:03:26.770
because our data classifications can
include retention periods, encryption

72
00:03:26.770 --> 00:03:32.000
requirements, logging,
access, things like that.

73
00:03:32.000 --> 00:03:35.000
And just about every
regulation that you go and

74
00:03:35.000 --> 00:03:39.860
look at is going to include clauses
to cover this kind of thing,

75
00:03:39.860 --> 00:03:44.360
from HIPAA, to FISMA,
to SOX, Sarbanes-Oxley.

76
00:03:44.360 --> 00:03:45.260
You name it,

77
00:03:45.260 --> 00:03:49.395
there's going to be information in there
about how long you need to keep stuff.

78
00:03:49.395 --> 00:03:50.705
If it needs to be encrypted.

79
00:03:50.705 --> 00:03:54.615
If you need to log every bit of access
that goes to it, that kind of thing.

80
00:03:54.615 --> 00:03:57.425
So, classification can help with that.

81
00:03:57.425 --> 00:04:01.435
When it comes to doing
the actual classification,

82
00:04:01.435 --> 00:04:05.245
now we have different levels that
we're gonna create basically.

83
00:04:05.245 --> 00:04:09.645
There are some out there that
are kinda commonly used.

84
00:04:09.645 --> 00:04:13.750
We know in the military, for
example, we have like Top Secret and

85
00:04:13.750 --> 00:04:17.600
Secret, or Confidential and
Classified information.

86
00:04:17.600 --> 00:04:22.350
And a lot of corporations,
and some that, for example,

87
00:04:22.350 --> 00:04:27.460
that Sans will recommend, or NIST will
recommend for public organizations,

88
00:04:27.460 --> 00:04:30.950
public, internal,
confidential, restricted.

89
00:04:32.750 --> 00:04:37.700
Public would mean information
available to the general public.

90
00:04:37.700 --> 00:04:40.590
This might be my product catalog, right?

91
00:04:40.590 --> 00:04:44.350
Descriptions of those products
that we're trying to sell,

92
00:04:44.350 --> 00:04:46.850
or company background information.

93
00:04:46.850 --> 00:04:50.900
That kind of thing is publicly
available information.

94
00:04:50.900 --> 00:04:54.430
So it would be on our lowest
level of protection requirements.

95
00:04:54.430 --> 00:04:58.420
And then we would have Internal
to designate stuff that

96
00:04:58.420 --> 00:05:00.690
wasn't available to the public.

97
00:05:00.690 --> 00:05:05.600
Internal would mean available to
the general employees of the organization.

98
00:05:05.600 --> 00:05:09.160
Anybody in the organization can
look at our acceptable use policy.

99
00:05:09.160 --> 00:05:09.950
They need to.
In fact,

100
00:05:09.950 --> 00:05:13.910
they should have read it and signed it and
it should be in their employee jacket.

101
00:05:13.910 --> 00:05:15.810
So that would be considered Internal.

102
00:05:15.810 --> 00:05:18.030
It's not meant for public consumption, but

103
00:05:18.030 --> 00:05:22.470
within my organizationn anybody in the
organization can access that information.

104
00:05:22.470 --> 00:05:26.600
Confidential would mean
available internally,

105
00:05:26.600 --> 00:05:30.720
but only to certain groups
within the organization like,

106
00:05:31.790 --> 00:05:36.440
I don't know, prices for
products or wholesale costs for

107
00:05:36.440 --> 00:05:40.990
products that we're selling,
might be limited to sales personnel.

108
00:05:40.990 --> 00:05:45.770
Or certain security documentation
might be limited to IT management or

109
00:05:45.770 --> 00:05:47.850
the C-level employees or
something like that.

110
00:05:47.850 --> 00:05:51.840
So, still available internally,
not public.

111
00:05:51.840 --> 00:05:54.378
But now we're talking about
a subset of employees.

112
00:05:54.378 --> 00:05:58.470
And so that'd be Confidential.

113
00:05:58.470 --> 00:06:03.260
And then Restricted would be my highest
level where now it's internally, but

114
00:06:03.260 --> 00:06:05.890
only named individuals, all right?

115
00:06:05.890 --> 00:06:10.840
Pay rates might only be
available to HR supervisor and

116
00:06:10.840 --> 00:06:13.130
the CEO and CIO or whomever.

117
00:06:13.130 --> 00:06:16.580
But now we're not talking groups
of people, but named individuals.

118
00:06:16.580 --> 00:06:18.700
This is the highest level.

119
00:06:18.700 --> 00:06:23.940
Here we're talking about corporate
secrets, intellectual property,

120
00:06:23.940 --> 00:06:28.545
that research project is only
available to the researcher and

121
00:06:28.545 --> 00:06:33.235
his assistant and the CEO and

535
00:27:19.770 --> 00:27:25.330
Well written policies are gonna include,
purpose, what is this policy for?

536
00:27:25.330 --> 00:27:28.390
Scope, who does this policy apply to?

537
00:27:28.390 --> 00:27:31.008

who's responsible for

538

539

Sanctions and violation what's gonna
happen if you violate the policy,

540
00:27:39.270 --> 00:27:40.200
how we gonna determine?

541
00:27:40.200 --> 00:27:43.069
If there's has been violation,
revisions and

542
00:27:43.069 --> 00:27:46.550
updating who's going to be responsible for
that.

543
00:27:46.550 --> 00:27:50.670
Content information if I have questions,
glossary, acronyms.

544
00:27:50.670 --> 00:27:55.330
All those should be in
your well-written policy.

545
00:27:55.330 --> 00:27:58.380
The last thing they
mention in this objective

546

547

And it really boils down

548
00:28:05.456 --> 00:28:05.993
Right.

549
00:28:05.993 --> 00:28:06.942
It ensures,

550
00:28:06.942 --> 00:28:12.810
remember when we talked about insurance
we're trying to make sure that we have,

551
00:28:12.810 --> 00:28:18.073
what's a good way to define insurance
I don't want to say a back up plan,

552
00:28:18.073 --> 00:28:24.240
but it gives me the ability to ensure that
I am compliant with say legal regulations.

553
00:28:24.240 --> 00:28:29.014
Right or let's say I have to follow

554
00:28:29.014 --> 00:28:30.860
something like that.

555
00:28:30.860 --> 00:28:36.040
Well my policies are gonna help me

556
00:28:36.040 --> 00:28:40.690
That I'm not just hoping I've read

I think we're implementing it.

558
00:28:43.030 --> 00:28:43.850
Hopefully.
>> [LAUGH]

559
00:28:43.850 --> 00:28:46.880
>> Or I have a policy that spells out how

we are compliant.

When auditors come in,

they know that we are doing what we can

563
00:28:54.370 --> 00:28:58.820
So, really does help us prove compliance,

564

And make sure that we're We're doing

we use when we're doing risk management,

probably risk assessment.

24

Keep in mind, this is a high

25
00:01:04.259 --> 00:01:07.268
So, again, the first thing I
want to talk about is some risk

26
00:01:07.268 --> 00:01:11.865
assessment methodologies, and there's

27
00:01:11.865 --> 00:01:15.785
We can do what we call

28
00:01:15.785 --> 00:01:18.805

29

31
00:01:24.925 --> 00:01:25.449
That's the big thing.

32

33

34

35

It's more of like a high,
medium, low, if you will.

36
00:01:40.630 --> 00:01:43.470
So it is a little bit

37
00:01:43.470 --> 00:01:45.660

38
00:01:45.660 --> 00:01:49.650
Why would we ever do qualitative if

40

Well, because,
qualitative is a lot more difficult to do.

41
00:01:57.710 --> 00:01:58.960
I'm sorry, quantitative is--I

get these two
>> Yeah

47
00:02:08.502 --> 00:02:10.710

48
00:02:11.900 --> 00:02:14.420
You have to know what
numbers to be plugging in.

49
00:02:14.420 --> 00:02:17.570
That means you've got to do your

50
00:02:17.570 --> 00:02:18.750
Now, granted,

51
00:02:18.750 --> 00:02:22.070
it gets easier over time because you've
already got some of the numbers.

52
00:02:22.070 --> 00:02:25.110
But especially the first one,
It'll be rough going.

53
00:02:25.110 --> 00:02:27.120
It'll take a lot of man hours to do.

54
00:02:27.120 --> 00:02:31.650
Whereas, qualitative,
being subjective I can brainstorm.

55
00:02:31.650 --> 00:02:32.760
We can get everybody together.

56
00:02:32.760 --> 00:02:36.120
We can just sit down and agree upon
something, and that's what it is.

57
00:02:36.120 --> 00:02:37.320
So it's a lot easier to do.

58
00:02:37.320 --> 00:02:38.280
Little bit simpler,

59
00:02:39.580 --> 00:02:44.450
especially if you have non-technical
staff doing the risk assessment.

60
00:02:44.450 --> 00:02:49.990
It's a lot easier for them, whereas
the quantitative it's a numeric value,

61
00:02:49.990 --> 00:02:53.650
so it can be more useful
based on known metrics.

62
00:02:53.650 --> 00:02:58.825
And our results are typically expressed
as monetary or percentages, all right?

63
00:02:58.825 --> 00:03:03.700
But there are, like I said,
the cons, large amount of work.

64
00:03:03.700 --> 00:03:07.050
Doing the quantitative,
a lot of research involved,

65
00:03:07.050 --> 00:03:11.700
a lot of time spent doing this, all right?

66
00:03:11.700 --> 00:03:15.930
So let's take a look at just
some very simple examples here

67
00:03:15.930 --> 00:03:18.140

68
00:03:18.140 --> 00:03:21.830
And I've got a little risk matrix
we can take a peek at as well.

69
00:03:21.830 --> 00:03:24.670
And we'll start off with qualitative.

70
00:03:24.670 --> 00:03:27.459
You know this one,
I think I got this one off NIST as

71
00:03:27.459 --> 00:03:30.260
an example of a little
chart that they were using.

72
00:03:30.260 --> 00:03:33.660
But this would be an example of
doing a qualitative assessment.

73
00:03:33.660 --> 00:03:36.330
Now you first have to
think about your assets.

74
00:03:36.330 --> 00:03:39.670
What assets do I need to
do my risk assessment on?

75
00:03:39.670 --> 00:03:42.820
So they've got like credit card
information that we're storing,

76
00:03:42.820 --> 00:03:46.310
network documentation, marketing
documents versus employee records.

77
00:03:47.510 --> 00:03:55.160

that those particular assets would face.

78
00:03:55.160 --> 00:03:57.410
Loss of confidentiality, right?

79
00:03:57.410 --> 00:04:00.070
So, that information
getting released to people

80
00:04:00.070 --> 00:04:02.760
that were not authorized
to see that information.

81
00:04:02.760 --> 00:04:06.670
Loss of integrity, the data has been
changed and it shouldn't have been or

82
00:04:06.670 --> 00:04:08.190
shouldn't have been allowed to.

83
00:04:08.190 --> 00:04:12.410
Loss of availability,
hard drive failures, data deletion,

84
00:04:12.410 --> 00:04:14.930
corruption, things like that.

85
00:04:14.930 --> 00:04:19.000
All of these assets would face
those types of vulnerabilities.

86
00:04:19.000 --> 00:04:20.240
And so
what we've done is we just said okay,

87
00:04:20.240 --> 00:04:24.069
well, I've got my credit card information,
if we lose confidentiality on that

88
00:04:25.140 --> 00:04:28.950
is that gonna be a low impact,
a medium or a high impact?

89
00:04:28.950 --> 00:04:30.660
It's gonna be high, right?

90
00:04:30.660 --> 00:04:33.077
And again,
this is not a set in stone thing.

91
00:04:33.077 --> 00:04:37.328
This is something that your organization
is going to determine but for

92
00:04:37.328 --> 00:04:41.680
an example, let's pretend that's high,
because we've got PCI.

93
00:04:41.680 --> 00:04:46.300
We've got regulations that I'm going to
get fined if this information is released

94
00:04:46.300 --> 00:04:47.750
to unauthorized people.

95
00:04:47.750 --> 00:04:50.440
I've got customers that are gonna
be really upset with me

96
00:04:50.440 --> 00:04:53.370

card information has been released.

97
00:04:53.370 --> 00:04:56.150
They're not gonna want
to shop with me anymore.

98
00:04:56.150 --> 00:04:57.330
The news is going to cover it.

99
00:04:57.330 --> 00:04:59.390
I'm going to lose face in public.

100
00:04:59.390 --> 00:05:05.040
I'm gonna lose business, so
the impact of this would be high.

101
00:05:05.040 --> 00:05:08.580
Whereas my marketing documents,
all right, well it's marketing.

102
00:05:08.580 --> 00:05:11.578
This is stuff that we put out
to the public eventually,

103
00:05:11.578 --> 00:05:12.870
as soon as we get it right.

104
00:05:12.870 --> 00:05:18.490
If this stuff was to lose confidentiality
the impact would not be that high.

105
00:05:18.490 --> 00:05:19.790
It's marketing material,

106
00:05:19.790 --> 00:05:22.950
eventually we want everybody to
see this information, most likely.

107
00:05:22.950 --> 00:05:24.980
I mean it depends,
is it in-house, whatever?

108
00:05:24.980 --> 00:05:27.190
But I think you get the idea, right?

109
00:05:27.190 --> 00:05:33.960
The idea behind qualitative is that we're
just going to kind of assign these values.

110
00:05:33.960 --> 00:05:37.260
Try to determine is it high,
medium or low, and you can come

111
00:05:37.260 --> 00:05:42.310
up with your own scale, three, five steps,
whatever you want in your scale.

112
00:05:42.310 --> 00:05:48.292
And the reason we do this in our risk
assessment is so that I can start,

113
00:05:48.292 --> 00:05:53.520
what's the word I'm looking for

114
00:05:53.520 --> 00:05:56.340
here, I can start prioritizing, right?

115
00:05:56.340 --> 00:06:02.440
Where do I need to put my efforts,
spend my money in mitigating these risks?

116
00:06:02.440 --> 00:06:05.150
Do I wanna start with
the marketing documents?

117
00:06:05.150 --> 00:06:09.060
No, it's got a low impact across all
three of those vulnerabilities there.

118
00:06:09.060 --> 00:06:10.850
So that's probably not
where I'm gonna start.

119
00:06:10.850 --> 00:06:14.010
I want to get to it eventually,
but not where I'm gonna start.

120
00:06:14.010 --> 00:06:16.530
I can see that credit card information and

121
00:06:16.530 --> 00:06:21.780
employee records both have a high
impact if I lose confidentiality.

122
00:06:21.780 --> 00:06:25.640
So those are where I want to start,
maybe those are the ones I want to look at

123
00:06:25.640 --> 00:06:29.380
how we can put in controls to make
sure we maintain that confidentiality.

124
00:06:29.380 --> 00:06:32.650
That's where I'm gonna spend my money and
my man hours, right?

125
00:06:32.650 --> 00:06:35.070
So that's what we're trying to
do here with a qualitative.

126
00:06:36.610 --> 00:06:39.132
You've probably seen risk matrix before.

127
00:06:39.132 --> 00:06:42.410
Here we've just taken severity categories,
and

128
00:06:42.410 --> 00:06:46.400
you can do it with a description,
you can do it with a number.

129
00:06:46.400 --> 00:06:49.830
Either way it would work,
whatever works for you.

130
00:06:49.830 --> 00:06:52.460
But severity they've got
like catastrophic, critical,

131
00:06:52.460 --> 00:06:56.250
marginal, negligible, and
a severity of one, two, three, four.

132
00:06:57.790 --> 00:07:00.410
Again this is from NIST,
I think I would have gone the other way.

133
00:07:00.410 --> 00:07:01.788
Catastrophic should be four in my opinion.

134
00:07:01.788 --> 00:07:04.551
>> [LAUGH]
>> But you know.

135
00:07:04.551 --> 00:07:06.176
Probability levels.

136
00:07:06.176 --> 00:07:14.310
What is the likelihood of occurrence, is
what the probability level is giving me.

137
00:07:14.310 --> 00:07:17.880
And I could use A, B, C, D, E, or
Frequent, Probable, Occasional,

138
00:07:17.880 --> 00:07:19.720
Remote, Improbable.

139
00:07:19.720 --> 00:07:22.140
And then we make a matrix out of this,
right?

140
00:07:22.140 --> 00:07:25.920
And so I can see we might have something,
and we're gonna list that.

141
00:07:25.920 --> 00:07:31.080
What I don't show you here is listing

142
00:07:31.080 --> 00:07:35.868
And we've done our business
impact analysis to determine

143
00:07:35.868 --> 00:07:40.753
that if this vulnerability was
discovered and acted upon,

144
00:07:40.753 --> 00:07:44.184
the outcome would be critical all right?

145
00:07:44.184 --> 00:07:47.538
It's not catastrophic, but
it's definitely not marginal.

146
00:07:47.538 --> 00:07:51.931
It'd be critical, and the probability
of somebody taking advantage

147
00:07:51.931 --> 00:07:55.588
of that vulnerability maybe
we find is probable, right?

148
00:07:55.588 --> 00:07:57.745
A B there on our scale.

149
00:07:57.745 --> 00:08:00.455
So then we'll say all
right well it's critical.

150
00:08:00.455 --> 00:08:04.340
And it's probable, so
where do those two intersect?

151
00:08:04.340 --> 00:08:06.286
Right there in high, right?

152
00:08:06.286 --> 00:08:09.511
So in my risk matrix,
I've determined that that

153
00:08:09.511 --> 00:08:13.849
particular vulnerability should
be on my top of the things to do.

154
00:08:13.849 --> 00:08:18.135
Again, that's what we're trying
to do is prioritize our risks so

155
00:08:18.135 --> 00:08:20.190
that we can go through them.

156
00:08:20.190 --> 00:08:22.380
You never gonna eliminate all risk.

157
00:08:22.380 --> 00:08:25.870
But I can find the ones that
are gonna have the biggest impact and

158
00:08:25.870 --> 00:08:27.740
I can focus on those first.

159
00:08:27.740 --> 00:08:30.902
That's really what risk
assessment is all about.

160
00:08:30.902 --> 00:08:33.144
Then we can go the quantitative route.

161
00:08:33.144 --> 00:08:37.284
And when we look at the quantitative,
again this is where we're gonna

162
00:08:37.284 --> 00:08:41.224
assign numbers, percentages,
monetary values to these risks.

163
00:08:41.224 --> 00:08:44.799
So same kind of process, we're gonna
look at an asset and we're gonna

164
00:08:44.799 --> 00:08:49.121
talk about all the different risks that
are associated with that particular asset.

165
00:08:49.121 --> 00:08:52.386
And again,
this is a very simple abbreviated chart.

166
00:08:52.386 --> 00:08:57.307
A single asset could have several
different risks listed for it,

167
00:08:57.307 --> 00:09:01.525
and I would do a business
impact analysis on that asset.

168
00:09:01.525 --> 00:09:06.166
and I would do my risk analysis on each
one of those vulnerabilities that that

169
00:09:06.166 --> 00:09:06.971
risk faced.

170
00:09:06.971 --> 00:09:11.485
But once we had our asset that we
needed to protect, we've got our risk,

171
00:09:11.485 --> 00:09:13.864
loss of data, no backup, all right?

172
00:09:13.864 --> 00:09:17.611
So determine the asset value for
each information asset.

173

So we've determined that my customer
database is worth $118,000.

174
00:09:22.262 --> 00:09:24.822
Now where did I come up with that number,
right?

175
00:09:24.822 --> 00:09:28.050
This is where the work comes in.

176
00:09:28.050 --> 00:09:29.410
What is it actually worth?

177
00:09:29.410 --> 00:09:32.390
This is where our business
impact analysis comes in.

178
00:09:32.390 --> 00:09:35.981
It helps me determine
what these numbers are.

179
00:09:35.981 --> 00:09:40.147
I might go to other people
in the organization.

180
00:09:40.147 --> 00:09:42.601
We'll brainstorm,
we'll talk about what it's worth.

181
00:09:42.601 --> 00:09:46.463
I might go to other organizations
in the same industry and

182
00:09:46.463 --> 00:09:50.820
see what they consider, right,
maybe get some help from them.

183
00:09:50.820 --> 00:09:54.256
So we assign our assets and values,
some are easier than others,

184
00:09:54.256 --> 00:09:58.003
like if I'm talking about my email
server I might be able to put, well,

185
00:09:58.003 --> 00:10:02.010
that one's still gonna be tough because
there's a lot of things tied to it.

186
00:10:02.010 --> 00:10:06.638
All right, my business impact analysis

It wasn't that organization
that hacked me.

514
00:26:35.650 --> 00:26:36.720
I could get angry with them.

515
00:26:36.720 --> 00:26:40.660
>> It's not a crime to be bad at security,
unfortunately [LAUGH].

516
00:26:40.660 --> 00:26:41.210
So you, so

517
00:26:41.210 --> 00:26:44.670
now all of a sudden you've gotta bring
the legal aspect of, am I even allowed to?

518
00:26:44.670 --> 00:26:47.680
I don't know the systems that
I'm getting ready to attack,

519
00:26:47.680 --> 00:26:49.320
that the attack was launched from.

520
00:26:49.320 --> 00:26:53.500
So I don't know if this is actually the
hacker's system or an intermediate system.

521
00:26:53.500 --> 00:26:56.170
So it's just not a good idea.

522
00:26:56.170 --> 00:27:00.350
You know the other thing they'll
say when they talk about hack back

523
00:27:00.350 --> 00:27:03.310
I always thought was interesting,
was you know reverse engineering

524
00:27:03.310 --> 00:27:06.570
an attack is a lot easier than
coming up with an attack yourself.

525
00:27:08.010 --> 00:27:11.015
The example I was reading
about was Stuxnet.

526
00:27:11.015 --> 00:27:15.100
Stuxnet was an extremely complex
attack that took advantage of

527
00:27:15.100 --> 00:27:16.590
several vulnerabilities.

528
00:27:18.060 --> 00:27:22.468
And once it got released,
now it's out there.

529
00:27:22.468 --> 00:27:25.300
And everybody can stop and
they can analyze that code.

530
00:27:25.300 --> 00:27:27.050
And they can tweak it to fit their needs,
and

531
00:27:27.050 --> 00:27:31.860
basically create their own modified
Stuxnet to work in their needs.

532
00:27:31.860 --> 00:27:34.133
So that's another reason not to hack back.

533
00:27:34.133 --> 00:27:35.740
I know that's a little bit of a stretch.

534
00:27:35.740 --> 00:27:38.650
But you know you don't want to
expose some of your techniques for

535
00:27:38.650 --> 00:27:42.610
fear of them turning around and
using those same techniques against you.

536
00:27:42.610 --> 00:27:46.020
>> Yeah, I think Stuxnet used
like four zero-ay attacks.

537
00:27:46.020 --> 00:27:47.390
>> Yeah.
>> It was insane.

538
00:27:47.390 --> 00:27:50.770
>> It's crazy, but here's a somebody,
something, some organization,

539
00:27:50.770 --> 00:27:51.320
we don't know who.

540
00:27:51.320 --> 00:27:52.092
>> Wink, wink.

541
00:27:52.092 --> 00:27:53.539
[LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH] No verification, anyway,

542
00:27:53.539 --> 00:27:54.206
of who did that.

543
00:27:54.206 --> 00:27:58.940
But they're sitting on
these zero-day attacks.

544
00:27:58.940 --> 00:28:00.760
And why weren't they using them all?

545
00:28:00.760 --> 00:28:02.970
Why didn't they tell somebody about them?

546
00:28:02.970 --> 00:28:04.370
>> Cuz they wanted to use it.

547
00:28:04.370 --> 00:28:05.730
>> That's their ace in the hole.

548
00:28:05.730 --> 00:28:07.847
They know that they can whip
this out anytime they need it.

549
00:28:07.847 --> 00:28:10.206
Unless somebody finds
it before they use it,

550
00:28:10.206 --> 00:28:15.510
there's a good chance that they're gonna
be successful with that particular attack.

551
00:28:15.510 --> 00:28:20.020
I know there's been a lot in the news
about certain documents leaking out and

552
00:28:20.020 --> 00:28:23.840
finding out about organizations here
in the US that have been sitting on

553
00:28:23.840 --> 00:28:25.030
all of these vulnerabilities.

554
00:28:25.030 --> 00:28:30.520
These zero days that they don't want to
release because then they'll get patched,

555
00:28:30.520 --> 00:28:32.675
and they won't be valid anymore.

556
00:28:32.675 --> 00:28:34.505
But that's another topic for another show,

557
00:28:34.505 --> 00:28:38.575
and another day when we don't
have objectives to cover.

558
00:28:38.575 --> 00:28:42.365
So I think, Daniel, that pretty
much covers attacks and malware.

559
00:28:42.365 --> 00:28:46.410
Again, it's a lot about understanding
the different types of attacks and

560
00:28:46.410 --> 00:28:48.450
malware that we're going to face.

561
00:28:48.450 --> 00:28:52.684
And having a good terminology base,
so that we can discuss these and

562
00:28:52.684 --> 00:28:54.998
protect our networks against them.

563
00:28:54.998 --> 00:28:57.355
>> Yep, I think you said it great
about talking about being able

564
00:28:57.355 --> 00:28:58.150
to discuss things.

565
00:28:58.150 --> 00:28:59.688
You have to be able to speak the language.

566
00:28:59.688 --> 00:29:04.473
And a lot of that come down to basic
terminology, definitions, brute force

567
00:29:04.473 --> 00:29:10.170
memorization of certain ideas and concepts
that are within the security community.

568
00:29:10.170 --> 00:29:13.710
So, it's just one of those things that
we have to do as security professionals.

569
00:29:13.710 --> 00:29:18.233
And Mike, you did a fantastic job of
walking us through a litany of different

570
00:29:18.233 --> 00:29:22.404
terms and definitions that we can
now assimilate into our language and

571
00:29:22.404 --> 00:29:24.116
have those conversations.

572
00:29:24.116 --> 00:29:25.420
So thank you for that.

573
00:29:25.420 --> 00:29:27.220
We do thank our good viewers for
joining us.

574
00:29:27.220 --> 00:29:30.430
But I guess it's about that time for
us to sign off for ITPro.TV.

575
00:29:30.430 --> 00:29:32.140
I've been your host Daniel Lowrie.

576
00:29:32.140 --> 00:29:33.070
>> And I'm Mike Rodrick.

577
00:29:33.070 --> 00:29:41.526
>> And we'll see you next time.
[MUSIC].

578
00:29:41.526 --> 00:29:46.980
>> Thank you for watching ITPro.TV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Mike explore the fundamentals of Incident Handling. They begin by explaining how to prepare for an incident through policies and training. Then they tackle incident identification, containment, eradication, and recovery. They finish by exploring investigation techniques and legal considerations.
episodes.title: Incident Response
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.008 --> 00:00:02.135
Welcome to ITProTV,
I'm your host Don Pezet.

2
00:00:02.135 --> 00:00:07.512
[SOUND]

3
00:00:07.512 --> 00:00:10.872
>> You're watching ITProTV.

4
00:00:10.872 --> 00:00:17.122
>> Greetings everyone, and welcome
to another great episode of ITProTV.

5
00:00:17.122 --> 00:00:18.336
I'm your host Daniel Lowrie.

6
00:00:18.336 --> 00:00:20.716
And in today's episode, that's right,

7
00:00:20.716 --> 00:00:24.162
we are back with more on our
GIAC Security Essentials series.

8
00:00:24.162 --> 00:00:27.957
And joining me in the studio is the man
that has been helping us along this

9
00:00:27.957 --> 00:00:28.598
endeavor.

10
00:00:28.598 --> 00:00:32.711
He figures he'll come back for just one
more at least if not a little bit more

11
00:00:32.711 --> 00:00:35.350
than that, our good friend Mr.
Mike Rodrick.

12
00:00:35.350 --> 00:00:36.300
Mike welcome back man.

13
00:00:36.300 --> 00:00:37.160
We're glad to have you again.

14
00:00:37.160 --> 00:00:38.380
>> Hey thanks for having me back,

15
00:00:38.380 --> 00:00:42.810
excited as always to be doing
our GIAC Security Essentials.

16
00:00:42.810 --> 00:00:47.410
All right so in this episode,
we wanna take a look at incident response.

17
00:00:47.410 --> 00:00:52.640
And then, we wanna talk about incident
handling fundamentals, right?

18
00:00:52.640 --> 00:00:57.930
And when we talk about incident response,
planning is a big part of it.

19
00:00:57.930 --> 00:01:01.520
And so
we have to have an idea of what it means.

20
00:01:01.520 --> 00:01:03.658
What is incident response?

21
00:01:03.658 --> 00:01:06.600
And when we look at incident response in
that way, when we talk about fundamentals.

22
00:01:06.600 --> 00:01:10.450
We're really talking about five or
six different phases here.

23
00:01:10.450 --> 00:01:13.730
We've got preparation, identification,

24
00:01:13.730 --> 00:01:19.240
containment, eradication,
recovery, and then lessons learned.

25
00:01:19.240 --> 00:01:24.100
So those are the steps we're gonna go
through as we do incident handling or

26
00:01:24.100 --> 00:01:25.010
incident response.

27
00:01:25.010 --> 00:01:28.420
And so let's break each one of those
down so we understand what they mean.

28
00:01:28.420 --> 00:01:29.470
And we'll just start at the beginning.

29
00:01:29.470 --> 00:01:31.070
It's always a good place to start.

30
00:01:31.070 --> 00:01:32.980
And that is preparation.

31
00:01:32.980 --> 00:01:39.270
We have to prepare before we attempt
to do any type of incident response.

32
00:01:39.270 --> 00:01:41.810
Now what does that preparation include?

33
00:01:41.810 --> 00:01:45.250
Well primarily it's going to be policies,
right?

34
00:01:45.250 --> 00:01:48.290
Or a big part of it I guess I should say,
is policies.

35
00:01:48.290 --> 00:01:51.190
And we put our policies in place that

36
00:01:51.190 --> 00:01:54.540
tell us what we're gonna do
in the event of an incident.

37
00:01:54.540 --> 00:01:56.280
How we're gonna go about handling it.

38
00:01:56.280 --> 00:01:59.860
Who is gonna do what,
who needs to be contacted.

39
00:01:59.860 --> 00:02:03.960
What we define as an incident.

40
00:02:03.960 --> 00:02:06.600
All of that is going
to be in our policies.

41
00:02:06.600 --> 00:02:09.640
So policies are gonna play
a big part in the preparation.

42
00:02:10.800 --> 00:02:14.940
And then training is gonna be
the other big part of preparation.

43
00:02:14.940 --> 00:02:21.110
And that means taking these policies
that we've created and testing them out.

44
00:02:21.110 --> 00:02:23.955
Making sure we go through our procedures.

45
00:02:23.955 --> 00:02:28.175
Make sure we do tabletop
exercises if that's what it takes

46
00:02:28.175 --> 00:02:31.775
to make sure we don't have
any gaps in our policies.

47
00:02:31.775 --> 00:02:36.575
Anything that we've missed that we haven't
though of might show itself doing these

48
00:02:36.575 --> 00:02:37.867
tabletop exercises.

49
00:02:37.867 --> 00:02:42.496
So training, how to handle evidence,

50
00:02:42.496 --> 00:02:46.150
following chains of custody.

51
00:02:46.150 --> 00:02:50.213
Doing practices where we try
to do an investigation on

52
00:02:50.213 --> 00:02:53.120
a computer imaging hard drives.

53
00:02:53.120 --> 00:02:54.310
All of that,
we should practice all of that.

54
00:02:54.310 --> 00:02:58.799
So when it comes to preparation, getting
ready for incident response is going to

55
00:02:58.799 --> 00:03:01.980
include having these policies and
procedures in place.

56
00:03:01.980 --> 00:03:05.260
As well as going through training.

57
00:03:05.260 --> 00:03:07.540
And then we get to
the identification phase.

58
00:03:07.540 --> 00:03:10.780
And so we've done all of our policies.

59
00:03:10.780 --> 00:03:13.620
We've got everything laid out of
what we're gonna do in the event of

60
00:03:13.620 --> 00:03:15.060
an incident.

61
00:03:15.060 --> 00:03:17.200
We've practiced it over and over again so

62
00:03:17.200 --> 00:03:20.300
I can do it in the dark without
even thinking about it.

63
00:03:20.300 --> 00:03:21.720
We're good to go there.

64
00:03:21.720 --> 00:03:23.740
Now we've got the identification phase.

65
00:03:23.740 --> 00:03:29.010
And this is the identification,
we'll call it a phase.

66
00:03:29.010 --> 00:03:33.840
This is where we determined that there
has been some type of incident, right.

67
00:03:33.840 --> 00:03:39.400
That that something is going to
trigger our incident response plan.

68
00:03:39.400 --> 00:03:41.360
Now where did we get this information,
right?

69
00:03:41.360 --> 00:03:44.290
Well what is it that leads us to believe
that there's been an incident, or

70
00:03:44.290 --> 00:03:45.620
that we've identified an incident?

71
00:03:45.620 --> 00:03:50.756
And we look at log files, are probably
one of the big sources of information.

72
00:03:50.756 --> 00:03:53.400
>> I assume there are some
blatant things like,

73
00:03:53.400 --> 00:03:56.315
there's ransomware on my computer and
it's asking me for BitCoin.

74
00:03:56.315 --> 00:04:00.510
Right, that would definitely be like,
I have an incident happening.

75
00:04:00.510 --> 00:04:03.470
>> Yeah, that would most likely
fall under say employees.

76
00:04:03.470 --> 00:04:06.190
Because they're gonna call somebody and
say, hey look.

77
00:04:06.190 --> 00:04:09.540
I've got this big thing on my desk,
and it's on my desktop, that says,

78
00:04:09.540 --> 00:04:13.440
I've been infected, or
all of my files have been encrypted.

79
00:04:13.440 --> 00:04:17.830
Here's where you can put your credit card
number in to pay to get your files back.

80
00:04:17.830 --> 00:04:21.530
Yeah, so definitely,
would be a sign of an incident.

81
00:04:23.100 --> 00:04:25.350
Your IDSs and your IPSs, right?

82
00:04:25.350 --> 00:04:28.920
Your intrusion detection systems,
they're capturing all that information

83
00:04:28.920 --> 00:04:31.240
from all your different
sensors from your servers.

84
00:04:32.340 --> 00:04:35.160
IPSs might be sending you
alerts letting you know that

85
00:04:35.160 --> 00:04:36.870
there's been malicious behavior.

86
00:04:36.870 --> 00:04:39.040
It might automate some of that.

87
00:04:39.040 --> 00:04:43.880
So IDSs and IPSs, SIEM systems,
system information and event management.

88
00:04:43.880 --> 00:04:48.520
These are correlating log files from
multiple devices on our network,

89
00:04:48.520 --> 00:04:49.930
pulling it all together.

90
00:04:49.930 --> 00:04:53.000
Great place to look for
signs of an incident.

91
00:04:53.000 --> 00:04:56.860
Antivirus software can warn you,
hey this system has been infected.

92
00:04:56.860 --> 00:04:59.640
It was quarantined but
I still need to go and respond and

93
00:04:59.640 --> 00:05:01.870
take a look at what it was,
how it got there.

94
00:05:01.870 --> 00:05:02.910
Making sure it didn't spread.

95
00:05:02.910 --> 00:05:04.890
Or maybe it wasn't quarantined, right?

96
00:05:04.890 --> 00:05:09.070
But AV can be an alert system to tell
me we've got an infection or incident.

97
00:05:10.570 --> 00:05:11.850
Exploit websites, right?

98
00:05:11.850 --> 00:05:13.580
Going out and doing your research.

99
00:05:13.580 --> 00:05:16.019
So, remember we've talked
about this before,

100
00:05:16.019 --> 00:05:18.758
you have to stay on top of
things in the security world.

101
00:05:18.758 --> 00:05:23.312
You need to follow bug trackers and news
feeds that these antivirus vendors put

102
00:05:23.312 --> 00:05:26.010
out, other security organizations put out.

103
00:05:26.010 --> 00:05:33.190
Because they're gonna give you information
about exploits that have been seen.

104
00:05:33.190 --> 00:05:36.170
Or vulnerabilities that have
been discovered that we might be

105
00:05:36.170 --> 00:05:37.040
susceptible to.

106
00:05:39.300 --> 00:05:42.895
Hacker sites, right,
they can give you just as much,

107
00:05:42.895 --> 00:05:45.330
some valuable information as well.

108
00:05:45.330 --> 00:05:47.761
And to be careful when
you go to them sites and

109
00:05:47.761 --> 00:05:50.006
don't infect yourself going to those.

110
00:05:50.006 --> 00:05:52.740
But they might put information
talking there talking with each other.

111
00:05:52.740 --> 00:05:56.624
There's information for other hackers
about techniques they've learned or

112
00:05:56.624 --> 00:05:58.750
places they've been able to compromise.

113
00:05:58.750 --> 00:06:01.160
We'll find information there.

114
00:06:01.160 --> 00:06:07.820
Vendors put out information, Microsoft,
Adobe, all these different vendors.

115
00:06:07.820 --> 00:06:11.960
If there's been
a vulnerability discovered,

116
00:06:11.960 --> 00:06:13.680
they'll put out a patch for it.

117
00:06:13.680 --> 00:06:16.390
And in the release for that patch,
they'll typically talk about

118
00:06:18.710 --> 00:06:23.060
symptoms of an infection,
what they're trying to patch.

119
00:06:23.060 --> 00:06:25.060
So this vulnerability is,

120
00:06:25.060 --> 00:06:27.630
what it might look like if somebody
tries to take advantage of it.

121
00:06:27.630 --> 00:06:28.610
So you can get information there.

122
00:06:28.610 --> 00:06:31.530
And as I said, employees can be
a big source of information as well,

123
00:06:31.530 --> 00:06:34.190
they're kind of our front line,
our eyes and ears out there.

124
00:06:34.190 --> 00:06:37.280
They're gonna let us know when
something weird is going on.

125
00:06:37.280 --> 00:06:41.903
Hey, my computer, it was kind of
flickering when I went to log onto this

126
00:06:41.903 --> 00:06:44.770
page, or my screen's turned upside down.

127
00:06:44.770 --> 00:06:46.680
Silly little,
I shouldn't say silly little.

128
00:06:46.680 --> 00:06:51.073
But some of those things that we used to
associate with malware was the CD Rom

129
00:06:51.073 --> 00:06:52.830
drawer opening up on its own.

130
00:06:52.830 --> 00:06:54.560
Typically I don't see
much of that any more.

131
00:06:54.560 --> 00:06:58.388
But again it's the end user that's out
there that's dealing with the systems.

132
00:06:58.388 --> 00:07:01.396
That will probably be the first
one to see signs of an infection.

133
00:07:01.396 --> 00:07:06.850
So they can be a great source
of identification of incidents.

134
00:07:06.850 --> 00:07:10.700
A lot of places we want to be monitoring,
looking for signs of an incident.

135
00:07:11.850 --> 00:07:18.080
Once we have picked up on a sign, that
we've got something that's indicating,

136
00:07:18.080 --> 00:07:19.390
that there has been an incident.

137
00:07:19.390 --> 00:07:23.260
We do our investigation, we found
out there was some type of incident.

138
00:07:23.260 --> 00:07:26.010
Our next task is to contain that, right?

139
00:07:26.010 --> 00:07:28.710
I do not want that spreading
to the rest of my network,

140
00:07:28.710 --> 00:07:33.790
I want to try to minimize the impact
that this incident was able to cause.

141
00:07:33.790 --> 00:07:38.810
Whether that's somebody getting access to
my file server, they're exfiltrating data.

142
00:07:38.810 --> 00:07:41.175
Maybe I stop that network connection so

143
00:07:41.175 --> 00:07:44.120
they can't get anymore
data out of the network.

144
00:07:44.120 --> 00:07:49.410
If it's a piece of malware,
I segregate or isolate that system so

145
00:07:49.410 --> 00:07:53.655
that it can't spread other
machines on my network.

146
00:07:53.655 --> 00:07:57.328
So maybe you disconnect
it from the network,

147
00:07:57.328 --> 00:08:00.428
you quarantine it Or you tolerate it.

148
00:08:00.428 --> 00:08:05.886
That sounds odd but it might be
an incident where it's like okay,

149
00:08:05.886 --> 00:08:08.467
I see that this is occurring but

150
00:08:08.467 --> 00:08:13.070
it doesn't warrant any
type of incident response.

151
00:08:13.070 --> 00:08:16.830
We're going to basically wait it out.

152
00:08:16.830 --> 00:08:19.370
Either deal with it because the risk or

153
00:08:19.370 --> 00:08:23.630
the impact is so small that we're
not that concerned with it,

154
00:08:23.630 --> 00:08:28.680
or we need to wait for
further development on the incident.

155
00:08:30.130 --> 00:08:32.300
Then comes the eradication.

156
00:08:32.300 --> 00:08:35.990
Once we've got that contained,
once we've got the infected system or

157
00:08:35.990 --> 00:08:38.030
systems isolated from
the rest of the network,

158
00:08:38.030 --> 00:08:42.530
or whatever type of incident it might be,
then we try to eradicate, right?

159
00:08:42.530 --> 00:08:45.230
We try to get rid of the malware,
for example,

160
00:08:45.230 --> 00:08:49.120
we remove the back door that somebody's
been using to get into our system.

161
00:08:49.120 --> 00:08:50.780
We deactivate accounts.

162
00:08:50.780 --> 00:08:52.230
>> You pay the bit coins [LAUGH].

163
00:08:52.230 --> 00:08:56.740
>> You'll pay the bit coins to get
your encryption key, all right?

164
00:08:56.740 --> 00:08:58.730
But we're doing our eradication and

165
00:08:58.730 --> 00:09:03.500
this gonna include patching
systems against vulnerabilities.

166
00:09:04.520 --> 00:09:08.760
So patching, removing software,
rebuilding systems.

167
00:09:09.960 --> 00:09:12.170
Then we get into the recovery phase.

00:39:48.490 --> 00:39:50.110
know the difference between a stream and

737
00:39:50.110 --> 00:39:53.770
a block cypher, and
that should get you pretty far.

738
00:39:53.770 --> 00:39:55.270
>> Well,
that's a great place to wrap this up.

739
00:39:55.270 --> 00:39:57.550
As always, Mike,
we appreciate having you here.

740
00:39:57.550 --> 00:40:00.830
And we appreciate you the viewer watching,
hopefully you've enjoyed it.

741
00:40:00.830 --> 00:40:03.720
Signing out for ITProTV,
I've been your host Wes Bryan.

742
00:40:03.720 --> 00:40:04.610
>> And I'm Mike Rodrick.

743
00:40:04.610 --> 00:40:07.149
>> And we'll see you next time.

744
00:40:07.149 --> 00:40:13.263
[MUSIC]

745
00:40:13.263 --> 00:40:15.090
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Mike tackle the world of public key infrastructure (PKI) and dive more into asymmetric key encryption, the infrastructure, and components such as certificates, certificate issuance, certificate validation, smart cards and certificate-based authentication. They will also look at certificate authorities (CAs), root CAs and the hierarchical infrastructure.

1

security essentials, or

00:00:21.770 --> 00:00:23.370
And joining us back in the studios for

00:00:25.810 --> 00:00:26.810
Mike, how you doing sir?

11

>> Doing great, Wes, glad to be back and

12
00:00:32.670 --> 00:00:36.775
In this one we're gonna be looking
at public key infrastructure,

13
00:00:36.775 --> 00:00:42.255
or PKI, as well as taking a look

which is nothing to do with dinosaurs.

00:00:44.465 --> 00:00:46.815
And we also need to go back,
wrap around, and

talk a little bit about crypto attacks.

17
00:00:49.375 --> 00:00:53.920
And we talked a lot about cryptology,

18
00:00:53.920 --> 00:00:57.040
And I wanna talk about some of
the attacks that we might face.

19
00:00:57.040 --> 00:01:01.780
And really,
more familiarizing ourselves with some

20
00:01:01.780 --> 00:01:07.210
terminology that we need to be able to
discuss when we discuss that cryptography.

21
00:01:07.210 --> 00:01:09.370
Whew, tongue-tied today.

22
00:01:09.370 --> 00:01:15.190
All right, so, let's start off with PKI,
or public key infrastructure and

23
00:01:15.190 --> 00:01:19.790
in the previous episode, we had talked
about different encryption methods.

24
00:01:19.790 --> 00:01:22.700
We talked about symmetric
versus asymmetric algorithms,

25
00:01:22.700 --> 00:01:28.200
and where secret key or
shared key for the symmetric.

26
00:01:28.200 --> 00:01:33.310
And then with asymmetric,
we also called it public key cryptography,

27
00:01:33.310 --> 00:01:35.060
asymmetric encryption or

28
00:01:35.060 --> 00:01:41.330
asymmetric algorithms where we have two
different keys that work as a key pair.

29
00:01:41.330 --> 00:01:42.900
And one of them you do the encryption and

30
00:01:42.900 --> 00:01:45.520
then the other one would
be used to decrypt it.

31
00:01:45.520 --> 00:01:48.670
And I mentioned in that episode
that normally that key pair,

32
00:01:48.670 --> 00:01:50.940
that gets assigned to you or
gets generated for

33
00:01:50.940 --> 00:01:54.840
you, the public key is part of
your certificate, all right.

34
00:01:54.840 --> 00:01:58.140
And then the private key gets
stored in a secure location and

35
00:01:58.140 --> 00:02:01.850
you can distribute your certificate which
includes your public key to whomever.

36
00:02:01.850 --> 00:02:05.410
If you make it available on the web, store
in Active Directory, whatever you're doing

37
00:02:05.410 --> 00:02:08.330
in your environment, email it to
somebody if they need it, right.

38
00:02:08.330 --> 00:02:10.870
So what we wanna do now is talk
about now is how we got that.

39
00:02:10.870 --> 00:02:15.080
We need to talk about the infrastructure

40
00:02:15.080 --> 00:02:18.950
What if I wanna use certificates,
I decide that hey certificates make sense,

41
00:02:18.950 --> 00:02:21.730
I want people to have certificates so

42
00:02:21.730 --> 00:02:23.750
Maybe we store them on a smart card,

43
00:02:23.750 --> 00:02:27.340
We've talked about that in our
authentication and authorization.

44
00:02:27.340 --> 00:02:29.520
Maybe that's what we're gonna

45
00:02:29.520 --> 00:02:34.070
Maybe just for doorway entry, or
for logging onto the systems.

46
00:02:34.070 --> 00:02:38.650
Or maybe I wanna issue certificates to my
machines so that they can create IP set

47
00:02:38.650 --> 00:02:42.860
conversations between those file servers
that contain sensitive information.

48
00:02:42.860 --> 00:02:45.780
So we can secure that, right,
all that's done with certificates.

49
00:02:45.780 --> 00:02:48.960
That VPN that your
mobile users create when

50
00:02:48.960 --> 00:02:51.080
they connect back to the workplace, right.

51
00:02:51.080 --> 00:02:53.830
Good chance that you wanna use
certificates as one of the authentication

52
00:02:53.830 --> 00:02:57.030
methods in that or direct access or
whatever else it is.

53
00:02:57.030 --> 00:02:59.900
Or you need to set up
an SSL on your website for

54
00:02:59.900 --> 00:03:03.120
your customers to come and
buy products from you.

55
00:03:03.120 --> 00:03:06.730
They're not gonna put that credit number
in there if you don't have a secure,

56
00:03:06.730 --> 00:03:07.620
connection, right.

57
00:03:07.620 --> 00:03:10.550
They wanna see that S,
at the end of that HTTP.

58
00:03:10.550 --> 00:03:15.710
Whether that is SSL, or TLS, they wanna
make sure the connection is secure,

59
00:03:15.710 --> 00:03:17.000
which means we need certificates.

60
00:03:17.000 --> 00:03:20.797
So certificates play a big part
in security in the enterprise and

61
00:03:20.797 --> 00:03:24.610
it's important we understand how
we go about supporting that.

62
00:03:24.610 --> 00:03:28.000
If we're gonna generate our own, or
we can go out and purchase these,

63
00:03:28.000 --> 00:03:29.090
actually, as well.

64
00:03:29.090 --> 00:03:30.780
So let's start with just the basics.

65
00:03:30.780 --> 00:03:33.460
Remember, a certificate
is not a piece of paper.

66
00:03:33.460 --> 00:03:35.570
You're not gonna get
anything handed to you.

67
00:03:35.570 --> 00:03:41.180
It is an electronic document
that really does one big thing,

68
00:03:41.180 --> 00:03:45.710
and that is tie an identity to a key pair,
right.

69
00:03:45.710 --> 00:03:49.660
We're gonna generate a key pair,
those mathematically related keys, and

70
00:03:49.660 --> 00:03:52.630
then we're gonna take that public key and
we're gonna put it in that certificate,

71
00:03:52.630 --> 00:03:55.820
and then we're gonna
bind that to an identity.

72
00:03:55.820 --> 00:03:59.800
Whether that's Wes, cuz he is an employee,
or whether that's the laptop, because we

73
00:03:59.800 --> 00:04:04.390
wanna issue them to the laptops, or
we're binding it to our website,

74
00:04:04.390 --> 00:04:08.630
the web server's identity svr01
dot lab dot itpro dot tv.

75
00:04:08.630 --> 00:04:11.740
We can use wildcards in there
when it comes to some of that.

76
00:04:11.740 --> 00:04:15.200
But basically, I want you to understand
that we're taking where a certificate

77
00:04:15.200 --> 00:04:18.735
is tying in a key pair to an identity.

78
00:04:18.735 --> 00:04:20.765
Because once Wes gets
issued that certificate,

79
00:04:20.765 --> 00:04:24.125
right, that has his information
in the certificate, his name.

80
00:04:24.125 --> 00:04:26.805
If it's in Active Directory it might
include other information about his

81
00:04:26.805 --> 00:04:30.535
account, and then that public key and
then he has the private key.

82
00:04:30.535 --> 00:04:34.465
So that key pair is now tied to Wes,
right, or

83
00:04:34.465 --> 00:04:36.439
if I issue to a machine or what have you.

84
00:04:37.740 --> 00:04:39.110
So we got that down pat, I think,

85
00:04:39.110 --> 00:04:43.540
certificates really tie
an identity to a key pair.

86
00:04:43.540 --> 00:04:46.390
Now some other terms we
need to be familiar with,

87
00:04:46.390 --> 00:04:50.480
we need to understand what PKI is,
or public key infrastructure.

88
00:04:50.480 --> 00:04:54.000
And PKI is all the pieces parts

89
00:04:54.000 --> 00:04:59.230
that we use to manage certificates and
it's throughout their entire lifetime.

90
00:04:59.230 --> 00:05:04.510
That is the issuing, the creation,
and the issuing of those certificates,

91
00:05:04.510 --> 00:05:07.780
to the managing of those certificates,
during their lifetime.

92
00:05:07.780 --> 00:05:09.960
And then eventually the removal or

93
00:05:09.960 --> 00:05:15.000
revocation of those certificates as well,
so that entire process.

94
00:05:15.000 --> 00:05:17.243
And there's a few different pieces,
that names or

95
00:05:17.243 --> 00:05:18.765
terms we need to be familiar with.

96
00:05:18.765 --> 00:05:21.359
So let's take a look at my screen here,
and

97
00:05:21.359 --> 00:05:26.056
this is a platform-independent view of
a PKI or public key infrastructure.

98
00:05:26.056 --> 00:05:29.787
I've got Alice down here, and
she wants to request a certificate so

99
00:05:29.787 --> 00:05:32.696
that she can digitally sign her emails,
all right.

100
00:05:32.696 --> 00:05:36.380
So what' she's gonna do is she's
gonna step number one here,

101
00:05:36.380 --> 00:05:39.300
she's gonna talk to
a registration authority.

102
00:05:39.300 --> 00:05:44.140
Now the registration authority
is the part of the PKI that

103
00:05:44.140 --> 00:05:46.300
validates the identity, right.

104
00:05:46.300 --> 00:05:48.880
I shouldn't be able to talk to that
registration authority and say,

105
00:05:48.880 --> 00:05:49.580
hey, I'm Wes.

106
00:05:49.580 --> 00:05:51.140
Can I get a certificate, right?

107
00:05:51.140 --> 00:05:54.550
We've gotta make sure that we are issuing
the certificates in the proper name.

108
00:05:54.550 --> 00:05:55.580
What if I went in and said, hey,

109
00:05:55.580 --> 00:05:58.030
I want to get a certificate in
the name of Bank of America, right.

110
00:05:58.030 --> 00:06:00.580
And I set up a website that
looks just like Bank of America.

111
00:06:00.580 --> 00:06:03.320
I've got a certificate that
says I'm Bank of America.

112
00:06:03.320 --> 00:06:05.190
That would not be a good thing, right?

113
00:06:05.190 --> 00:06:09.340
So a very important part of
issuing certificates, and

114
00:06:09.340 --> 00:06:12.550
of our public key infrastructure,
is that registration authority,

115
00:06:12.550 --> 00:06:15.805
the part where we validate the identity.

116
00:06:15.805 --> 00:06:17.770
Because we're tying a key
pair to an identity,

117
00:06:17.770 --> 00:06:20.170
I better make sure I know that identity.

118
00:06:20.170 --> 00:06:24.130
You know this isn't exactly the same but
by analogy here Mike,

119
00:06:24.130 --> 00:06:28.410
recently I had to travel overseas and
I needed a passport really quick.

120
00:06:28.410 --> 00:06:31.970
But I couldn't actually apply for
one and get it back in time,

121
00:06:31.970 --> 00:06:36.160
so they had somebody that I could take
all of my identifying information.

122
00:06:36.160 --> 00:06:38.770
And I could hand it over to them, and

123
00:06:38.770 --> 00:06:41.150
then they could request
the passport on my behalf.

124
00:06:41.150 --> 00:06:44.770
So your registration authority is kinda
like a proxy between you getting that

125
00:06:44.770 --> 00:06:46.490
certificate and
requesting that certificate.

126
00:06:46.490 --> 00:06:47.230
Are we pretty close here?

127
00:06:47.230 --> 00:06:50.440
>> That's a great analogy,
because whoever's doing the issuing of

128
00:06:50.440 --> 00:06:56.230
the passport trusts this person or this
entity that you took your information to.

129
00:06:56.230 --> 00:07:00.460
And they're saying, okay we're gonna
trust the fact that this third party

130
00:07:00.460 --> 00:07:02.390
is validating all that information.

131
00:07:02.390 --> 00:07:05.014
And that's exactly what
the registration authority is doing,

132
00:07:05.014 --> 00:07:06.910
cuz it's not issuing the certificate.

133
00:07:06.910 --> 00:07:11.040
The registration authority is
only validating the identity.

134
00:07:11.040 --> 00:07:14.850
And then it's gonna forward in step two,
is when it forwards that over and

135
00:07:14.850 --> 00:07:15.715
says all right.

136
00:07:15.715 --> 00:07:18.524
I have validated all this information,
here is the request,

137
00:07:18.524 --> 00:07:20.584
here is the information
about the identity.

138
00:07:20.584 --> 00:07:25.121
Now the certificate authority, this part
up here, this is the one that actually

139
00:07:25.121 --> 00:07:29.320
does the issuing the generation and
the issuing of the certificate.

140
00:07:29.320 --> 00:07:34.610
So, in Wes's is analogy that would be
whoever is actually issuing the passport.

141
00:07:34.610 --> 00:07:37.260
It would be the US government that
would be issuing the passport.

142
00:07:37.260 --> 00:07:40.120
But they had somebody else acting as

143
00:07:40.120 --> 00:07:43.820
the registration authority
on behalf of them, right.

144
00:07:43.820 --> 00:07:46.422
So that's a great analogy,
I really like that.

145
00:07:46.422 --> 00:07:50.368
All right, now the certificate authority
then based on that information

146
00:07:50.368 --> 00:07:53.243
it receives and
policies that it might have in place.

147
00:07:53.243 --> 00:07:56.809
Like who's allowed or not allowed to
request, what information has to be

148
00:07:56.809 --> 00:07:59.915
presented, like What if I went
to the registration authority,

149
00:07:59.915 --> 00:08:03.720
and I gave him my name, and my last name,
and my address and yadda yadda.

150
00:08:03.720 --> 00:08:07.090
Tries to present that,
maybe that doesn't comply with the policy.

151
00:08:07.090 --> 00:08:08.980
Wes, you probably had to provide certain

152
00:08:08.980 --> 00:08:10.131
documents-
>> [CROSSTALK]

153
00:08:10.131 --> 00:08:11.310
>> Yeah, absolutely.

154
00:08:11.310 --> 00:08:12.400
They wanted everything.

155
00:08:12.400 --> 00:08:15.190
About the only thing I think that
they didn't want was my blood type.

156
00:08:15.190 --> 00:08:17.730
>> Yeah, and if you had left
one of those documents out?

157
00:08:17.730 --> 00:08:21.640
>> Yeah, the registration authority,
if you will, in this case,

158
00:08:21.640 --> 00:08:22.930
was gonna take that document.

159
00:08:22.930 --> 00:08:25.230
And they were gonna send it back to me,
and they wouldn't even have bothered.

160
00:08:25.230 --> 00:08:29.420
>> Yeah, exactly, so, we have policies
that'll define what information is

161
00:08:29.420 --> 00:08:33.100
necessary to request a certificate.

162
00:08:33.100 --> 00:08:35.200
Who can receive a certificate?

163
00:08:35.200 --> 00:08:37.890
What the certificate can be used for,
because we haven't talked about that.

164
00:08:37.890 --> 00:08:40.260
Certificates have purpose as well.

165
00:08:40.260 --> 00:08:41.600
So, we'll continue on here.

166
00:08:41.600 --> 00:08:44.270
So, the certificate authority gets
the information from the registration

167
00:08:44.270 --> 00:08:45.120
authority.

168
00:08:45.120 --> 00:08:48.980
The certificate authority makes a
decision, says, okay, based on policy and

169
00:08:48.980 --> 00:08:52.120
the information given, we'll go ahead and
issue the certificate.

170
00:08:52.120 --> 00:08:54.430
The certificate then gets issued to Alice,

171
00:08:54.430 --> 00:08:59.270
that means she now has a digital
certificate with a public key inside it.

172
00:08:59.270 --> 00:09:04.780
And a private key that gets stored in
a secure location on her local hard drive.

173
00:09:04.780 --> 00:09:09.549
Now, she can take that certificate and
say present it to a secure mail server.

174
00:09:10.660 --> 00:09:14.950
All right, so maybe she's setting up
HTTPS to connect to that mail server,

175
00:09:14.950 --> 00:09:17.300
like in OWA, or something like that.

176
00:09:17.300 --> 00:09:21.390
But when she presents that certificate,
it doesn't automatically say, great,

177
00:09:21.390 --> 00:09:22.850
hey Alice, thanks for coming back.

178
00:09:22.850 --> 00:09:24.194
Here's your mail, right?

179
00:09:24.194 --> 00:09:26.621
It's gotta verify that certificate,

180
00:09:26.621 --> 00:09:31.189
cuz what if I made up a certificate
that looks a lot like Alice's, right?

181
00:09:31.189 --> 00:09:35.360
Or try to, we'll talk about how
easy that is here just second.

182
00:09:35.360 --> 00:09:38.536
What if, what if it's not Alice's
certificate, in other words?

183
00:09:38.536 --> 00:09:43.402
So, the mail server is not just gonna
blindly accept the certificate that Alice

184
00:09:43.402 --> 00:09:48.052
is presenting, it says okay,
this certificate says you're Alice.

185
00:09:48.052 --> 00:09:52.660
Right, and now I'm gonna talk to
what's called a validation authority.

186
00:09:52.660 --> 00:09:57.010
I'm gonna ask that validation authority,
hey, is this certificate okay?

187
00:09:57.010 --> 00:10:01.950
Things that it's checking
are primarily the expiration date,

188
00:10:01.950 --> 00:10:05.170
and its usage,
what the certificate could be used for.

189
00:10:05.170 --> 00:10:07.890
Making sure that,
if it's a certificate for EFS,

190
00:10:07.890 --> 00:10:12.660
Encrypting File System,
then it might not be valid for.

191
00:10:12.660 --> 00:10:14.500
A client identification, right?

192
00:10:14.500 --> 00:10:16.420
Certificates have
purposes built into them.

193
00:10:16.420 --> 00:10:20.530
And a certificate can be a single purpose,
or a multi-purpose certificate.

194
00:10:20.530 --> 00:10:25.640
It could be that you issue users one
certificate for encrypting file systems,

195
00:10:25.640 --> 00:10:29.560
but a different certificate for
doing digital signatures on emails, right?

196
00:10:29.560 --> 00:10:32.080
Or you could issue them a multi-purpose
certificate that covers all of those.

197
00:10:32.080 --> 00:10:37.040
But it's checking the purpose, and
the validity period on that certificate.

198
00:10:37.040 --> 00:10:39.850
>> I'm thinking of law enforcement here.

199
00:10:39.850 --> 00:10:43.414
If I have to present my driver's license,
they can see the driver's license.

200
00:10:43.414 --> 00:10:46.740
Now, technically, they can see
the expiration date on it, but

201
00:10:46.740 --> 00:10:50.248
what they don't know, just by
looking at it is whether my license,

202
00:10:50.248 --> 00:10:52.849
do I even have the right to
be on the road with this?

203
00:10:52.849 --> 00:10:54.790
So, they check,
kind a like their own database.

204
00:10:54.790 --> 00:10:56.480
Would that be close to
the validation authority,

205
00:10:56.480 --> 00:10:58.280
making sure that it hasn't been suspended?

206
00:10:58.280 --> 00:10:59.380
>> Exactly right.

207
00:10:59.380 --> 00:11:01.330
When we talk about,
it's another great analogy,

208
00:11:01.330 --> 00:11:06.160
is using that drivers license,
because it really fits this whole process.

209
00:11:06.160 --> 00:11:09.620
Here in the states, we have the Department
of Motor Vehicles, and they issue these

210
00:11:09.620 --> 00:11:13.382
drivers license, and before you can get a
license, you have to prove your identity.

211
00:11:13.382 --> 00:11:17.685
So, they're the registration authority
slash certificate authority,

212
00:11:17.685 --> 00:11:19.790
where they would validate
all my information,

213
00:11:19.790 --> 00:11:24.040
issue me a certificate, a driver's
license in this case, and hand it to me.

214
00:11:24.040 --> 00:11:26.890
They put a state of Florida seal,
in my case, here in Florida, and

215
00:11:26.890 --> 00:11:28.530
then they laminate it,
they handed it back to me.
