00:36:06.230 --> 00:36:09.470
And it's actually something
that can be adjusted.

690
00:36:09.470 --> 00:36:10.398
Like a lot of them,

691
00:36:10.398 --> 00:36:14.000
you have to be within down to two
centimeters to get it to activate.

692
00:36:14.000 --> 00:36:18.480
Others, you can set it up to a couple of
feet, where, just get that card close.

693
00:36:18.480 --> 00:36:21.050
Or as I walk by the doorway,

694
00:36:21.050 --> 00:36:24.620
maybe I've got a reader sitting over
here in the hall on the wall by door.

695
00:36:24.620 --> 00:36:25.890
And just me getting close,

696
00:36:25.890 --> 00:36:29.140
as I'm walking towards the door,
is enough to release the door.

697
00:36:29.140 --> 00:36:31.940
It says that's Mike, he's allowed
through this door between 8 and 5,

698
00:36:31.940 --> 00:36:34.160
and we'll go ahead and open them, right.

699
00:36:34.160 --> 00:36:35.118
So smart cards.

700
00:36:35.118 --> 00:36:38.600
Little chip, store information.

701
00:36:38.600 --> 00:36:41.730
They got memory, they've got processor.

702
00:36:41.730 --> 00:36:44.945
They can be contact-based,
where I need a reader to plug in.

703
00:36:44.945 --> 00:36:48.875
That reader can be hooked up via USB or
other mechanisms,

704
00:36:48.875 --> 00:36:50.740
like built in to the machine itself.

705
00:36:50.740 --> 00:36:52.260
And then you have contactless,

706
00:36:52.260 --> 00:36:56.100
which you use as a shortwave radio,
for the communications.

707
00:36:56.100 --> 00:36:58.210
>> Well, that's a great
wealth of information, Mike.

708
00:36:58.210 --> 00:37:01.140
We definitely appreciate you
stopping by and letting us know.

709
00:37:01.140 --> 00:37:05.405
But we have definitely pushed the clock,
to its wit's end on this one.

710
00:37:05.405 --> 00:37:06.470
>> [LAUGH]
>> So we're going to go ahead and

711
00:37:06.470 --> 00:37:09.630
take the time to sign out here at ITProTV.

712
00:37:09.630 --> 00:37:11.460
We appreciate you joining us.

713
00:37:11.460 --> 00:37:13.700
Signing out here,
I've been your host, Wes Bryan.

714
00:37:13.700 --> 00:37:14.650
>> And I'm Mike Rodrick.

715
00:37:14.650 --> 00:37:16.807
>> And we'll see you next time.

716
00:37:16.807 --> 00:37:22.810
[MUSIC]

717
00:37:22.810 --> 00:37:25.505
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Mike demonstrate controlling access to resource within a Windows environment through permissions. They look at NTFS and shared permissions as well as discussing the two permission set’s interaction with each other. They will also look at printer permissions that can be applied to shared printers within a network.
episodes.title: Windows Permissions
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.092 --> 00:00:06.717
Welcome to ITPro.TV,
I'm your host, Don Pezet.

2
00:00:06.717 --> 00:00:07.237
[CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:07.237 --> 00:00:08.311
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:08.311 --> 00:00:09.310
>> You're watching ITPro.TV.

5
00:00:11.710 --> 00:00:14.660
>> Welcome back to another
great episode here at ITPro.TV.

6
00:00:14.660 --> 00:00:16.203
I'm your host Wes Bryan, and

7
00:00:16.203 --> 00:00:20.421
in today's episode we are continuing
through our fundamental course.

8
00:00:20.421 --> 00:00:22.136
And joining us back in the studios for

9
00:00:22.136 --> 00:00:24.690
this very endeavor is none
other than Mr Mike Rodrick.

10
00:00:24.690 --> 00:00:25.589
Mike, how you doing, sir?

11
00:00:25.589 --> 00:00:27.200
>> Doing great, glad to be back.

12
00:00:27.200 --> 00:00:31.090
And we are moving on into the world of
Windows permissions in this particular

13
00:00:31.090 --> 00:00:31.650
episode.

14
00:00:31.650 --> 00:00:34.892
So we're gonna take a look at a few
things I wanna look at ntfs permissions,

15
00:00:34.892 --> 00:00:36.850
we wanna look at share permissions.

16
00:00:36.850 --> 00:00:40.162
We also wanna take a look at
active directory permissions,

17
00:00:40.162 --> 00:00:42.820
registry permissions and
print permissions.

18
00:00:42.820 --> 00:00:44.486
Well have a lot of permissions to go over.

19
00:00:44.486 --> 00:00:49.100
And let's start with the basics we're
gonna talk about ntfs permissions first.

20
00:00:50.290 --> 00:00:55.330
NTFS permissions are part of
the NTFS file system, all right.

21
00:00:55.330 --> 00:00:59.340
So when we format a volume as NTFS,
one of the things that we get,

22
00:00:59.340 --> 00:01:03.680
one of the advantages of using NTFS over,
say, FAT32 or

23
00:01:03.680 --> 00:01:08.800
some other file system, is the file and
folder level security that we get.

24
00:01:08.800 --> 00:01:14.680
That's the NTFS permissions that
we can assign over a resource.

25
00:01:14.680 --> 00:01:19.290
When you format a volume with NTFS,
every object on that volume

26
00:01:19.290 --> 00:01:23.180
gets what we call an access
control list associated with it.

27
00:01:23.180 --> 00:01:28.250
That access control list is where I list
the people that I want to give access,

28
00:01:28.250 --> 00:01:30.890
that's how I control access to the object,
right.

29
00:01:30.890 --> 00:01:33.770
Hence the name access control list.

30
00:01:33.770 --> 00:01:38.181
Now there are different access
models that we can use.

31
00:01:38.181 --> 00:01:44.295
So let's just real quick define NTFS
as a Discretionary Access Control List

32
00:01:44.295 --> 00:01:49.656
system or, what we call it DACL,
Discretionary Access Control.

33
00:01:49.656 --> 00:01:52.940
And then the list is
the actual list permissions.

34
00:01:52.940 --> 00:01:54.730
Versus, say, Mandatory Access Control.

35
00:01:54.730 --> 00:01:56.206
Let's contrast it with something else,

36
00:01:56.206 --> 00:02:00.370
so we understand what Mike's trying to
say here, Mandatory Access Control.

37
00:02:00.370 --> 00:02:06.980
Somebody is going to define who
should have access to this resource.

38
00:02:06.980 --> 00:02:11.770
And, let's say,
I create an object, a file.

39
00:02:11.770 --> 00:02:13.580
Somebody else would be responsible for
saying,

40
00:02:13.580 --> 00:02:16.900
hey that file is considered classified.

41
00:02:16.900 --> 00:02:20.540
And if a person trying to access it
doesn't have the appropriate level

42
00:02:20.540 --> 00:02:22.360
they're not gonna get access to it.

43
00:02:22.360 --> 00:02:26.441
Whereas, the discretionary is typically
at the discretion of the creator of

44
00:02:26.441 --> 00:02:27.142
the object.

45
00:02:27.142 --> 00:02:31.852
In other words, when I create a file,
I'm considered the creator

46
00:02:31.852 --> 00:02:36.070
owner of that file and
I can add remove people from the list.

47
00:02:36.070 --> 00:02:41.130
I can choose who I want to allow or deny,
or give read or write, or what have you.

48
00:02:41.130 --> 00:02:44.137
So, discretionary access control
is discretionary, meaning,

49
00:02:44.137 --> 00:02:46.187
at the discretion of
the owner of the object.

50
00:02:46.187 --> 00:02:50.308
Whereas mandatory access control, there's
typically a separate body that decides

51
00:02:50.308 --> 00:02:52.530
hey, we're gonna read your document.

52
00:02:52.530 --> 00:02:54.843
You've mentioned this and
this and this in here,

53
00:02:54.843 --> 00:02:56.672
it's gonna get stamped as top secret.

54
00:02:56.672 --> 00:02:59.940
You, the person that created it,
really had no control over that.

55
00:02:59.940 --> 00:03:02.560
I guess I did a little bit by
including that information,

56
00:03:02.560 --> 00:03:05.230
but you get the idea all right.

57
00:03:05.230 --> 00:03:06.650
So just terminology wise,

58
00:03:06.650 --> 00:03:10.056
understand that NDFS is based
on discretionary access control.

59
00:03:10.056 --> 00:03:13.213
>> You know, Mike, in one of
the other episodes in this course,

60
00:03:13.213 --> 00:03:16.091
you had mentioned a concept
of work groups and domains.

61
00:03:16.091 --> 00:03:19.792
And you mentioned authentication,
that was verifying who you are but

62
00:03:19.792 --> 00:03:21.933
you also taught us another concept too.

63
00:03:21.933 --> 00:03:24.790
You mentioned another
concept called authorization.

64
00:03:24.790 --> 00:03:28.447
Is that where we start to see
the concept of authorization here?

65
00:03:28.447 --> 00:03:29.180
>> It's absolutely.

66
00:03:29.180 --> 00:03:30.077
That's a great point.

67
00:03:30.077 --> 00:03:33.179
When I logged on to my system,
I authenticated it.

68
00:03:33.179 --> 00:03:37.540
I verified that I am Mike Roderick by
typing in the appropriate password.

69
00:03:37.540 --> 00:03:38.600
So I've been authenticated.

70
00:03:38.600 --> 00:03:41.070
The system now knows who I am.

71
00:03:41.070 --> 00:03:44.950
So when I go to access a resource,
it now has to authorize me.

72
00:03:44.950 --> 00:03:48.200
Should Mike be able to double
click on this file or not?

73
00:03:48.200 --> 00:03:52.316
If he is able to double click and
open that file, can he just read it,

74
00:03:52.316 --> 00:03:54.790
can he read and write, can he delete it?

75
00:03:54.790 --> 00:03:59.770
You know, that's the authorization part,
determining what level of access I have.

76
00:03:59.770 --> 00:04:02.834
Now that it knows who I am so
you are absolutely right,

77
00:04:02.834 --> 00:04:06.502
this is where we start getting
into the authorization phase.

78
00:04:06.502 --> 00:04:10.730
So a couple things I want us to be
familiar with about NTFS permission.

79
00:04:10.730 --> 00:04:13.285
First of all they're always checked,
always.

80
00:04:13.285 --> 00:04:16.035
Regardless and you might think
like duh shouldn't they be?

81
00:04:16.035 --> 00:04:17.005
Yes they should but

82
00:04:17.005 --> 00:04:19.915
we're gonna talk about another type of
permissions that aren't always check.

83
00:04:19.915 --> 00:04:21.331
So I wanna differentiate.

84
00:04:21.331 --> 00:04:25.624
NTFS permissions are always checked,
whether you are accessing a resource

85
00:04:25.624 --> 00:04:30.597
on your local machine, it's gonna verify
your identity or it's gonna authorize you.

86
00:04:30.597 --> 00:04:35.402
Whether you're going across the network,
you're gonna need

87
00:04:35.402 --> 00:04:40.487
the appropriate NTFS permission
over those resources all right?

88
00:04:40.487 --> 00:04:43.290
NTFS permissions are also accumulative.

89
00:04:43.290 --> 00:04:46.770
Now typically when we
assign NTFS provisions,

90
00:04:46.770 --> 00:04:51.123
a best practice is to assign
them to groups and not to users.

91
00:04:51.123 --> 00:04:53.170
But we're gonna save that for another day.

92
00:04:53.170 --> 00:04:57.060
That's really not something I think
we need to worry about right here.

93
00:04:57.060 --> 00:05:01.110
But what I want you to understand is
NTFS permissions are cumulative, and

94
00:05:01.110 --> 00:05:03.580
what that means is you get to add up

95
00:05:03.580 --> 00:05:06.150
all the permissions that
have been assigned to you.

96
00:05:06.150 --> 00:05:09.420
So let's say that you belong,
we were talking about this earlier,

97
00:05:09.420 --> 00:05:12.870
let's say you belong to
a group called sales.

98
00:05:12.870 --> 00:05:15.870
One of the cool things
about NTFS is that I can

99
00:05:15.870 --> 00:05:18.990
use groups to ease
the assignment of permissions.

100
00:05:18.990 --> 00:05:21.880
We'll take a little side track here
just for a second to talk about groups.

101
00:05:21.880 --> 00:05:24.175
Cuz let's say I have 30 sales people.

102
00:05:24.175 --> 00:05:27.545
And I've got a resource that I want all
my salespeople to be able to read this

103
00:05:27.545 --> 00:05:29.075
report, for example.

104
00:05:29.075 --> 00:05:33.825
Well I could add each one of those
salespeople to the access control list for

105
00:05:33.825 --> 00:05:34.925
that report.

106
00:05:34.925 --> 00:05:36.590
And I could give them all read permission.

107
00:05:36.590 --> 00:05:39.317
I'd have 30 of them,
that's be 30 people I'd have to add,

108
00:05:39.317 --> 00:05:41.780
giving them permissions one at a time.

109
00:05:41.780 --> 00:05:45.310
Or what I can do is I can create
a security group in active directory.

110
00:05:45.310 --> 00:05:47.060
And I can put all, and
lets say I call it sales,

111
00:05:47.060 --> 00:05:51.270
I can put all 30 sales
users in that group.

112
00:05:51.270 --> 00:05:54.030
Now I can go to the resources,
the report, and

113
00:05:54.030 --> 00:05:56.580
I can assign the permissions to the group.

114
00:05:56.580 --> 00:06:03.040
So one entry in my access control list,
that say sales group has read permissions.

115
00:06:03.040 --> 00:06:06.860
Now, anybody in that group
will get that permission,

116
00:06:06.860 --> 00:06:09.570
that read permission over that report.

117
00:06:09.570 --> 00:06:13.240
If I hire ten new sales people tomorrow, I
don't have to go modify the permissions on

118
00:06:13.240 --> 00:06:15.920
that report, I just need to make
sure I put them in that group,

119
00:06:15.920 --> 00:06:17.960
because the group already
has the permissions.

120
00:06:17.960 --> 00:06:20.940
If five of those people
leave the company tomorrow

121
00:06:20.940 --> 00:06:23.140
I don't have to go modify
the access control list.

122
00:06:23.140 --> 00:06:25.214
I just pull them out of that group,
they no longer have those permissions.

123
00:06:25.214 --> 00:06:26.704
Or, maybe they changed departments,

124
00:06:26.704 --> 00:06:29.370
and they shouldn't be able
to read that report anymore.

125
00:06:29.370 --> 00:06:32.310
I just pull them out of the group,
they no longer have those permissions.

126
00:06:32.310 --> 00:06:34.782
So, groups are typically the way to go.

127
00:06:34.782 --> 00:06:37.390
It is the best practice
in a Microsoft world.

128
00:06:37.390 --> 00:06:38.999
And, so, back to the cumulative thing.

129
00:06:40.080 --> 00:06:42.710
I might have one group for my sales users.

130
00:06:42.710 --> 00:06:44.590
But then I also have sales managers.

131
00:06:44.590 --> 00:06:47.360
And my managers need
to be able to do more.

132
00:06:47.360 --> 00:06:48.880
They need to read the report.

133
00:06:48.880 --> 00:06:51.270
But they also need to be
able to modify the report.

134
00:06:51.270 --> 00:06:53.770
So I need to give them say
let's say we wanna give them

135
00:06:53.770 --> 00:06:55.480
write permissions all right.

136
00:06:56.750 --> 00:06:59.560
As a sales manager I need
all the permissions that

137
00:06:59.560 --> 00:07:02.350
the sales users have plus some.

138
00:07:02.350 --> 00:07:03.650
So what I'm gonna do, is I'm gonna take,

139
00:07:03.650 --> 00:07:07.890
let's say Wes is my sales manager,
I can put Wes in that sales group.

140
00:07:07.890 --> 00:07:11.230
He'll get read permission from
belonging to that sales group.

141
00:07:11.230 --> 00:07:14.880
On the access control list I've got
another group called sales managers, and

142
00:07:14.880 --> 00:07:18.190
I'm gonna give the sales
managers group write permission.

143
00:07:18.190 --> 00:07:20.280
I'm gonna put Wes in both groups.

144
00:07:20.280 --> 00:07:26.600
Wes user account is now a member
of sales users and sales managers.

145
00:07:26.600 --> 00:07:29.120
So, Wes gets to add up
all the permissions.

146
00:07:29.120 --> 00:07:34.200
He'll get, say, he'll get read permission
from being part of the sales users group.

147
00:07:34.200 --> 00:07:37.860
He'll get write permission from being
part of the sales managers group.

148
00:07:37.860 --> 00:07:40.270
So, in the end,
Wes has read-write permissions.

149
00:07:40.270 --> 00:07:41.800
And that's what we mean by cumulative,

150
00:07:41.800 --> 00:07:46.050
you get to add up all the permissions
from the different groups you belong to.

151
00:07:46.050 --> 00:07:50.399
It's a cumulative affect, all right.

152
00:07:50.399 --> 00:07:53.058
Let's see what else, let's take
a look at an access control list.

153
00:07:53.058 --> 00:07:54.769
So we're just sitting
here talking about it.

154
00:07:54.769 --> 00:07:59.040
Let's take a look at my screen here and
I'm just gonna open up file explorer.

155
00:07:59.040 --> 00:08:03.069
I'll go to my C drive and
I'll make a new folder so

156
00:08:03.069 --> 00:08:06.030
I'll have somewhere to play with.

157
00:08:06.030 --> 00:08:09.890
We'll call this Test, and
I'll go inside there and

158
00:08:09.890 --> 00:08:15.150
I'll make a new document,
and I'll call it Report.

159
00:08:16.820 --> 00:08:21.024
And you know I'm gonna have to fix that
typo there cuz that's just the way I am,

160
00:08:21.024 --> 00:08:21.680
all right?

161
00:08:21.680 --> 00:08:24.660
Now I'm gonna right click on that
report and choose properties.

162
00:08:25.660 --> 00:08:29.870
And on the properties of this,
I'm gonna click on the security tab.

163
00:08:29.870 --> 00:08:34.970
The security tab, this is
the discretionary access control list.

164
00:08:34.970 --> 00:08:41.630
This is a list of all of the identities
that have permissions over this resource.

165
00:08:43.349 --> 00:08:44.470
Where was I gonna go with that?

166
00:08:44.470 --> 00:08:50.740
So each one of these is known as an ACE,
an access control entry, all right?

167
00:08:50.740 --> 00:08:54.570
So if I wanna assign permissions
to somebody, I can click Edit,

168
00:08:55.640 --> 00:09:02.900
I can click Add, I can find
Wes Bryan's user account and click OK.

169
00:09:02.900 --> 00:09:07.640
Now there's an ACE,
an access control entry, for Wes Bryan.

170
00:09:07.640 --> 00:09:11.510
Now I can control what access
he has over this resource

171
00:09:11.510 --> 00:09:13.900
by changing his NTFS permissions.

172
00:09:13.900 --> 00:09:16.071
Do I wanna give him full control or

173
00:09:16.071 --> 00:09:21.220
do I wanna give him just a read-permission
or read and write permission?

174
00:09:21.220 --> 00:09:24.072
What is it that I'm trying to assign or
do I wanna deny?

175
00:09:24.072 --> 00:09:28.662
I wanna give him read permission but
I wanna deny any write permission, right?

176
00:09:28.662 --> 00:09:34.941
We can allow, NTFS allows for, I shouldn't
use that word twice to define it,

177
00:09:34.941 --> 00:09:40.660
NTFS gives me the ability to allow or
deny access to a resource.

178
00:09:40.660 --> 00:09:42.510
Now one thing we should understand,
I'm gonna cancel.

179
00:09:42.510 --> 00:09:43.400
I'll just go ahead and leave.

180
00:09:43.400 --> 00:09:44.560
I don't wanna deny him there.

181
00:09:44.560 --> 00:09:45.432
We'll click OK.

182
00:09:45.432 --> 00:09:46.870
And so now, there we go.

183
00:09:46.870 --> 00:09:49.810
Wes Bryan has an entry and
it says he has read and

184
00:09:49.810 --> 00:09:52.240
write permissions over this report.

185
00:09:52.240 --> 00:09:57.380
So at my discretion, I created a file, I'm
able to go in and change the permissions.

186
00:09:57.380 --> 00:10:00.300
Now that can be taken away,
just as a side note.

187
00:10:00.300 --> 00:10:01.680
There are many times where,

188
00:10:01.680 --> 00:10:05.570
let's say, a user creates a document
that's important to my company.

189
00:10:05.570 --> 00:10:11.150
It's a, I don't know, they came up with
some spreadsheet that tracks sales and

190
00:10:11.150 --> 00:10:15.190
I don't want that particular user to
be in complete control over that.

191
00:10:15.190 --> 00:10:19.142
We can take ownership away, and maybe
assign it to the Domain Admins Group or

192
00:10:19.142 --> 00:10:21.753
something like that, so
that they can no longer.

193
00:10:21.753 --> 00:10:23.270
So maybe I don't want.

194
00:10:23.270 --> 00:10:25.400
Let's say Wes was the owner of the file.

195
00:10:25.400 --> 00:10:28.360
And I parked in Wes's
parking spot this morning.

196
00:10:28.360 --> 00:10:30.880
So in order to get back at me,
Wes went and

197
00:10:30.880 --> 00:10:33.960
took my permissions away over
resources that I need to do my job.

198
00:10:33.960 --> 00:10:37.860
Right, because he can if he was
the creator or owner of those resources.

199
00:10:37.860 --> 00:10:39.820
So there are times that we take that away.

200
00:10:39.820 --> 00:10:41.160
But just understand by default,

655
00:35:03.104 --> 00:35:06.810
permissions, is complexity
through granularity, for sure.

656
00:35:06.810 --> 00:35:08.880
>> [LAUGH]
>> But we're glad we got you here

657
00:35:08.880 --> 00:35:11.070
to help make it a little
easier to understand.

658
00:35:11.070 --> 00:35:13.990
Now judging by that time clock, it does
look like we're coming to the end of

659
00:35:13.990 --> 00:35:17.140
another episode, Mike, but before we do,
do you got any additional words of wisdom

660
00:35:17.140 --> 00:35:20.730
you might wanna impart to our viewers when
it comes to managing your permissions?

661
00:35:20.730 --> 00:35:25.360
>> The main thing is documentation is
very important when you're working

662
00:35:25.360 --> 00:35:29.030
with permissions, good documentation can
make troubleshooting so much easier.

663
00:35:29.030 --> 00:35:33.530
So document what you're doing and
then follow the best practices.

664
00:35:33.530 --> 00:35:35.130
Always assign permissions.

665
00:35:35.130 --> 00:35:36.090
Delegate permissions.

666
00:35:36.090 --> 00:35:38.480
Whatever it is you're doing to groups.

667
00:35:38.480 --> 00:35:43.810
And then control who has the permission
by changing the membership of the group.

668
00:35:43.810 --> 00:35:45.460
>> Well, words of wisdom from Mr.
Roderick.

669
00:35:45.460 --> 00:35:47.870
We appreciate you being
in the studios with us.

670
00:35:47.870 --> 00:35:49.870
We appreciate you, the viewer, watching.

671
00:35:49.870 --> 00:35:51.170
Signing out for ITProTV.

672
00:35:51.170 --> 00:35:53.030
I've been your host, Wes Brian.

673
00:35:53.030 --> 00:35:53.800
>> And I'm Mike Roderick.

674
00:35:53.800 --> 00:35:56.005
>> And we'll see you next time.

675
00:35:56.005 --> 00:36:02.124
[MUSIC]

676
00:36:02.124 --> 00:36:06.910
Thank you for watching ITPRO.TV

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Mike discuss concepts related to patch management of Windows-based systems through updates. They dive into the different components of updates such as service packs, hot fixes, automatic updates and the Windows Server Update Service also known as WSUS.
episodes.title: Windows Updates
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.240 --> 00:00:03.455
Welcome to ITPro.TV,
I'm your host, Don Pezet.

2
00:00:03.455 --> 00:00:06.796
>> [CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:06.796 --> 00:00:08.574
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:08.574 --> 00:00:11.740
>> You're watching ITPro.TV.

5
00:00:11.740 --> 00:00:14.480
>> Welcome to another great
episode here at ITPro.TV.

6
00:00:14.480 --> 00:00:15.520
I'm your host, Wes Bryan.

7
00:00:15.520 --> 00:00:17.184
And in today's episode,

8
00:00:17.184 --> 00:00:22.411
we're continuing through our GIAC Security
Fundamentals, also known as GIAC.

9
00:00:22.411 --> 00:00:23.323
And joining us in the studio for

10
00:00:23.323 --> 00:00:24.980
this endeavor It's none other than Mr.
Mike Rodrick.

11
00:00:24.980 --> 00:00:26.220
Mike how are you doing sir?

12
00:00:26.220 --> 00:00:26.900
>> Doing great Wes.

13
00:00:26.900 --> 00:00:27.870
Thanks for having me back.

14
00:00:27.870 --> 00:00:31.215
And in this episode we are gonna
be looking at Windows Updates,

15
00:00:31.215 --> 00:00:32.741
exciting stuff here right.

16
00:00:32.741 --> 00:00:37.400
You know and you might think well what
are we gonna learn about Windows updates.

17
00:00:37.400 --> 00:00:40.321
Most of you have run a Windows
operating system before,

18
00:00:40.321 --> 00:00:44.370
you're familiar with a Windows update,
you know what else is there.

19
00:00:44.370 --> 00:00:47.947
Well there's a couple of the things
that we need be familiar with for

20
00:00:47.947 --> 00:00:52.470
this exam especially and just for
managing an enterprise environment.

21
00:00:52.470 --> 00:00:57.250
So let's start with just
some terminology right?

22
00:00:57.250 --> 00:00:58.350
We know we have Windows updates.

23
00:00:58.350 --> 00:01:01.528
But there's actually different
classifications of updates.

24
00:01:01.528 --> 00:01:03.440
And you might or
might not be familiar with this.

25
00:01:03.440 --> 00:01:07.940
You've got things like hot fixes and
service packs, and

26
00:01:07.940 --> 00:01:11.200
tools, and updates, and patches.

27
00:01:11.200 --> 00:01:14.345
All these different terms, they're all
referring to the same thing or no.

28
00:01:14.345 --> 00:01:16.700
They're actually not, right?

29
00:01:16.700 --> 00:01:19.027
People try to use the terms
interchangeably sometimes or

30
00:01:19.027 --> 00:01:21.122
we just say blanket,
you know, Windows updates.

31
00:01:21.122 --> 00:01:24.640
And, does it matter to us?

32
00:01:24.640 --> 00:01:26.650
Yes and no.

33
00:01:26.650 --> 00:01:30.234
No in the fact that we want to
get our Windows updates and, but

34
00:01:30.234 --> 00:01:34.473
yes in the fact that we might put
a priority on some updates over others.

35
00:01:34.473 --> 00:01:38.241
By getting those critical secure or
security related updates are gonna be more

36
00:01:38.241 --> 00:01:42.150
important than maybe rolling out a service
back that extends functionality.

37
00:01:42.150 --> 00:01:44.790
So, first let's define
the different classifications.

38
00:01:44.790 --> 00:01:45.483
And let's take a look at my screen.

39
00:01:45.483 --> 00:01:49.307
I actually browsed out to a Microsoft
site here, and description

40
00:01:49.307 --> 00:01:54.710
of the standard terminology that is used
to describe Microsoft software updates.

41
00:01:54.710 --> 00:01:56.496
Where better to get the information
than from Microsoft.

42
00:01:56.496 --> 00:02:00.470
And we see here a critical update.

43
00:02:00.470 --> 00:02:01.846
Widely released fix for

44
00:02:01.846 --> 00:02:06.820
a specific problem that addresses
a critical non-security related update.

45
00:02:06.820 --> 00:02:07.334
That's the key there.

46
00:02:07.334 --> 00:02:09.560
You think, critical, that's security.

47
00:02:09.560 --> 00:02:10.970
It's actually not.

48
00:02:10.970 --> 00:02:13.229
It's an important update,
a specific problem.

49
00:02:13.229 --> 00:02:14.580
It's a critical problem.

50
00:02:14.580 --> 00:02:16.460
But it's not security related.

51
00:02:16.460 --> 00:02:20.000
We have a different classification for
security related updates.

52
00:02:20.000 --> 00:02:23.330
And that would be our
security updates all right.

53
00:02:23.330 --> 00:02:24.790
We also have definition updates.

54
00:02:24.790 --> 00:02:27.800
Because now we get our
Windows definitions, or

55
00:02:27.800 --> 00:02:31.220
sorry our Windows definitions,
our Windows defender.

56
00:02:31.220 --> 00:02:33.670
Definitions through Windows update for

57
00:02:33.670 --> 00:02:39.310
our anti malware suite that's built into
Microsoft operating systems nowadays.

58
00:02:39.310 --> 00:02:43.750
We've got service packs,
tested cumulative set of all hot fixes,

59
00:02:43.750 --> 00:02:46.975
security updates, critical updates,
and updates, right.

60
00:02:46.975 --> 00:02:50.803
When they say it's accumulative,
that means as we go through time,

61
00:02:50.803 --> 00:02:55.102
they're releasing hot fixes and
critical updates, and security updates.

62
00:02:55.102 --> 00:02:58.582
And then it comes to the point where they
say, you know what, we're gonna take

63
00:02:58.582 --> 00:03:02.303
everything we released over the last few
months, or however long of a time period.

64
00:03:02.303 --> 00:03:04.420
And we're gonna roll it
up in to a service pack.

65
00:03:04.420 --> 00:03:08.183
All right, and then you can get that one
service pack instead of getting hundreds

66
00:03:08.183 --> 00:03:09.745
of individual updates, right?

67
00:03:09.745 --> 00:03:13.830
So if I go and
install a fresh copy of Windows 10.

68
00:03:13.830 --> 00:03:15.000
Well it's been out for a while.

69
00:03:15.000 --> 00:03:15.840
Or I shouldn't use Windows 10.

70
00:03:15.840 --> 00:03:16.607
I don't think there's a service pack yet
for it.

71
00:03:16.607 --> 00:03:20.080
But maybe for Windows 8, right?

72
00:03:20.080 --> 00:03:22.910
There's probably a service pack
I can go get that would include

73
00:03:22.910 --> 00:03:27.540
all the updates that have occurred
over the past several months or

74
00:03:27.540 --> 00:03:29.520
whatever again that time period might be.

75
00:03:29.520 --> 00:03:34.460
So just service packs roll everything
up into one convenient bundle.

76
00:03:34.460 --> 00:03:37.990
Although service packs can
also include new features.

77
00:03:37.990 --> 00:03:40.260
Not only can they update and
patch existing features,

78
00:03:40.260 --> 00:03:44.440
include all the hot fixes and
updates that have come out over time, but

79
00:03:44.440 --> 00:03:47.730
they can also actually
introduce new features.

80
00:03:47.730 --> 00:03:51.540
One that pops into mind is
Windows XP Service Pack, was it three,

81
00:03:51.540 --> 00:03:53.610
Wes, that did the firewall?

82
00:03:53.610 --> 00:03:55.851
>> I want to say that it was
service pack two, yeah a major,

83
00:03:55.851 --> 00:03:58.022
major advancement in
the Windows operating system.

84
00:03:58.022 --> 00:04:01.136
>> Yeah, it actually a lot of
the functionality of Windows itself.

85
00:04:01.136 --> 00:04:02.386
It introduced a firewall.

86
00:04:02.386 --> 00:04:07.279
It might have been service pack three that
introduced IPv6 support with Windows XP.

87
00:04:07.279 --> 00:04:08.760
>> It's funny that you said that.

88
00:04:08.760 --> 00:04:11.510
You just brought Flash back.

89
00:04:11.510 --> 00:04:14.120
I remember prior to
service pack two in XP,

90
00:04:14.120 --> 00:04:18.989
having to install a firewall like zone
alarm there, so talk about a flashback.

91
00:04:18.989 --> 00:04:20.250
>> Yeah, exactly.

92
00:04:20.250 --> 00:04:24.605
So service packs not only roll
up all the recent updates

93
00:04:24.605 --> 00:04:27.765
that have come out they can
introduce new features as well.

94
00:04:27.765 --> 00:04:31.604
Which then of course is going to actually
turn into another round of updates later

95
00:04:31.604 --> 00:04:34.715
on for those new features, but
hey that's just the way it works.

96
00:04:34.715 --> 00:04:39.413
And there are some other ones,
they talk about tools, the utility,

97
00:04:39.413 --> 00:04:45.094
your feature, the completed task and
update a widely released specific problem.

98
00:04:45.094 --> 00:04:49.110
They're not gonna quiz you on
every single classification.

99
00:04:49.110 --> 00:04:51.870
I just wanted to point out that there
are different classifications for

100
00:04:51.870 --> 00:04:53.030
these updates and

101
00:04:53.030 --> 00:04:58.120
usually we really focus in on the security
related updates and the critical updates.

102
00:04:58.120 --> 00:05:03.346
The other ones we might be a little
slower to deploy all right?

103
00:05:03.346 --> 00:05:06.195
All right so that's our classification.

104
00:05:06.195 --> 00:05:10.292
Now with Windows updates we'll
probably understand that our machines

105
00:05:10.292 --> 00:05:11.930
are configured by default,

106
00:05:11.930 --> 00:05:16.448
if we don't do anything to go out to
Microsoft servers every night at three am.

107
00:05:16.448 --> 00:05:18.405
And look for updates.

108
00:05:18.405 --> 00:05:23.415
It reports in what operating system it's
running and what updates it already has.

109
00:05:23.415 --> 00:05:26.655
It scans to see what updates
are available based on the OS.

110
00:05:26.655 --> 00:05:30.280
And possibly even applications you're
running if you're getting updates for

111
00:05:30.280 --> 00:05:33.210
Office and Internet Explorer and
things like that.

112
00:05:33.210 --> 00:05:36.940
And then the server reports back these
updates are available, and then depending

113
00:05:36.940 --> 00:05:41.410
on your settings on your machine it might
download and install them automatically.

114
00:05:41.410 --> 00:05:43.790
It might just download them and
then you can go in and

115
00:05:43.790 --> 00:05:46.400
install them whenever you need to.

116
00:05:46.400 --> 00:05:50.110
Or it might just tell you that there's
updates available, but not download them.

117
00:05:50.110 --> 00:05:53.390
And let you decide when to download them,
and when to install them.

118
00:05:53.390 --> 00:05:54.250
Or it might not check at all.

119
00:05:54.250 --> 00:05:59.530
You can configure your machine to not
check for Windows updates at all right?

120
00:05:59.530 --> 00:06:01.640
Definitely not a good idea.

121
00:06:01.640 --> 00:06:02.980
We wanna get those updates.

122
00:06:02.980 --> 00:06:04.900
Those updates are put out for a reason.

123
00:06:04.900 --> 00:06:06.170
Something is broke, or

124
00:06:06.170 --> 00:06:08.990
something has been discovered that
somebody can take advantage of.

125
00:06:08.990 --> 00:06:12.380
And possibly compromise your machine,
gain access to your machine,

126
00:06:12.380 --> 00:06:14.180
gain access to your information.

127
00:06:14.180 --> 00:06:15.069
We want those things applied.

128
00:06:15.069 --> 00:06:17.960
We really want them as
soon as we can all right?

129
00:06:17.960 --> 00:06:22.210
So on our home systems, and in small
corporate environments where we're not

130
00:06:22.210 --> 00:06:26.850
centrally managed you know just allowing
those machines individually go out to

131
00:06:26.850 --> 00:06:31.600
Microsoft and get those updates
is probably just fine all right?

132
00:06:31.600 --> 00:06:32.770
Or it is just fine and

133
00:06:32.770 --> 00:06:35.150
we should definitively make
sure we're doing that but

134
00:06:35.150 --> 00:06:38.800
when we get into a corporate environment,
the game changes just a little bit.

135
00:06:40.160 --> 00:06:44.550
When we're dealing with many,
many clients, many, many servers.

136
00:06:44.550 --> 00:06:47.480
You know, most updates are tested,
all updates, I should say,

137
00:06:47.480 --> 00:06:50.040
are tested by Microsoft and
they're vetted.

138
00:06:50.040 --> 00:06:53.820
They're making sure that they're not
going to cause any problems before

139
00:06:53.820 --> 00:06:54.930
they're released.

140
00:06:54.930 --> 00:06:57.520
But the truth of the matter is,
is sometimes they still do,

141
00:06:57.520 --> 00:07:02.150
and that's because Microsoft cannot test
every possible combination of hardware and

142
00:07:02.150 --> 00:07:03.110
software.

143
00:07:03.110 --> 00:07:06.432
That people might be running and
occasionally an update comes out and

144
00:07:06.432 --> 00:07:09.924
it causes a problem with a line of
business application that your company

145
00:07:09.924 --> 00:07:10.679
custom wrote.

146
00:07:10.679 --> 00:07:12.296
Or had written for them or

147
00:07:12.296 --> 00:07:17.010
some combination of software just
causes a problem, all right.

148
00:07:17.010 --> 00:07:21.340
So what we run into in
a corporate environment is I

149
00:07:21.340 --> 00:07:25.180
need to be a little more careful with
my application of these updates.

150
00:07:25.180 --> 00:07:28.790
And what I mean is I really need
to be able to test these updates

151
00:07:28.790 --> 00:07:30.370
before I roll them out.

152
00:07:30.370 --> 00:07:33.780
Because what I don’t want to
happen is come in one morning and

153
00:07:33.780 --> 00:07:38.260
find out that 90% of the clients
on my network are blue streamed.

154
00:07:38.260 --> 00:07:41.380
Because some update came out last night,
got automatically installed and

155
00:07:41.380 --> 00:07:44.697
is now causing a problem with some line
of business application that we happen to

156
00:07:44.697 --> 00:07:45.257
be running.

157
00:07:45.257 --> 00:07:48.371
And Microsoft's not able to test,
and now we've got a problem.

158
00:07:48.371 --> 00:07:53.290
All of a sudden, we're scrambling to get
these back online, to get them fixed.

159
00:07:53.290 --> 00:07:55.609
Or worse, our servers are having issues.

160
00:07:55.609 --> 00:07:59.316
And nobody can connect to them because
of some problem from an update.

161
00:07:59.316 --> 00:08:03.769
So ideally, we'd be able to test these
updates before we allow them to be

162
00:08:03.769 --> 00:08:06.839
deployed to the machines on our network,
right?

163
00:08:06.839 --> 00:08:10.780
And that's not to say that a small shop
can't do this as well, don't get me wrong.

164
00:08:10.780 --> 00:08:15.120
But in a small shop, I've only got three
computers, little easier to deal with than

165
00:08:15.120 --> 00:08:18.860
if I had thousands of computers that
are going through this problem, all right?

166
00:08:18.860 --> 00:08:19.810
So, what is the solution?

167
00:08:21.100 --> 00:08:23.990
Well, it's called
Windows Server Update Services, right?

168
00:08:23.990 --> 00:08:28.560
It's actually a role that I can
install on a Windows Server

169
00:08:28.560 --> 00:08:32.420
that will allow me to do just that,
to test updates and

170
00:08:32.420 --> 00:08:37.870
control the issuing or
the application of these updates.

171
00:08:37.870 --> 00:08:40.260
The best part is, is it's free, I mean,

172
00:08:40.260 --> 00:08:43.910
you've already bought your server license
obviously, so that cost you some money.

173
00:08:43.910 --> 00:08:46.880
But this is just a role you're
gonna install, just like DNS or

174
00:08:46.880 --> 00:08:48.410
Active Directory, or DHCP.

175
00:08:48.410 --> 00:08:52.600
And it's gonna give you complete
control over that update process.

176
00:08:52.600 --> 00:08:54.980
Fantastic, I don't know why anybody,

177
00:08:54.980 --> 00:08:59.020
every organization, honestly in my
opinion, should be running WSUS.

178
00:08:59.020 --> 00:09:02.170
That's just one of those
things that we need to do.

179
00:09:02.170 --> 00:09:06.350
All right, so let's talk about the whole
Windows Server Updates Services.

180
00:09:06.350 --> 00:09:10.150
First thing I wanna do is
kinda give you an overview

181
00:09:11.190 --> 00:09:14.630
of really what it's doing,
where it sits in our network.

182
00:09:14.630 --> 00:09:17.460
So let's take a look at my screen here,
and I've got a little diagram.

183
00:09:17.460 --> 00:09:20.030
I'll try to zoom in
just a little bit here.

184
00:09:21.230 --> 00:09:23.180
Where's zoom on this guy?

185
00:09:23.180 --> 00:09:27.350
There we go.
I'll make that a little bit bigger, so

186
00:09:27.350 --> 00:09:27.900
we can see it.

187
00:09:27.900 --> 00:09:30.790
So, out in the internet,
out there in Microsoft's networks,

188
00:09:30.790 --> 00:09:33.260
they've got their
Microsoft Update Servers.

189
00:09:33.260 --> 00:09:36.780
And, what's gonna happen is
we're gonna set up our own,

190
00:09:36.780 --> 00:09:40.750
what we call a WSUS server,
Windows Server Update Services server.

191
00:09:40.750 --> 00:09:42.440
We install that role on there.

192
00:09:42.440 --> 00:09:45.660
And that server is gonna
reach out to Microsoft and

193
00:09:45.660 --> 00:09:51.170
download the updates and store them
locally here on that WSUS server.

194
00:09:51.170 --> 00:09:54.660
And then my clients are not
gonna go talk to Microsoft.

195
00:09:54.660 --> 00:09:58.480
They're gonna talk to my server and
they're gonna get the updates from there.

196
00:09:58.480 --> 00:10:01.790
And what this allows me
to do is to kinda stop

197
00:10:01.790 --> 00:10:06.530
the process right here at the WSUS server,
and I can choose to approve or

198
00:10:06.530 --> 00:10:09.950
not approve these updates for
the client machines back here.

199
00:10:09.950 --> 00:10:13.330
So I now have control over
the updates that are gonna

200
00:10:13.330 --> 00:10:15.420
be applied to the machines in my network.

201
00:10:15.420 --> 00:10:20.120
The other cool thing about WSUS
is it allows me to create groups.

202
00:10:20.120 --> 00:10:22.360
Now these are independent
from Active Directory groups,

203
00:10:22.360 --> 00:10:25.030
they have nothing to do with my
security groups I would create there.

204
00:10:25.030 --> 00:10:28.390
These are groups that
are only used within WSUS.

205
00:10:28.390 --> 00:10:32.130
But I can create a group of,
let's say, my test computers, right?

206
00:10:32.130 --> 00:10:35.590
I can pick a few machines on my network,
call them my canaries,

207
00:10:35.590 --> 00:10:37.040
my little test group.

208
00:10:37.040 --> 00:10:41.380
And when an update comes in,
I can approve the update, but only for

209
00:10:41.380 --> 00:10:43.380
those five test computers.

210
00:10:43.380 --> 00:10:44.920
Let those computers run for a day.

00:22:59.330 --> 00:23:03.580
So when you configure settings through
group policy, it locks the user interface.

440
00:23:03.580 --> 00:23:06.860
Even an admin can't change that setting.

441
00:23:06.860 --> 00:23:10.807
The only way to change it is to come
back through group policy and change it,

442
00:23:10.807 --> 00:23:11.450
all right?

443
00:23:11.450 --> 00:23:13.960
So it's fantastic,
we do love that as administrators.

444
00:23:13.960 --> 00:23:16.824
But anyway, so
I'm going to turn on updates and

445
00:23:16.824 --> 00:23:21.490
I'll just do automatically download and
install and I'll click OK.

446
00:23:21.490 --> 00:23:24.360
So all that's doing is making sure
that my clients and my servers for

447
00:23:24.360 --> 00:23:26.260
that matter if I apply this to them,

448
00:23:26.260 --> 00:23:29.860
are gonna be automatically getting
their updates every night at 3 AM.

449
00:23:29.860 --> 00:23:33.480
Then we're gonna double-click on Specify,

450
00:23:33.480 --> 00:23:38.530
if I can say that, Intranet
Microsoft Update Service Location.

451
00:23:38.530 --> 00:23:39.330
I'll double-click on that, right?

452
00:23:41.310 --> 00:23:42.710
And I'm gonna enable it.

453
00:23:42.710 --> 00:23:43.740
I'm choosing Enable.

454
00:23:43.740 --> 00:23:46.070
I know that's small,
let me zoom in for just a second.

455
00:23:46.070 --> 00:23:47.380
I'm gonna enable it.

456
00:23:47.380 --> 00:23:48.620
And then I got two options there.

457
00:23:48.620 --> 00:23:52.160
Set the intranet update service for
detecting updates.

458
00:23:52.160 --> 00:23:53.920
Set the intranet statistic service.

459
00:23:54.940 --> 00:23:56.740
This is all HTTP based or

460
00:23:56.740 --> 00:24:02.784
HTTPS depending on whether you've set it
up to use secure socket layers or SSL.

461
00:24:02.784 --> 00:24:07.568
So on my WSUS server there is actually
a web interface that these clients end up

462
00:24:07.568 --> 00:24:08.608
connecting to.

463
00:24:08.608 --> 00:24:12.388
So you're gonna give them the URL for
your Update server.

464
00:24:12.388 --> 00:24:13.805
Let me zoom back out.

465
00:24:13.805 --> 00:24:18.143
And in my case, that's gonna be

466
00:24:18.143 --> 00:24:24.094
http://svro1.lab.itpro.tv: and

467
00:24:24.094 --> 00:24:26.995
you know what, Wes?

468
00:24:26.995 --> 00:24:29.335
I forgot my default port number.

469
00:24:29.335 --> 00:24:34.347
So let's go back and
check my options here on that one.

470
00:24:34.347 --> 00:24:40.217
[SOUND] And
let's check my configuration wizard.

471
00:24:40.217 --> 00:24:44.171
And remember what my default
port number is 8530.

472
00:24:44.171 --> 00:24:46.342
Brain cramp there for a second.

473
00:24:46.342 --> 00:24:48.391
Something you can definitely change.

474
00:24:48.391 --> 00:24:54.144
But the default port number is 8530 for
WSUS, so 8530.

475
00:24:54.144 --> 00:24:56.200
The difference between these two,

476
00:24:56.200 --> 00:24:59.290
the first one is what machine
do I go to get my updates?

477
00:24:59.290 --> 00:25:02.100
To check to see if there's updates and
pull them down if there are.

478
00:25:02.100 --> 00:25:05.450
The second one is,
who do I report back to just say hey,

479
00:25:05.450 --> 00:25:07.030
these are the updates I've got.

480
00:25:07.030 --> 00:25:09.000
These are the updates I don't have.

481
00:25:09.000 --> 00:25:12.330
I successfully installed this one,
whatever the case may be.

482
00:25:12.330 --> 00:25:16.920
I have one server, so
they're both gonna be the same URL.

483
00:25:16.920 --> 00:25:22.009
You might have it in a large environment,
WSUS servers at each branch office,

484
00:25:22.009 --> 00:25:25.790
so they can pull the updates
from a local WSUS server.

485
00:25:25.790 --> 00:25:29.678
But you might want them all reporting back
to a central one in your corporate office,

486
00:25:29.678 --> 00:25:33.074
so you can run reports every morning
to see how many nodes successfully got

487
00:25:33.074 --> 00:25:34.918
their updates, and things like that.

488
00:25:34.918 --> 00:25:36.976
I'll do

489
00:25:36.976 --> 00:25:46.980
svro1.lab.itpro.tv:8530.

490
00:25:46.980 --> 00:25:49.800
And then I'll go ahead and
click OK, all right?

491
00:25:49.800 --> 00:25:52.200
So we've got two configured so far.

492
00:25:52.200 --> 00:25:54.410
One, turning on automatic updates.

493
00:25:54.410 --> 00:25:58.410
Two, telling them where
the local update server is.

494
00:25:58.410 --> 00:26:01.983
And then the third one,

495
00:26:01.983 --> 00:26:08.065
if I can find it here,
[SOUND] where is it?

496
00:26:08.065 --> 00:26:12.220
You might or might not use is enable
client side targeting, right?

497
00:26:12.220 --> 00:26:16.970
Remember I said we created the groups
like test and sales and marketing.

498
00:26:16.970 --> 00:26:20.040
Well, how do my computers
know what group they're in?

499
00:26:20.040 --> 00:26:21.735
There's two ways you can do this.

500
00:26:21.735 --> 00:26:24.475
You can do it in the WSUS console.

501
00:26:24.475 --> 00:26:29.443
When the computer first reports in,
and he knows how to do that because of

502
00:26:29.443 --> 00:26:33.630
that setting we just configured,
HTTP svro1:8530.

503
00:26:33.630 --> 00:26:36.690
It's gonna show up under what's called un,

504
00:26:36.690 --> 00:26:41.170
let's just look at that there,
unassigned computers, right?

505
00:26:41.170 --> 00:26:44.420
When we look at these groups, there's
a group called Unassigned Computers.

506
00:26:44.420 --> 00:26:45.890
All computers start there,

507
00:26:45.890 --> 00:26:50.136
and then what would happen is I would see
them listed out here in the details area.

508
00:26:50.136 --> 00:26:52.821
I'd right-click on one,
choose Add to Group, and

509
00:26:52.821 --> 00:26:56.372
I could move it to the test
computer's group, for example, right.

510
00:26:56.372 --> 00:26:58.690
So that's a very manual process.

511
00:26:58.690 --> 00:27:02.890
The other way to do it is to
use client side targeting.

512
00:27:02.890 --> 00:27:08.240
We can actually create a policy that says,
if this policy applies to you,

513
00:27:08.240 --> 00:27:14.550
I wanna put you in the test
computer's group, all right?

514
00:27:14.550 --> 00:27:15.660
And I could click OK.

515
00:27:15.660 --> 00:27:18.570
So now when this policy applies,
they'll automatically,

516
00:27:18.570 --> 00:27:22.130
when they go reporting into WSUS, they'll
say, by the way, I'm in the test group.

517
00:27:22.130 --> 00:27:23.940
And it'll put them in
the appropriate group.

518
00:27:23.940 --> 00:27:28.130
So a little more automated process there
of assigning those machines to the groups.

519
00:27:28.130 --> 00:27:32.470
Now in my case, if you're paying
attention, don't write into my forums.

520
00:27:32.470 --> 00:27:35.290
I know that I link this to
the domain itself and so

521
00:27:35.290 --> 00:27:38.660
every machine in my network is now
gonna be part of the test group.

522
00:27:38.660 --> 00:27:41.550
That would not be a good scenario, okay.

523
00:27:41.550 --> 00:27:44.630
I just wanted to show you
that configuration option.

524
00:27:44.630 --> 00:27:46.700
You would make individual policies.

525
00:27:46.700 --> 00:27:50.760
You would go to the OU that contain the
sales computers and you'd make a policy

526
00:27:50.760 --> 00:27:54.360
there, turn on updates, tell them
where their update server was, and

527
00:27:54.360 --> 00:27:57.220
put them in that sales group
using client side targeting.

528
00:27:57.220 --> 00:28:00.120
Then you go to the marketing OU and
you do the same thing.

529
00:28:00.120 --> 00:28:03.200
Make a policy that told them to
turn on their automatic updates,

530
00:28:03.200 --> 00:28:05.290
where to go to get them, and
put them in the marketing area.

531
00:28:05.290 --> 00:28:08.640
You'd have several policies to assign

532
00:28:08.640 --> 00:28:12.040
these computers to the different
groups within WSUS.

533
00:28:12.040 --> 00:28:14.660
But those are the three policies
you need to be familiar with.

534
00:28:14.660 --> 00:28:17.658
There are others as you can
see here that you might or

535
00:28:17.658 --> 00:28:22.121
might not use in your environment, but
those are the big three that we need to

536
00:28:22.121 --> 00:28:25.229
use to configure
Windows Server Updates Services.

537
00:28:25.229 --> 00:28:30.729
Now Wes, I swore there was one more thing
that I wanted to say about WSUS but

538
00:28:30.729 --> 00:28:34.930
I can't think of it now so
I must of covered it all.

539
00:28:34.930 --> 00:28:37.406
>> Yeah, we call that sometimers,
sometimes I remember,

540
00:28:37.406 --> 00:28:38.705
sometimes I forget for sure.

541
00:28:38.705 --> 00:28:40.490
>> [LAUGH]
>> Now that's a lot of great information

542
00:28:40.490 --> 00:28:42.910
when it comes to updates and
just patch management in general,

543
00:28:42.910 --> 00:28:45.297
making sure that your computers are up and
running smoothly.

544
00:28:45.297 --> 00:28:48.163
And making sure that they don't have
any security vulnerabilities in them.

545
00:28:48.163 --> 00:28:52.265
So definitely take Mike's advice,
keep those machines patched.

546
00:28:52.265 --> 00:28:56.047
Now Mike it does look like we're coming
to the end of another episode, but

547
00:28:56.047 --> 00:28:58.975
before we do, do you have any
additional advice you might

548
00:28:58.975 --> 00:29:02.097
like to give on just the overall
Windows update experience?

549
00:29:02.097 --> 00:29:05.288
>> Yeah, just the importance
of getting the updates.

550
00:29:05.288 --> 00:29:06.884
You hear stories and people say,

551
00:29:06.884 --> 00:29:10.740
well your computer will run better if
you actually don't go get updates.

552
00:29:10.740 --> 00:29:12.350
Don't believe that hooey.

553
00:29:12.350 --> 00:29:15.490
Make sure you're getting your updates,
at least the critical and

554
00:29:15.490 --> 00:29:17.012
the security related updates.

555
00:29:17.012 --> 00:29:18.740
The feature updates and
things like that, okay, yeah,

556
00:29:18.740 --> 00:29:19.800
you might be able to put that off.

557
00:29:19.800 --> 00:29:22.780
But those security updates, I mean,
when they've put out a security update,

558
00:29:22.780 --> 00:29:25.135
that's because they have found a flaw.

559
00:29:25.135 --> 00:29:29.670
Somebody, either the companies they pay
to test their products and report back to

560
00:29:29.670 --> 00:29:34.460
them, or they've found a serious
problem that could lead to compromise.

561
00:29:34.460 --> 00:29:39.820
And you don't want to be running around,
that's like running around vulnerable

562
00:29:39.820 --> 00:29:44.370
to chicken pox when there's a vaccine I
can go get to protect me from chicken pox.

563
00:29:44.370 --> 00:29:46.180
I mean, why would you do that, right?

564
00:29:46.180 --> 00:29:47.090
It's the same thing here.

565
00:29:47.090 --> 00:29:51.660
Why would you run around vulnerable to
some buffer overflow attack, when it would

566
00:29:51.660 --> 00:29:54.940
take one update, and you would no
longer be vulnerable to that attack?

567
00:29:54.940 --> 00:29:56.175
So, get your updates.

568
00:29:56.175 --> 00:29:58.879
[LAUGH]
>> I was gonna say, Mike Rodrick,

569
00:29:58.879 --> 00:30:03.160
the urban Windows update urban
legend debunker, for sure.

570
00:30:03.160 --> 00:30:06.150
Well, Mike, that's a great
place to go ahead and wrap up.

571
00:30:06.150 --> 00:30:09.390
We do appreciate you being in the studio
with us and we appreciate you,

572
00:30:09.390 --> 00:30:10.240
the viewer, watching.

573
00:30:10.240 --> 00:30:13.380
Signing out for ITProTV,
I've been your host, Wes Bryan.

574
00:30:13.380 --> 00:30:14.303
>> And I'm Mike Rodrick.

575
00:30:14.303 --> 00:30:16.864
>> And we'll see you next time.

576
00:30:16.864 --> 00:30:22.886
[MUSIC]

577
00:30:22.886 --> 00:30:26.207
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: In this episode Wes and Mike look at the various concepts surrounding maintaining Windows systems . They explain the overall backup process as well as demonstrate that process through the Windows Server Backup tool. They explore the importance of system state information and backup types.
episodes.title: Windows Backup and Restore
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.030 --> 00:00:02.530
Welcome to ITProTV,
I'm your host, Don Pezet.

2
00:00:02.530 --> 00:00:06.423
>> [CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:06.423 --> 00:00:08.306
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:08.306 --> 00:00:11.997
>> You're watching ITProTV.

5
00:00:11.997 --> 00:00:14.755
>> Welcome to another great
episode here at ITProTV.

6
00:00:14.755 --> 00:00:16.141
I'm your host, Wes Bryan.

7
00:00:16.141 --> 00:00:20.250
And in today's episode, we are continuing
through our GIACGSEC Security Essentials.

8
00:00:20.250 --> 00:00:21.800
And joining me back in the studios for

9
00:00:21.800 --> 00:00:24.340
this very endeavor is none
other than Mr Mike Rodrick.

10
00:00:24.340 --> 00:00:25.290
Mike, how you doing, sir?

11
00:00:25.290 --> 00:00:27.500
>> I'm doing great,
thanks for having me back.

12
00:00:27.500 --> 00:00:31.685
And yep,
we are continuing on with our GIACGSEC.

13
00:00:31.685 --> 00:00:34.160
Again this episode,
we're gonna be looking at Windows.

14
00:00:34.160 --> 00:00:37.640
And in particular,
we're gonna be looking at backup and

15
00:00:37.640 --> 00:00:40.320
restore, talk a little bit about that.

16
00:00:40.320 --> 00:00:41.570
Obviously important stuff.

17
00:00:41.570 --> 00:00:45.240
We're gonna need to make sure
that we're taking good backups,

18
00:00:45.240 --> 00:00:50.230
understand what our backups are, and
that we can restore those backups, right?

19
00:00:50.230 --> 00:00:53.540
It's all about disaster recovery and
preventing or

20
00:00:53.540 --> 00:00:58.740
being able to recover in
the event of some type of failure.

21
00:00:58.740 --> 00:01:02.120
So let's start with talking about backup.

22
00:01:02.120 --> 00:01:06.167
And in general we should understand
the concept of backing up our data,

23
00:01:06.167 --> 00:01:07.995
especially our critical data.

24
00:01:07.995 --> 00:01:11.319
This is something that
an organization has to go through and

25
00:01:11.319 --> 00:01:16.250
determine what type of backup strategy we
need to use for different sets of data.

26
00:01:16.250 --> 00:01:20.280
Typically involves data classification,
which we talk about in another episode

27
00:01:20.280 --> 00:01:23.730
because some data I need
to back up once in a while.

28
00:01:23.730 --> 00:01:28.883
If it's archived data, for example, if
it's data that we use to generate reports,

29
00:01:28.883 --> 00:01:32.833
last year's sales, the year before sales,
before that sales.

30
00:01:32.833 --> 00:01:36.827
That kind of information obviously very
important that we keep, we maintain, but

31
00:01:36.827 --> 00:01:38.630
it's not changing.

32
00:01:38.630 --> 00:01:42.800
So as long as I've got a backup of it,
I don't need to take one everyday,

33
00:01:42.800 --> 00:01:45.750
because the backup I take today is
gonna be exactly the same as the backup

34
00:01:45.750 --> 00:01:49.420
I took yesterday, which is exactly
the same as the backup I took last week.

35
00:01:49.420 --> 00:01:54.770
Right, so if it's not changing a lot,
we don't need to back up as frequently.

36
00:01:54.770 --> 00:01:58.400
We just need to make sure we've got a good
backup, and that it's stored properly.

37
00:01:58.400 --> 00:02:02.030
Typically two copies,
one on site, one off site,

38
00:02:02.030 --> 00:02:07.900
in the event of a disaster of some kind,
fire, hurricane, things like that.

39
00:02:07.900 --> 00:02:11.428
Right, so but other data,
data that does change frequently,

40
00:02:11.428 --> 00:02:13.034
I need to back up more often.

41
00:02:13.034 --> 00:02:14.117
Because it changes and

42
00:02:14.117 --> 00:02:17.548
so I need to make sure I've got the most
current version in that backup.

43
00:02:17.548 --> 00:02:19.913
I don't wanna roll that
backup if something happens.

44
00:02:19.913 --> 00:02:23.950
I go back and restore my backup and
the backup's three months old.

45
00:02:23.950 --> 00:02:28.490
Well, that information is dated or missing
three months' worth of changes that have

46
00:02:28.490 --> 00:02:31.360
occurred to that data, it's probably
not gonna do us a whole lot of good.

47
00:02:31.360 --> 00:02:37.072
It's better than nothing, but
it's not a very good scenario to be in.

48
00:02:37.072 --> 00:02:41.030
In fact, we've joked around, I know
we've got a couple stories around here.

49
00:02:41.030 --> 00:02:43.290
Not of anybody here but just in general.

50
00:02:43.290 --> 00:02:48.344
That's what can end up
being what we call a RGE.

51
00:02:48.344 --> 00:02:49.910
You remember that acronym, right?

52
00:02:49.910 --> 00:02:52.390
>> Absolutely,
that's the resume generating event.

53
00:02:52.390 --> 00:02:54.950
And I've also heard that if the whole
network fails, if you've got

54
00:02:54.950 --> 00:02:58.218
one printer that works, at least you can
print your resume on the way out the door.

55
00:02:58.218 --> 00:02:59.590
>> [LAUGH] That's right.

56
00:02:59.590 --> 00:03:03.972
So you don't wanna be that guy or gal that
when they say we had a failure, let's go

57
00:03:03.972 --> 00:03:08.756
get our backups, let's do our restore, and
you don't have all your backups, right?

58
00:03:08.756 --> 00:03:10.700
You didn't back everything up.

59
00:03:10.700 --> 00:03:14.150
Or the backups you do have aren't
restoring properly because

60
00:03:14.150 --> 00:03:15.830
there's something corrupt in them.

61
00:03:15.830 --> 00:03:19.960
Or your backups are three months old and
that's the most current backup you have.

62
00:03:19.960 --> 00:03:21.900
Not a good place to be.

63
00:03:21.900 --> 00:03:24.310
>> Now Mike,
when it comes to backups in general,

64
00:03:24.310 --> 00:03:27.870
would you say that this is a part
of ongoing system maintenance and

65
00:03:27.870 --> 00:03:30.082
it really shouldn't be like
a reactive type maintenance.

66
00:03:30.082 --> 00:03:32.270
You're saying everything fails,

67
00:03:32.270 --> 00:03:34.820
we're scrambling to find out
where's our backup media.

68
00:03:34.820 --> 00:03:35.980
But this really should be,

69
00:03:35.980 --> 00:03:40.100
would you say in your opinion,
part of an ongoing system maintenance?

70
00:03:40.100 --> 00:03:44.070
Whether it's daily, whatever your backup
schedule is, but just do your backups.

71
00:03:44.070 --> 00:03:46.684
>> Absolutely, it has to be planned out.

72
00:03:46.684 --> 00:03:49.560
We have to think about what we need to do,
where we're gonna store it,

73
00:03:49.560 --> 00:03:51.860
how often we're gonna back it up,
things like that.

74
00:03:51.860 --> 00:03:53.520
How many backups are we gonna keep?

75
00:03:53.520 --> 00:03:55.812
If I back it up today do I
still need yesterday's backup?

76
00:03:55.812 --> 00:03:56.470
Or do I need last month's backup?

77
00:03:56.470 --> 00:03:59.310
Or do I need last year's backup?

78
00:03:59.310 --> 00:04:00.938
How are we doing this?
There's different methods.

79
00:04:00.938 --> 00:04:05.791
I know we talk about in,
I can't remember if it's A+ or NetPlus.

80
00:04:05.791 --> 00:04:06.390
What is it?

81
00:04:06.390 --> 00:04:10.100
The father,
the grandfather methodology, or-

82
00:04:10.100 --> 00:04:10.880
>> Yeah, definitely.

83
00:04:10.880 --> 00:04:13.650
That's the tape rotation method.

84
00:04:13.650 --> 00:04:18.990
That doesn't really define what
we're putting on the media.

85
00:04:18.990 --> 00:04:22.170
But a better systematic approach to

86
00:04:22.170 --> 00:04:26.040
reduce the complexities behind
managing that media, absolutely.

87
00:04:26.040 --> 00:04:27.430
What is it, grandfather, father's son?

88
00:04:27.430 --> 00:04:30.520
And then the other one,
which is a crazy method for

89

00:27:16.807 --> 00:27:20.788
Let's see we could choose this one,
though.

541
00:27:20.788 --> 00:27:24.750
We'll do that one, so I just browse,
show all available disks.

542
00:27:24.750 --> 00:27:28.580
It was looking for an external drive,
I've got an internal drive there.

543
00:27:28.580 --> 00:27:33.750
I click next and
it tells me that was a unit included,

544
00:27:33.750 --> 00:27:36.350
volume D,
on the list of items be backed up?

545
00:27:36.350 --> 00:27:39.800
Did I, I didn't choose you to backup.

546
00:27:39.800 --> 00:27:41.380
Because they do a full backup,

547
00:27:41.380 --> 00:27:44.750
it's backing up everything it
sees including the D drive.

548
00:27:44.750 --> 00:27:48.664
And now I'm telling it to store the backup
on the D drive, so it's really not happy

549
00:27:48.664 --> 00:27:51.861
about that, which is something that
we should be aware of as well.

550
00:27:51.861 --> 00:27:55.300
I don't want to store the backup
on the drive that I'm backing up.

551
00:27:55.300 --> 00:27:56.350
One, that wouldn't do me any good.

552
00:27:56.350 --> 00:27:59.320
If I lose that drive I lost the back up.

553
00:27:59.320 --> 00:28:01.330
So most of them won't let you.

554
00:28:01.330 --> 00:28:05.048
But I can choose, do you want to
remove this volume from the back up?

555
00:28:05.048 --> 00:28:06.290
There's nothing on that drive.

556
00:28:06.290 --> 00:28:09.430
I put that drive in there specifically,
for back ups.

557
00:28:09.430 --> 00:28:11.500
So, yeah, sure, don't back that drive up.

558
00:28:11.500 --> 00:28:13.018
Use it as a place to store the back up.

559
00:28:13.018 --> 00:28:19.689
And then, it tells me it's gonna
reformat and all that I'll say yes.

560
00:28:19.689 --> 00:28:23.240
And then it's gonna back up again.

561
00:28:23.240 --> 00:28:26.120
Doing a full metal, full server backup.

562
00:28:26.120 --> 00:28:27.850
It's gonna do bare metal recovery.

563
00:28:27.850 --> 00:28:33.170
If a system partition,
local disk recovery, and system state.

564
00:28:33.170 --> 00:28:35.730
Now let's talk about these
options here real quick.

565
00:28:35.730 --> 00:28:39.415
Cuz I don't want to actually do
this backup just take too long.

566
00:28:39.415 --> 00:28:42.615
But a bare metal recovery, what is that?

567
00:28:42.615 --> 00:28:47.428
That I'm backing up everything,
if I need to be able to, let's say I

568
00:28:47.428 --> 00:28:52.033
lose a hard drive, or I lose the physical
server, I rebuild that server.

569
00:28:52.033 --> 00:28:57.000
It's got no OS, blank hard drives are put
back in there, this is what I would use

570
00:28:57.000 --> 00:29:02.210
a bare metal recovery is includes the
operating system, everything, all right?

571
00:29:04.010 --> 00:29:09.050
If a system partition that's that
hidden partition on our drive,

572
00:29:09.050 --> 00:29:13.730
sometimes has vendor information
in there for recovering for

573
00:29:13.730 --> 00:29:16.345
doing system restore on a system.

574
00:29:16.345 --> 00:29:20.493
The local disk C obviously is where
my operating system is installed that

575
00:29:20.493 --> 00:29:22.126
recovery partition again.

576
00:29:22.126 --> 00:29:23.846
Another one of those hidden partitions.

577
00:29:23.846 --> 00:29:26.831
I think it's about a 150 megs, or
140 megs, or something like that.

578
00:29:26.831 --> 00:29:29.440
And then system state, right?

579
00:29:29.440 --> 00:29:33.720
Now system state is the configuration
of the operating system.

580
00:29:35.640 --> 00:29:39.770
If I do a bare metal recovery and
I don't have the system state, or

581
00:29:39.770 --> 00:29:43.010
if I reinstall an operating system,
let's say I don't have this.

582
00:29:43.010 --> 00:29:44.150
I don't have a backup.

583
00:29:44.150 --> 00:29:45.130
And I've lost that server.

584
00:29:45.130 --> 00:29:47.090
I've gotta reinstall the operating system.

585
00:29:47.090 --> 00:29:49.170
But now it's a clean install, right.

586
00:29:49.170 --> 00:29:50.384
None of my configuration is there.

587
00:29:50.384 --> 00:29:53.600
So I've gotta go back and
do all that reconfiguration.

588
00:29:53.600 --> 00:29:56.865
If I backup the system state,
that includes that configuration.

589
00:29:56.865 --> 00:30:01.910
So not only can I get the OS back, but
I can get my configuration back as well.

590
00:30:01.910 --> 00:30:05.140
We do need to understand what is
included in a system state back up.

591
00:30:05.140 --> 00:30:06.701
That's a great test question.

592
00:30:06.701 --> 00:30:10.115
Let me make sure I get them all,
we got the boot files are in there.

593
00:30:10.115 --> 00:30:16.310
Your system registry settings, your system
protective files active directory data.

594
00:30:16.310 --> 00:30:17.930
If it's a domain controller,

595
00:30:17.930 --> 00:30:22.980
your system state will include
the active directory database.

596
00:30:22.980 --> 00:30:26.008
If it's a domain controller, that's where
the information that gets replicated

597
00:30:26.008 --> 00:30:27.706
between your domain
controllers are stored.

598
00:30:27.706 --> 00:30:30.265
Your group policy information
get's stored there.

599
00:30:30.265 --> 00:30:34.120
That would be included if
it was a domain controller.

600
00:30:34.120 --> 00:30:36.915
Your com-plus component
registration services or

601
00:30:36.915 --> 00:30:40.412
component services database would
be included in system state.

602
00:30:40.412 --> 00:30:42.963
As well as the certificate
services database,

603
00:30:42.963 --> 00:30:45.890
if you have certificate
services installed.

604
00:30:45.890 --> 00:30:47.390
We talked about that
in a previous episode.

605
00:30:47.390 --> 00:30:51.037
That's where all the information
about the certificates that have been

606
00:30:51.037 --> 00:30:55.295
issued by that certificate authority,
when they expire, who they were issued to.

607
00:30:55.295 --> 00:30:58.560
Verification information,
things like that.

608
00:30:58.560 --> 00:31:00.020
So if I back up the system state,

609
00:31:00.020 --> 00:31:02.842
it would include the certificate
services database as well.

610
00:31:02.842 --> 00:31:05.740
IIS metadata is actually also included.

611
00:31:05.740 --> 00:31:08.485
Not on my list, I don't know how I
missed that one, but I remembered, so

612
00:31:08.485 --> 00:31:09.299
you guys are in luck.

613
00:31:09.299 --> 00:31:11.134
But your IIS metadata.

614
00:31:11.134 --> 00:31:14.942
Now not all your websites It's not
your actual web pages typically

615
00:31:14.942 --> 00:31:20.230
unless they happen to be located on one of
the drives that you're backing up already.

616
00:31:20.230 --> 00:31:23.101
But IIS metadata configuration for IIS,

617
00:31:23.101 --> 00:31:26.305
the sites that are there and
things like that.

618
00:31:26.305 --> 00:31:29.008
And if it happens to be a web server, so

619
00:31:29.008 --> 00:31:33.573
I'll go ahead and click finish
It's gonna format that drive and

620
00:31:33.573 --> 00:31:38.790
it won't actually do the backup
until 10 o'clock tonight.

621
00:31:38.790 --> 00:31:43.286
So that is backing it up but
Wes is giving me that evil eye again.

622
00:31:43.286 --> 00:31:44.600
So I'll tell you what,

623
00:31:44.600 --> 00:31:48.164
why don't we talk about restore
after Wes let's me talk again.

624
00:31:48.164 --> 00:31:49.382
>> [LAUGH] And that's right.

625
00:31:49.382 --> 00:31:53.214
Because we coming to the end of another
episode but we have more to go.

626
00:31:53.214 --> 00:31:57.110
Very important concept,keep in mind that
not only are we talking about system

627
00:31:57.110 --> 00:32:00.427
maintenance here but
we are also talking about security, right.

628
00:32:00.427 --> 00:32:04.704
Cuz as Mike talked about in other
episodes we talked about confidentiality,

629
00:32:04.704 --> 00:32:06.564
we've talked about integrity.

630
00:32:06.564 --> 00:32:07.219
We've taught,

631
00:32:07.219 --> 00:32:09.849
showed you some of the things you
can use whether it be encryption.

632
00:32:09.849 --> 00:32:14.060
Whether it be things like your hash values
to make sure that messages haven't changed

633
00:32:14.060 --> 00:32:15.467
when we've received them.

634
00:32:15.467 --> 00:32:19.041
But, one of the other ones that's
in there too is the availability,

635
00:32:19.041 --> 00:32:22.860
making sure that your users are have
the data readily available to them and

636
00:32:22.860 --> 00:32:25.900
the backups are definitely
a way that we can protect that.

637
00:32:25.900 --> 00:32:28.140
So, I would send it back to you Mike, but

638
00:32:28.140 --> 00:32:31.010
he's already said that he is
leaving you with a cliffhanger.

639
00:32:31.010 --> 00:32:32.308
You're gonna come back for part two.

640
00:32:32.308 --> 00:32:35.400
So, that's perfect place to go ahead and
wrap this one up.

641
00:32:35.400 --> 00:32:37.400
As always Mike,
we appreciate you being here.

642
00:32:37.400 --> 00:32:38.971
And we appreciate you the viewer watching.

643
00:32:38.971 --> 00:32:42.057
Signing out for ITProTV,
I've been your host Wes Bryan.

644
00:32:42.057 --> 00:32:42.927
>> And I'm Mike Rodrick.

645
00:32:42.927 --> 00:32:44.333
>> And we'll see you next time.

646
00:32:44.333 --> 00:32:49.534
[MUSIC]

647
00:32:49.534 --> 00:32:54.028
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: In this episode Wes and Mike continue their discussion on various concepts surrounding maintaining Windows systems . They explain the restore process as well as demonstrate the restoration process through the Windows Server Backup tool. They also will look at driver rollback and Windows Update basics.
episodes.title: Windows Backup and Restore Part 2

WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.220 --> 00:00:03.087
Welcome to ITProTV, I'm your host, Don-

2
00:00:03.087 --> 00:00:05.202

00:00:05.202 --> 00:00:06.427
California [CROSSTALK]
