00:00:06.427 --> 00:00:08.293
[MUSIC]

5
00:00:08.293 --> 00:00:11.895
>> You're watching ITProTV.

6
00:00:11.895 --> 00:00:14.365
>> Welcome to another great
episode here at ITProTV.

7
00:00:14.365 --> 00:00:15.907
I'm your host Wes Bryan and

8
00:00:15.907 --> 00:00:20.350
in today's episode we are continuing
through our GIAC security essentials.

9
00:00:20.350 --> 00:00:23.510
That's right, GSEC essentials and
we're coming back with a Part Two.

10
00:00:23.510 --> 00:00:25.970
Joining us in the studios is none
other than Mr. Mike Rodrick.

11
00:00:25.970 --> 00:00:27.070
Mike, how you doing sir?

12
00:00:27.070 --> 00:00:28.400
>> Doing great, glad to be back.

13
00:00:28.400 --> 00:00:33.190
And yep, continuing on, talking a little
bit about good old backup and restore.

14
00:00:33.190 --> 00:00:35.240
So let's just jump right back into it.

15
00:00:35.240 --> 00:00:38.430
In our previous episode we
had talked about backups.

16
00:00:38.430 --> 00:00:41.420
We went through the backup process
with Windows Server Backup.

17
00:00:41.420 --> 00:00:44.000
And then I went ahead and
ran the backup so

18
00:00:44.000 --> 00:00:47.650
now we've got something to look at
when we talk about doing our restore.

19
00:00:47.650 --> 00:00:50.970
So let's take a look at my screen here,
and I'll show you what we've got.

20
00:00:50.970 --> 00:00:53.380
So back in Windows Server Backup,

21
00:00:53.380 --> 00:00:55.150
I can now see that I have
a little bit of details.

22
00:00:55.150 --> 00:00:56.264
If we zoom in here,

23
00:00:56.264 --> 00:01:00.607
I can see the last successful backup
was done [LAUGH] a few minutes ago, no.

24
00:01:00.607 --> 00:01:03.960
[LAUGH] But there you can see that
there was a successful backup.

25
00:01:03.960 --> 00:01:07.368
Obviously, there'd be more listed there
if this was a production environment.

26
00:01:07.368 --> 00:01:11.462
Down below that I can see
some status messages.

27
00:01:11.462 --> 00:01:16.803
I can even click on some of those to
get some details of what was backed up,

28
00:01:16.803 --> 00:01:18.250
and so on.

29
00:01:18.250 --> 00:01:22.045
Down below that I can see information
about my scheduled backup,

30
00:01:22.045 --> 00:01:24.810
what it's getting,
when the next runtime is.

31
00:01:24.810 --> 00:01:29.611
Destination information, I can see how
much space I have left, how many copies,

32
00:01:29.611 --> 00:01:31.720
how many backups are up there.

33
00:01:31.720 --> 00:01:34.820
And it'll do basically a first-in,
first-out type thing,

34
00:01:34.820 --> 00:01:38.510
whereas it'll keep backups
until it runs out of space.

35
00:01:38.510 --> 00:01:39.670
And then if it needs more space,

36
00:01:39.670 --> 00:01:43.192
it'll push the oldest backups out to
make room for the newest backups.

37
00:01:43.192 --> 00:01:48.690
All right, so now what we'll talk
about is the Backup Once option.

38
00:01:48.690 --> 00:01:54.698
When you choose Backup Once, you can
either use your scheduled backup options,

39
00:01:54.698 --> 00:01:57.260
remember we said a lot of
things in the scheduled backup.

40
00:01:57.260 --> 00:02:01.560
We said where we want it go,
we told it what we wanted to backup,

41
00:02:01.560 --> 00:02:06.446
in our case we did a full backup, and
we told it to do it at 10 o'clock.

42
00:02:06.446 --> 00:02:11.131
If I wanna just use those options,
backup everything, same destination,

43
00:02:11.131 --> 00:02:15.530
I could just use my scheduled
backup options, click Next and go.

44
00:02:15.530 --> 00:02:17.900
It would not affect my schedule.

45
00:02:17.900 --> 00:02:21.150
So remember, it's scheduled to
do this every night at 10 PM.

46
00:02:21.150 --> 00:02:25.940
If I ran this right now,
it would still backup tonight at 10 PM,

47
00:02:25.940 --> 00:02:28.290
it would not interfere
with my normal schedule.

48
00:02:28.290 --> 00:02:31.220
Just using the options that were
configured in the schedule.

49
00:02:31.220 --> 00:02:33.170
Or I can choose different options.

50
00:02:33.170 --> 00:02:34.830
So maybe I don't wanna do a full backup.

51
00:02:34.830 --> 00:02:36.088
It's the middle of the day,

52
00:02:36.088 --> 00:02:39.035
I just wanna backup something real
quick before I test something.

53
00:02:39.035 --> 00:02:43.000
Or I need to restore it into a VM
to do a little testing there.

54
00:02:43.000 --> 00:02:47.279
So I want to change my options, change my
destination, whatever the case may be,

55
00:02:47.279 --> 00:02:49.024
I can choose different options.

56
00:02:49.024 --> 00:02:51.939
And then I would go through the same
choices, run my backup again,

57
00:02:51.939 --> 00:02:54.420
it won't interfere with
my backup schedule.

58
00:02:54.420 --> 00:02:57.290
So that's what that Backup Once is for.

59
00:02:57.290 --> 00:03:00.520
We'll go ahead and cancel that out
cuz we've already got our backup and

60
00:03:00.520 --> 00:03:02.600
we don't want to see it happen again.

61
00:03:02.600 --> 00:03:05.441
But now that we have a backup,
we can choose Recover, all right.

62
00:03:06.490 --> 00:03:11.140
Recover is how we restore our
backup in the event of a failure.

63
00:03:11.140 --> 00:03:14.397
And first thing it asks me is
where is the backup stored?

64
00:03:14.397 --> 00:03:18.770
Is that on this machine or
another location like a network or

65
00:03:18.770 --> 00:03:20.435
something like that?

66
00:03:20.435 --> 00:03:23.992
Mine happens to be on this server,
we got that second drive in here.

67
00:03:23.992 --> 00:03:28.170
So I'll leave it and I'll click Next and
then I get a little calendar view.

68
00:03:28.170 --> 00:03:31.637
And this is pretty cool because what
it's gonna do, I'm gonna click away, and

69
00:03:31.637 --> 00:03:32.540
then kinda zoom in.

70
00:03:32.540 --> 00:03:35.010
You see how the 14 is bold?

71
00:03:35.010 --> 00:03:37.970
The blue box around the 14
just means that's today.

72
00:03:37.970 --> 00:03:42.896
But the fact that the number 14 is bold
means there was a backup form that day.

73
00:03:42.896 --> 00:03:46.230
And normally you'd see other
days that were bold as well.

74
00:03:46.230 --> 00:03:49.970
And what you can do is you can
click on a particular day and

75
00:03:49.970 --> 00:03:54.440
then you get a drop down list of all
the backups that were made on that day and

76
00:03:54.440 --> 00:03:56.380
you can pick the appropriate one.

77
00:03:56.380 --> 00:03:59.190
In my case, again,
we've only got the one to pick from.

78
00:03:59.190 --> 00:04:00.726
So I'll choose the 14th and

79
00:04:00.726 --> 00:04:04.547
I'll choose from the drop down list
the one that we did at the 3:52 PM.

80
00:04:04.547 --> 00:04:09.648
And you can see Recoverable Items and
it says Bare Metal.

81
00:04:09.648 --> 00:04:13.430
If I click on that, it'll actually
show me what is in the backup.

82
00:04:13.430 --> 00:04:16.480
Maybe I don't know what
backup was done last Sunday.

83
00:04:16.480 --> 00:04:22.275
Was it a full backup, was it just a few
files that were backed up, what was it?

84
00:04:22.275 --> 00:04:25.220
I can see that in this backup
it was a full or a bare metal,

85
00:04:25.220 --> 00:04:27.629
cuz I can see all
the different pieces there.

86
00:04:27.629 --> 00:04:31.665
You can see Bare Metal Recovery,
you'll also see AD and TDS, right?

87
00:04:31.665 --> 00:04:33.705
That's because this is
a domain controller, so

88
00:04:33.705 --> 00:04:36.085
it did include
the Active Directory database.

89
00:04:36.085 --> 00:04:39.335
You'll also see, let's see where in there?

90
00:04:39.335 --> 00:04:43.050
I don't see, FRS and then that GUID,

91
00:04:43.050 --> 00:04:47.650
that's my Sysvol folder, what the domain
controllers use for replication.

92
00:04:47.650 --> 00:04:51.400
You can see Local Disk C is there,
my recovery partition is in there,

93
00:04:51.400 --> 00:04:56.620
my EFI system partition is in there,
my system state is in there, the registry.

94
00:04:56.620 --> 00:05:00.240
So this was a full backup, right.

95
00:05:00.240 --> 00:05:05.520
Now when I go to, I'll click Next,
and then what I do I wanna restore?

96
00:05:05.520 --> 00:05:08.020
If let's say we had lost the machine or

97
00:05:08.020 --> 00:05:10.480
we were moving this to
a new piece of hardware.

98
00:05:10.480 --> 00:05:13.110
So we went ahead and
built our new piece of hardware.

99
00:05:13.110 --> 00:05:15.855
We installed the operating
system as a fresh install.

100
00:05:15.855 --> 00:05:18.115
And then I could restore the system state,

101
00:05:18.115 --> 00:05:21.045
the configuration to
that operating system.

102
00:05:21.045 --> 00:05:24.925
Or maybe I wanna restore applications
if they had registered with

103
00:05:24.925 --> 00:05:27.465
Windows Server Backup and
were included in the backup.

104
00:05:27.465 --> 00:05:30.845
We can restore entire volumes
if we had a D drive, an E drive,

105
00:05:30.845 --> 00:05:32.865
or in this case I got my C drive.

106
00:05:32.865 --> 00:05:35.775
Or we can do individual files and
folders, that's pretty cool.

107
00:05:37.790 --> 00:05:39.550
With Windows Server Backup,

108
00:05:39.550 --> 00:05:42.750
we can actually backup
individual files and folders.

109
00:05:42.750 --> 00:05:46.301
We did a full backup, let me cancel
this for a second and just show you.

110
00:05:46.301 --> 00:05:51.270
I'll do a Backup Once and I'll choose
different options and I'll click Next.

111
00:05:51.270 --> 00:05:55.080
And instead of doing a full like we did,
I could do custom.

112
00:05:56.720 --> 00:06:00.200
And then I can click Add Items,
and actually come in here and say,

113
00:06:00.200 --> 00:06:02.870
you know what,
I just need my profile backed up.

114
00:06:02.870 --> 00:06:05.040
I wanna restore that somewhere else,
so I come here and

115
00:06:05.040 --> 00:06:08.040
check it and click OK, and
now it'll include that.

116
00:06:08.040 --> 00:06:11.192
Or I might have a folder that
has a bunch of reports that I

117

episodes.description: In this episode Wes and Mike discuss the importance and utilization of Security Templates in a Windows environment as well as controlling settings through Group Policy in Windows domains. They explore password policies, lockout policies, software restriction policies and AppLocker.
episodes.title: Templates and Group Policy

Its the modern version of
software restriction policies.

555
00:27:50.358 --> 00:27:52.720
Alright, but they both do the same thing.

556
00:27:52.720 --> 00:27:55.530
And we still have software restriction
policies because some of you might still

557
00:27:55.530 --> 00:28:00.050
have XP machines on your network, why not?

558
00:28:00.050 --> 00:28:03.720
And application control policies
would not apply to Windows XP.

559
00:28:05.130 --> 00:28:07.750
So that's why we still have software
restriction policies, as well.

560
00:28:07.750 --> 00:28:11.790
But both of them allow me
to flag an application

561
00:28:11.790 --> 00:28:14.510
as not allowed to run on my machine.

562
00:28:14.510 --> 00:28:15.440
So just again,

563
00:28:15.440 --> 00:28:19.328
there might be an application that
you know has malware embedded in it.

564
00:28:19.328 --> 00:28:23.740
And you wanna prevent anybody from trying
to download and install that application.

565
00:28:23.740 --> 00:28:26.810
There's this Windows Store
app that's the latest craze.

566
00:28:26.810 --> 00:28:31.990
It's Galaga Wars and everybody in the
corporate office, has this thing installed

567
00:28:31.990 --> 00:28:35.460
and they're wasting, they're spending time
that should be working, playing this game.

568
00:28:35.460 --> 00:28:38.050
Well I'm gonna prevent that game
from installing on my machines.

569
00:28:38.050 --> 00:28:40.470
I can make an app locker
policy to do that.

570
00:28:40.470 --> 00:28:41.005
>> Very good.

571
00:28:41.005 --> 00:28:43.515
That's a good way to control it and
stay away from my computer.

572
00:28:43.515 --> 00:28:45.177
Computer by the way.

573
00:28:45.177 --> 00:28:46.355
>> [LAUGH].
>> [LAUGH] Mike now it does

574
00:28:46.355 --> 00:28:48.855
look like we're coming to the end of
another episode, but before we do,

575
00:28:48.855 --> 00:28:51.955
do you have any additional words of wisdom
you'd like to impart before we sign off?

576
00:28:51.955 --> 00:28:55.985
>> The biggest thing here I want you to
understand is the different options that

577
00:28:55.985 --> 00:28:58.705
we have to control the environment.

578
00:28:58.705 --> 00:29:01.015
So using the local security policy or

579
00:29:01.015 --> 00:29:05.665
the local group policy versus security
templates, versus group policy.

580
00:29:05.665 --> 00:29:10.360
Understanding when the best time to
use each of those is going to be, and

581
00:29:10.360 --> 00:29:14.090
then being familiar with a couple
of those settings within there.

582
00:29:14.090 --> 00:29:18.300
Your password policies and your account
lock out policies is always a good thing.

583
00:29:18.300 --> 00:29:20.610
>> Well that's a lot of great information,
Mike, as always.

584
00:29:20.610 --> 00:29:23.050
We do appreciate you being here
in the studios with us, and

585
00:29:23.050 --> 00:29:25.100
we also appreciate you,
the viewer, watching.

586
00:29:25.100 --> 00:29:28.020
Signing out for IT Pro TV,
I've been your host Wes Bryan.

587
00:29:28.020 --> 00:29:29.020
>> And I'm Mike Rodrick.

588
00:29:29.020 --> 00:29:30.988
>> And we'll see you next time.

589
00:29:30.988 --> 00:29:37.386
[MUSIC]

590
00:29:37.386 --> 00:29:39.370
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: In this show Cherokee and Mike begin explaining Windows security starting with Microsoft Firewall. Watch Mike demonstrate how to create and implement custom rules.
episodes.title: Windows Network Security
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.270 --> 00:00:02.533
Welcome to ITProTV,
I'm your host Don Pezet.

2
00:00:02.533 --> 00:00:06.386
[CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:06.386 --> 00:00:08.318
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:08.318 --> 00:00:12.064
>> You're watching ITProTV.

5
00:00:12.064 --> 00:00:15.850
>> Welcome to your
GIAC Security Essentials series.

6
00:00:15.850 --> 00:00:17.770
I'm your show host Cherokee Boose.

7
00:00:17.770 --> 00:00:21.230
In this episode, we'll be taking
a look at Windows Network Security.

8
00:00:21.230 --> 00:00:23.920
And with us today we have,
Mr Rodrick in the studios.

9
00:00:23.920 --> 00:00:25.280
Thank you for joining us, Mike.

10
00:00:25.280 --> 00:00:26.530
>> Hey, thanks for
having me back, Cherokee.

11
00:00:26.530 --> 00:00:30.205
Excited, as always,
to be here doing our GIAC GSEC content.

12
00:00:30.205 --> 00:00:32.420
>> Awesome, so, what are we
going to be starting with, Mike?

13
00:00:32.420 --> 00:00:35.380
>> Today, we're gonna look at,
well, news network security and

14
00:00:35.380 --> 00:00:37.790
we're gonna focus in on
a couple of technologies.

15
00:00:37.790 --> 00:00:40.290
We wanna look at the Windows Firewall.

16
00:00:40.290 --> 00:00:42.540
We also wanna take a look at IPsec.

17
00:00:42.540 --> 00:00:47.353
Using IPsec within Windows
as well as some VPN.

18
00:00:47.353 --> 00:00:52.080
We'll take a look at VPN, what it is, and
we'll talk a little bit about it as well.

19
00:00:52.080 --> 00:00:55.918
And then we'll round things out probably
in another episode the way I like to talk

20
00:00:55.918 --> 00:00:57.109
and stretch things out.

21
00:00:57.109 --> 00:01:01.549
We'll take a look at some Windows services
and some best practices associated

22
00:01:01.549 --> 00:01:05.250
with those built-in service
accounts that we have in Windows.

23
00:01:05.250 --> 00:01:07.980
So, those are the different things
that we have on tap for today.

24
00:01:07.980 --> 00:01:08.587
Sound exciting?
>> Sounds great.

25
00:01:08.587 --> 00:01:09.116
It does, yeah.

26
00:01:09.116 --> 00:01:11.580
>> All right, well,
should we get started, then?

27
00:01:11.580 --> 00:01:12.530
>> Yes, let's do it.

28
00:01:12.530 --> 00:01:13.140
>> All right, so

29
00:01:13.140 --> 00:01:15.650
we're gonna start off talking about
the good old Windows Firewall.

30
00:01:15.650 --> 00:01:20.930
And, on our exam objectives, they call out
in this topic Windows network security,

31
00:01:20.930 --> 00:01:24.830
they call out the firewalls and
packet filtering.

32
00:01:24.830 --> 00:01:27.470
So what we wanna do is we wanna take
a look at the Windows Firewall and

33
00:01:27.470 --> 00:01:30.140
see how we can do packet
filtering with that.

34
00:01:30.140 --> 00:01:35.210
Cuz a lot of people might not realize
that it does packet filtering.

35
00:01:35.210 --> 00:01:38.690
More likely, they just don't
put the two pieces together and

36
00:01:38.690 --> 00:01:42.000
understand that what they're doing
is actually packet filtering.

37
00:01:42.000 --> 00:01:45.480
>> Now Mike, we did have an episode where
we discussed different types of firewalls,

38
00:01:45.480 --> 00:01:49.110
so if we had to classify your
integrated Windows Firewall,

39
00:01:49.110 --> 00:01:51.430
that would be our host firewall, right?

40
00:01:51.430 --> 00:01:54.970
>> Exactly, there's gonna be a host
space firewall, which means,

41
00:01:54.970 --> 00:01:56.960
it only protects that particular host,
right?

42
00:01:56.960 --> 00:01:59.220
It's not worried about
anything else on the network.

43
00:01:59.220 --> 00:02:03.731
It's like that fence, or wall, that you're
gonna put up between your computer and

44
00:02:03.731 --> 00:02:06.349
the network that your
computer is connected to.

45
00:02:06.349 --> 00:02:11.863
And we should also understand that when we
look at networking, and IPv4, and TCP/IP,

46
00:02:11.863 --> 00:02:17.259
we're talking about just networking
in general, there's, what, 65,530?

47
00:02:17.259 --> 00:02:17.930
>> Five.

48
00:02:17.930 --> 00:02:19.450
>> Five ports or six ports?

49
00:02:19.450 --> 00:02:20.022
Zero through?

50
00:02:20.022 --> 00:02:21.365
>> Something like that.
[LAUGH]

51
00:02:21.365 --> 00:02:22.072
>> 34, yeah, you get it.

52
00:02:22.072 --> 00:02:23.913
>> [LAUGH]
>> The zero that is, no.

53
00:02:23.913 --> 00:02:24.905
>> Okay.
[LAUGH]

54
00:02:24.905 --> 00:02:26.240
>> But there's a lot of ports.

55
00:02:26.240 --> 00:02:30.283
And each one of those ports is
basically a doorway into your computer.

56
00:02:30.283 --> 00:02:34.423
Because remember when we create a socket,
a connection, between two machines,

57
00:02:34.423 --> 00:02:36.680
we've got three things that are needed.

58
00:02:36.680 --> 00:02:40.210
We've got the protocols
being used like TCP.

59
00:02:40.210 --> 00:02:43.458
We have the IP address,
the destination of this connection,

60
00:02:43.458 --> 00:02:46.273
who I'm trying to connect to,
their IPv4 address.

61
00:02:46.273 --> 00:02:48.555
And then we have the port
number which is the protocol.

62
00:02:48.555 --> 00:02:52.140
All right what port I'm connecting
to on that other machine.

63
00:02:52.140 --> 00:02:53.876
Those three things make up the socket.

64
00:02:53.876 --> 00:02:58.386
So, TCP 10.1.2.3:80 to connect to

65
00:02:58.386 --> 00:03:02.905
the web service on that
particular IP address.

66
00:03:02.905 --> 00:03:06.521
And with all those ports,
each one being a doorway in or basically

67
00:03:06.521 --> 00:03:11.210
a connection point that somebody can make,
that's a lot of ports to monitor.

68
00:03:11.210 --> 00:03:14.040
So a firewall allows me
to shut them all down and

69
00:03:14.040 --> 00:03:18.620
then say, I wanna open up this one, and
this one, but not the rest of them, right?

70
00:03:18.620 --> 00:03:22.140
So I can pick and choose what kind of
traffic I wanna allow to come in and

71
00:03:22.140 --> 00:03:25.650
come out,
which is packet filtering, right?

72
00:03:25.650 --> 00:03:28.060
When we talk about a packet
filtering firewall,

73
00:03:28.060 --> 00:03:32.740
we're talking about one that looks at
basically the header information alone.

74
00:03:32.740 --> 00:03:36.210
It's looking at source and
destination IP address, source and

75
00:03:36.210 --> 00:03:40.470
destination port numbers and
the protocol that's being used.

76
00:03:40.470 --> 00:03:44.880
So when we go in and we work with the
Windows Firewall, we can drop traffic or

77
00:03:44.880 --> 00:03:48.990
block or allow traffic, one of
the options is based on port number or

78
00:03:48.990 --> 00:03:50.700
what protocol we wanna use.

79
00:03:50.700 --> 00:03:53.650
There are some others that
we can do in there as well.

80
00:03:53.650 --> 00:03:56.190
So it allows us to do that,
to secure our computer.

81
00:03:56.190 --> 00:03:57.299
I'm not running FTP.

82
00:03:57.299 --> 00:04:01.739
I don't want anybody trying to connect
to port 20 or 21 to my machine.

83
00:04:01.739 --> 00:04:03.350
I'm not running a web service.

84
00:04:03.350 --> 00:04:05.930
I don't want to allow port
80 traffic into my machine.

85
00:04:05.930 --> 00:04:07.870
I don't want my machine listening, or

86
00:04:07.870 --> 00:04:11.960
I don't want this server on my
network listening on port 80.

87
00:04:11.960 --> 00:04:13.910
There's no reason for
anybody to connect to that.

88
00:04:13.910 --> 00:04:17.211
So I can make rules that block those,
all right?

89
00:04:17.211 --> 00:04:19.447
Now on Windows Server by default,

90
00:04:19.447 --> 00:04:23.310
the firewall starts out pretty
much blocking most things.

91
00:04:23.310 --> 00:04:26.040
It's gonna allow outbound traffic, but

92
00:04:26.040 --> 00:04:29.680
it's gonna block most inbound traffic,
which is the way we want it.

93
00:04:29.680 --> 00:04:33.890
>> And that kind of falls back on the term
implicit deny, right, that we spoke about?

94
00:04:33.890 --> 00:04:37.720
Exactly, that way, it's basically saying
unless you specifically allow it,

95
00:04:37.720 --> 00:04:40.030
I'm going to try to block that traffic.

96
00:04:40.030 --> 00:04:42.050
Now again, it's not locking everything.

97
00:04:42.050 --> 00:04:45.991
You definitely wanna go in and make sure
it's configured the way you want it.

98
00:04:45.991 --> 00:04:48.370
But also remember what we talked about.

99
00:04:48.370 --> 00:04:50.810
Return traffic is not inbound traffic,
right?

100
00:04:50.810 --> 00:04:53.970
I know it's coming into your computer but
it's not the same.

101
00:04:53.970 --> 00:04:55.710
It is return traffic.

102
00:04:55.710 --> 00:04:58.550
Your computer requested that traffic.

103
00:04:58.550 --> 00:04:59.980
It went out, talked to somebody,

104
00:04:59.980 --> 00:05:03.480
return traffic is part of
a conversation that you initiated.

105
00:05:03.480 --> 00:05:06.404
So it's going to be allowed
by the firewall, right?

106
00:05:06.404 --> 00:05:09.187
This is why the bad guys want
you to click on things and

107
00:05:09.187 --> 00:05:12.667
run things from the inside because
you're opening up a doorway,

108
00:05:12.667 --> 00:05:15.698
or allowing them in-
>> Soliciting that communication instead

109
00:05:15.698 --> 00:05:17.122
of an unsolicited communication.

110
00:05:17.122 --> 00:05:21.472
>> Yes, exactly, and the firewall,
when we add services to servers,

111
00:05:21.472 --> 00:05:24.030
we've gotta think about the firewall.

112
00:05:24.030 --> 00:05:27.270
If I wanna run a DHCP server service,

113
00:05:27.270 --> 00:05:33.150
I install DHCP on that server but in order
for it to provide services to the network,

114
00:05:33.150 --> 00:05:36.300
it needs to be listening
on port 67 by default.

115
00:05:36.300 --> 00:05:40.310
So, I've gotta make sure that port
gets opened up, If I'm running DNS,

116
00:05:40.310 --> 00:05:42.210
I've gotta have port 53 open.

117
00:05:42.210 --> 00:05:46.870
If I'm running Active Directory,
If I've got three to three 636 that's

118
00:05:46.870 --> 00:05:50.170
gotta be listening there so, and a lot
of these are configured automatically.

119
00:05:50.170 --> 00:05:55.960
Like when you go and install DHCP or
enable Remote Desktop, right?

120
00:05:55.960 --> 00:06:00.046
It's gonna say, hey, would you like me
to make an exception for port 3389?

121
00:06:00.046 --> 00:06:04.067
And you can say, yes, and it'll create
the rule for you, but not always.

122
00:06:04.067 --> 00:06:05.426
You gotta double check and

123
00:06:05.426 --> 00:06:08.759
make sure I've seen scenarios where
it says it was gonna do it but

124
00:06:08.759 --> 00:06:13.150
it never did it, and you're wondering
why nobody can get DNS resolution.

125
00:06:13.150 --> 00:06:15.575
And it's because, the firewall
didn't get configured properly.

126
00:06:15.575 --> 00:06:17.751
Something glitched, something happened,

127
00:06:17.751 --> 00:06:21.875
the account you were running didn't have
credentials to do the firewall exception,

128
00:06:21.875 --> 00:06:25.040
and maybe it just didn't do it so
you always have to double check.

129
00:06:28.140 --> 00:06:31.172
>> That's an amazing point to bring up,
Mike because, typically,

130
00:06:31.172 --> 00:06:34.746
if you're not allowed to connect and
you have a misconfiguration like that and

131
00:06:34.746 --> 00:06:37.345
it's an application or
service that your end users use,

132
00:06:37.345 --> 00:06:41.320
they'll notify you that a particular
service or piece of software is failing.

133
00:06:41.320 --> 00:06:44.270
But alternatively,
if you have misconfigured and

134
00:06:44.270 --> 00:06:48.060
have open ports that shouldn't be open
you're not really gonna get notifications

135
00:06:48.060 --> 00:06:51.330
on that so you definitely wanna double
check your configurations settings.

136
00:06:51.330 --> 00:06:53.055
>> Yeah, you get other kinds of surprises.

137
00:06:53.055 --> 00:06:54.420
>> [LAUGH]
>> Other than notifications, right?

138
00:06:54.420 --> 00:06:59.180
All your data starts drifting off
the network or you start blue screening or

139
00:06:59.180 --> 00:07:02.490
you get the old scary skull and

140
00:07:02.490 --> 00:07:05.610
crossbones laughing at you on your screen,
that's not good.

141
00:07:05.610 --> 00:07:09.418
All right, so let's take a look at a
Windows Firewall, start off with a client.

142
00:07:09.418 --> 00:07:13.180
It's really the same that you're
gonna see in a server as well.

143
00:07:13.180 --> 00:07:15.210
Windows Firewall came out, what XP?

144
00:07:16.240 --> 00:07:20.940
Service Pack 3,
I believe is when that came out.

145
00:07:20.940 --> 00:07:21.849
It's been a little while.

146
00:07:21.849 --> 00:07:22.600
>> I don't know.

147
00:07:22.600 --> 00:07:26.376
I think the Service Pack 2 is when a lot
of the security features came out?

148
00:07:26.376 --> 00:07:27.473
But, I don't know if it was 2 or 3.

149
00:07:27.473 --> 00:07:28.606
>> Yeah,
it might have been Service Pack 2.

150
00:07:28.606 --> 00:07:30.472
So, any of you people out
there in the chat room, yeah.

151
00:07:30.472 --> 00:07:31.240
>> Microsoft trivia.

152
00:07:31.240 --> 00:07:32.490
>> It's a trivia question for you.

153
00:07:32.490 --> 00:07:33.935
>> [LAUGH]
>> What's the Service Pack 2 and

154
00:07:33.935 --> 00:07:36.630
Service Pack 3 that brought
in the firewall there?

155
00:07:36.630 --> 00:07:37.149
>> Nonetheless.

156
00:07:37.149 --> 00:07:37.738
[LAUGH]
>> Yeah,

157
00:07:37.738 --> 00:07:40.499
but either way, Windows operating systems,
both client and

158
00:07:40.499 --> 00:07:42.631
server have a built in
firewall that we can use.

159
00:07:42.631 --> 00:07:43.818
You could do third party but

160
00:07:43.818 --> 00:07:46.690
we have to learn about Windows
in this particular episode.

161
00:07:46.690 --> 00:07:49.415
So, let's take a look
at my Windows Firewall.

162
00:07:49.415 --> 00:07:53.192
I'm on my client and so,
I'm gonna go to my Start menu and

163
00:07:53.192 --> 00:07:55.493
I'm just gonna type in firewall.

164
00:07:55.493 --> 00:07:59.269
And I'll see, I have a couple of options,
actually I have Windows Firewall.

165
00:07:59.269 --> 00:08:01.983
And then I have Windows Firewall
through Advanced Security.

166
00:08:01.983 --> 00:08:05.640
I have allow an app through a Firewall,
check Firewall status.

167
00:08:05.640 --> 00:08:07.310
So we've got a few options here.

168
00:08:07.310 --> 00:08:12.355
On the client, I do wanna show you,
if I go to Windows Firewall, it has a very

169
00:08:12.355 --> 00:08:17.565
basic panel where I can see currently
I'm connected to the domain network or

170
00:08:17.565 --> 00:08:22.085
the domain profile is being applied
to this particular connection.

171
00:08:22.085 --> 00:08:25.435
Because it detected the domain
controller said I'm on the domain, so

172
00:08:25.435 --> 00:08:29.435
I'm gonna allow certain things
because I'm on a trusted network.

173
00:08:29.435 --> 00:08:34.359
You also have your private and
your guest profiles, or public profiles.

174
00:08:35.860 --> 00:08:38.920
And great thing about the Windows Firewall
is we do have these profiles.

175
00:08:38.920 --> 00:08:41.890
Makes it a lot easier when
you move between trusted and

176
00:08:41.890 --> 00:08:46.030
untrusted networks especially on portable
computers, laptops, things like that.

177
00:08:47.210 --> 00:08:50.710
We don't wanna have to reconfigure
our Firewall every time but it,

178
00:08:50.710 --> 00:08:51.960
it's a real pain.

179
00:08:51.960 --> 00:08:55.860
It's like, okay I need remote desktop
enabled when I'm in the network

180
00:08:55.860 --> 00:08:59.110
because that's what the help desk uses
to connect to my machine to fix things.

181
00:08:59.110 --> 00:09:02.340
But when I go out to Starbucks I don't
want remote desktop listening for

182
00:09:02.340 --> 00:09:03.500
any connections.

183
00:09:03.500 --> 00:09:07.970
But is an end user actually going to
reconfigure their firewall every time they

184
00:09:07.970 --> 00:09:09.880
go from one place to the other?

185
00:09:09.880 --> 00:09:11.060
Most likely not.

186
00:09:11.060 --> 00:09:15.980
So these profiles allow me to configure
settings on a per profile basis and

187
00:09:15.980 --> 00:09:17.060
then Windows will detect.

188
00:09:17.060 --> 00:09:21.910
Every time you connect to a new network
Windows asks you, hey do you want to allow

189
00:09:21.910 --> 00:09:25.290
other computers to see you and
see other computers on this network?

190
00:09:25.290 --> 00:09:29.700
If you say yes, you're saying it's
a private network, that you trust it and

00:21:58.968 --> 00:22:02.841

00:22:06.241 --> 00:22:07.333

>> You have to run around from machine to

00:22:12.530 --> 00:22:13.920
Squeak, squeak, squeak.
>> [LAUGH]

458
00:22:13.920 --> 00:22:14.676
>> All right,

459
00:22:14.676 --> 00:22:18.011
so there's a good old look
at the Windows Firewall.

460
00:22:18.011 --> 00:22:23.674
I guess the only other thing I could
is maybe show you it in action.

00:22:23.674 --> 00:22:26.797
How could I do that?

>> Yeah, I think what I'll do

that it's updated the computer policy,

I'm going to refresh my inbound rules.

And if I look, what did I call that thing?

Something about allow ICMP4.

the IP address, but

479
00:23:36.290 --> 00:23:43.248
So if I go back over to the client and
we make a new rule,

480
00:23:43.248 --> 00:23:48.984
right click > New Rule> Port> Nex> TCP.

481
00:23:48.984 --> 00:23:50.025
Actually, I take that back.

00:23:55.402 --> 00:24:00.412
TCP, all ports,

484

So let's do that again.

485
00:24:01.170 --> 00:24:04.527
Let's do a custom rule.

486
00:24:04.527 --> 00:24:07.686
And I'll click Next, and
we'll do All Programs.

487
00:24:07.686 --> 00:24:12.270
But then I wanna choose a particular,
no I don't want a service, wow.

488
00:24:12.270 --> 00:24:14.410
Mike's having trouble
creating a new firewall rule.

489
00:24:14.410 --> 00:24:18.360
All Programs, and then here I'm

490
00:24:19.880 --> 00:24:21.370
And I'm not gonna customize it.

491
00:24:21.370 --> 00:24:25.980
I could just use like echo requests and
not some of the other ICMP type messages.

492
00:24:25.980 --> 00:24:27.590
>> Okay.
>> I'm gonna leave it like it is.

493
00:24:27.590 --> 00:24:29.370

494
00:24:29.370 --> 00:24:32.300
We'll say, Any for Source Destination.

495

496

Next.

498

cuz we use ping's test network
connectivity in our domain.

499
00:24:40.090 --> 00:24:45.666
Next, I'll give it a name, allow ICMPv4.

500
00:24:45.666 --> 00:24:49.410
I'll click Next.

501
00:24:49.410 --> 00:24:52.260
And again, in a sense I went into

502
00:24:52.260 --> 00:24:54.550
But now, there is my rule, it is enabled.

503
00:24:54.550 --> 00:24:56.520
So if I go back over to
the domain controller,

504
00:24:56.520 --> 00:24:59.140
I try to ping that client again.

505
00:24:59.140 --> 00:25:02.050
All of a sudden,
it is responding to those.

506
00:25:02.050 --> 00:25:05.380
So really what I did was
the opposite of filtering a packet.

507
00:25:05.380 --> 00:25:08.050
Well, I still am doing packet filtering.

508
00:25:08.050 --> 00:25:11.990
When we say packet filtering, it's not
necessarily dropping packets, right?

509
00:25:11.990 --> 00:25:14.540
It could be allowing
a certain type of packet, but

510
00:25:14.540 --> 00:25:16.100
the opposite would be true as well.

511
00:25:16.100 --> 00:25:18.510
I could have gone in there and
said, look, FTP.

512
00:25:18.510 --> 00:25:22.470
Do not allow or block and

513
00:25:22.470 --> 00:25:27.550
So good to see how we can use that Windows
firewall to help secure our environment.

514
00:25:27.550 --> 00:25:30.010
We've gotta make sure that
the firewall's enabled.

515
00:25:30.010 --> 00:25:33.030
It's one of those things that the users
will try to turn off because they think it

516
00:25:33.030 --> 00:25:38.850
makes the machine faster, but
it is that layer of security that we need.

517
00:25:38.850 --> 00:25:41.650
We also need to understand in Windows
environment or in domain environment

518
00:25:41.650 --> 00:25:45.440
anyway that we can use group policy to
make the administration of the firewall

519
00:25:45.440 --> 00:25:49.070
setting a lot easier as well as
prevent the users from being able to

520
00:25:49.070 --> 00:25:53.160
change settings that you've decided need
to be applied to those client machines.

521
00:25:53.160 --> 00:25:56.010
>> Yeah, I mean it's one of
those things that are kind

522
00:25:56.010 --> 00:25:57.680
of like any kind of anti malware programs.

523
00:25:57.680 --> 00:25:59.300
You don't wanna have
more than two running but

524
00:25:59.300 --> 00:26:03.410
if you think about having a host based
firewall and then also having a network

525
00:26:03.410 --> 00:26:06.410
based firewall, it doesn't matter
that they're both running.

526
00:26:06.410 --> 00:26:07.930
They're not gonna conflict in any way.

527
00:26:07.930 --> 00:26:12.450
So really end users shouldn't really
turn their firewall off maybe,

528
00:26:12.450 --> 00:26:15.760
unless they were troubleshooting,
to try to get an application to work or

529
00:26:15.760 --> 00:26:16.550
something like that.

530
00:26:16.550 --> 00:26:19.960
But otherwise,
I can't think of another reason.

531
00:26:19.960 --> 00:26:23.070
Installing, maybe some
anti-malware software maybe.

532
00:26:23.070 --> 00:26:24.290
>> Yeah.

533
00:26:24.290 --> 00:26:27.990
The funny thing is,
if your user has administrative rights,

534
00:26:27.990 --> 00:26:28.900
they can change things.

535
00:26:28.900 --> 00:26:32.730
And I can't tell you how many
forum posts blogs that I've read,

536
00:26:32.730 --> 00:26:34.470
you're like, hey this isn't working.

537
00:26:34.470 --> 00:26:36.810
I'm having trouble making
this connect to so-and-so.

538
00:26:36.810 --> 00:26:39.690
And you're reading this blog,
and somebody will say,

539
00:26:39.690 --> 00:26:43.238
always inevitably one of the posts is,
turn off your firewall.

540
00:26:43.238 --> 00:26:46.990
I am like duh, yeah, that's going to
fix it, but that's not the solution.

541
00:26:46.990 --> 00:26:47.770
Right?
We don't

542
00:26:47.770 --> 00:26:49.600
turn it off to fix a small problem.

543
00:26:49.600 --> 00:26:53.215
To allow one program to talk,
you don't disable the entire firewall.

544
00:26:53.215 --> 00:26:55.350
Please don't do that [LAUGH].

545
00:26:55.350 --> 00:26:57.000
>> All right Mike I know
we're getting close on time,

546
00:26:57.000 --> 00:26:59.680
do you wanna take a look at IP security or
do you wanna wait until the next episode?

547
00:26:59.680 --> 00:27:02.390
>> You know what, rather than try to
squeeze it in in a couple minutes I got

548
00:27:02.390 --> 00:27:03.635
a lot more to say about it.

549
00:27:03.635 --> 00:27:05.190
>> [LAUGH]
>> Let's save that for another episode.

550
00:27:05.190 --> 00:27:06.340
>> Sounds great, all right.

So thank you so much for being here,
and thank you ladies and gentlemen for

00:27:09.010 --> 00:27:10.240
joining us as well.

00:27:10.920 --> 00:27:13.063

WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.270 --> 00:00:06.669
Welcome to ITProTV,
I'm your host [CROSSTALK].

2
00:00:06.669 --> 00:00:08.447
[MUSIC]

3
00:00:08.447 --> 00:00:11.844
>> You're watching ITPRO.TV.

4
00:00:11.844 --> 00:00:15.870
>> Welcome to your
GIAC Security Essentials series.

5
00:00:15.870 --> 00:00:16.896
I'm your show host Cherokee Boose.

6
00:00:16.896 --> 00:00:21.319
This is actually a part two,
a continuation from a discussion we're

7
00:00:21.319 --> 00:00:25.390
previously having on our
Windows Networking Security.

8
00:00:25.390 --> 00:00:27.306
And with us today we have Mr.
Mike Rodrick in the studio.

9
00:00:27.306 --> 00:00:28.889
Thank you for joining us today, Mike.

10
00:00:28.889 --> 00:00:31.779
>> You're welcome Cherokee, thanks for
having me back even though I talk so

11
00:00:31.779 --> 00:00:33.190
much and make part twos and threes.

12
00:00:33.190 --> 00:00:34.248
[LAUGH]
>> It's all right.

13
00:00:34.248 --> 00:00:35.119
>> Okay.

14
00:00:35.119 --> 00:00:36.026
>> We'll get there.

15
00:00:36.026 --> 00:00:38.955
>> You're good, all right so yeah,
we do, we wanna continue on,

16
00:00:38.955 --> 00:00:42.670
we looked at firewalls in that previous
episode of part one, Windows Security.

17
00:00:42.670 --> 00:00:45.802
Next one we wanna take a look
at is something called IPsec.

18
00:00:45.802 --> 00:00:47.955
And I know we've mentioned that
in a couple of other episodes.

19
00:00:47.955 --> 00:00:50.371
Let's rehash what we already know and

20
00:00:50.371 --> 00:00:54.690
then we'll add a little bit to it as
well as do a quick demo on IPsec.

21
00:00:54.690 --> 00:00:57.753
So IPsec,
Internet Protocol Security, right?

22
00:00:57.753 --> 00:01:02.335
Is a protocol that we can use
to either authenticate and,

23
00:01:02.335 --> 00:01:07.430
or encrypt traffic going back and
forth between two nodes.

24
00:01:07.430 --> 00:01:12.757
And it allows me to do, remember IPsec
works down at layer, gosh two or three,

25
00:01:12.757 --> 00:01:18.438
way down on the OSI model, which means
it's application-independent, right?

26
00:01:18.438 --> 00:01:21.470
Whereas something like SSL, your browser,

27
00:01:21.470 --> 00:01:25.010
the application itself
has to understand SSL.

28
00:01:25.010 --> 00:01:26.870
If it doesn't support it,
you're not gonna be able to do it,

29
00:01:26.870 --> 00:01:30.152
because it's taking place up
there at the application layer.

30
00:01:30.152 --> 00:01:32.950
Whereas IPsec is way
down on the OSI model,

31
00:01:32.950 --> 00:01:34.830
application doesn't have
to know anything about it.

32
00:01:34.830 --> 00:01:37.970
It just sends its data as it
goes down through the layer,

33
00:01:37.970 --> 00:01:41.350
it gets encrypted when it gets down to
the bottom, goes across the network.

34
00:01:41.350 --> 00:01:45.200
It's decrypted well before it gets back
to the application on the other side, so

35
00:01:45.200 --> 00:01:48.760
the application is completely unaware
of what's going on, which is great,

36
00:01:48.760 --> 00:01:52.720
because I can secure any
kind of traffic using IPsec,

37
00:01:52.720 --> 00:01:55.200
it doesn't matter what the application is.

38
00:01:55.200 --> 00:01:57.290
So that's a cool thing.

39
00:01:57.290 --> 00:02:01.290
With IPsec we could spend a whole, gosh,

40
00:02:01.290 --> 00:02:05.250
we could do a whole series on IPSsec,
because there are a lot of options to it.

41
00:02:05.250 --> 00:02:10.850
You create your rules, we decide how
we want to apply this to the traffic.

42
00:02:10.850 --> 00:02:14.190
What rules we wanna put in
place to trigger IPsec.

43
00:02:14.190 --> 00:02:17.210
And we'll take a look, I'll show you
the wizard, and we'll walk through it and

44
00:02:17.210 --> 00:02:18.580
we'll make a simple one there.

45
00:02:20.050 --> 00:02:24.690
But like I said,
it's used any time I need to encrypt or

46
00:02:24.690 --> 00:02:27.570
secure, at least authenticate,
usually encrypt.

47
00:02:27.570 --> 00:02:31.210
Cuz it does have two different modes,
where we can do authentication header.

48
00:02:31.210 --> 00:02:35.820
Where we're only providing data integrity,
making sure it hasn't been modified.

49
00:02:35.820 --> 00:02:40.180
Or I can do ESP my
Encapsulating Security Payload

50
00:02:40.180 --> 00:02:42.040
where I do protect the payload itself,

51
00:02:42.040 --> 00:02:47.590
where I encrypt the traffic as well as
do integrity checks on that, all right?

52
00:02:47.590 --> 00:02:49.180
What else do I wanna say about that?

53
00:02:49.180 --> 00:02:55.180
I guess from a Window perspective with
IPsec, we enable it using policies.

54
00:02:55.180 --> 00:03:00.030
We create IPsec policies that
define what it is we need to do or

55
00:03:00.030 --> 00:03:02.360
how we want to apply IPsec.

56
00:03:02.360 --> 00:03:03.166
Like we can say,

57
00:03:03.166 --> 00:03:06.863
let's say I've got a server that has
sensitive information on it, right?

58
00:03:06.863 --> 00:03:08.852
Healthcare information or
something like that.

59
00:03:08.852 --> 00:03:13.490
And I wanna make sure anytime somebody
connects to that traffic is encrypted.

60
00:03:13.490 --> 00:03:16.322
So, if anybody is sniffing the network,
they're not gonna be able to

61
00:03:16.322 --> 00:03:18.879
see that information that they
might not be authorized to see.

62
00:03:18.879 --> 00:03:20.666
So, we can set it up to where,

63
00:03:20.666 --> 00:03:25.252
if you're connecting to this server,
the connection has to be encrypted.

64
00:03:25.252 --> 00:03:30.730
And we do that again using
these Windows policies.

65
00:03:30.730 --> 00:03:34.510
Now, let's take a look at what's
a good way to show you this.

66
00:03:34.510 --> 00:03:37.280
Let me hold off before we go to that
screen, let me say a couple more things.

67
00:03:37.280 --> 00:03:40.390
There are some default policies
we can use within Windows.

68
00:03:40.390 --> 00:03:42.660
There's client respond only.

69
00:03:42.660 --> 00:03:45.590
There's secure server request server.

70
00:03:45.590 --> 00:03:48.600
And then there's server require security.

71
00:03:48.600 --> 00:03:52.140
And basically what those do,
if you require security that means

72
00:03:52.140 --> 00:03:56.860
every connection to that machine is
gonna have to be encrypted with IPsec.

73
00:03:56.860 --> 00:03:59.374
If you do the secure
server request security,

74
00:03:59.374 --> 00:04:03.756
that means when a server receives a
connection attempt it's gonna say hey, Mr.

75
00:04:03.756 --> 00:04:07.696
Connector, whoever's trying to
connect to it, let's encrypt this.

76
00:04:07.696 --> 00:04:09.687
If the other end says
I don't understand or

77
00:04:09.687 --> 00:04:12.390
if it says I can encrypt
then we'll encrypt it.

78
00:04:12.390 --> 00:04:16.115
If the other end says I don't understand
IPsec, I don't know how to do it,

79
00:04:16.115 --> 00:04:20.336
then the server's gonna say I'll let you
connect anyway at least we tried, get it?

80
00:04:20.336 --> 00:04:24.737
Request security, you're gonna try to
encrypt it but if it doesn't, okay,

81
00:04:24.737 --> 00:04:25.350
we tried.

82
00:04:25.350 --> 00:04:28.470
And then the client respond
only means the client,

83
00:04:28.470 --> 00:04:32.640
the node will never
initiate secure connection.

84
00:04:32.640 --> 00:04:36.480
But if the other end says hey let's
encrypt it, the client can say okay,

85
00:04:36.480 --> 00:04:38.580
I understand IPsec, let's do that.

86
00:04:38.580 --> 00:04:40.720
But it'll never initiate on its own.

87
00:04:40.720 --> 00:04:44.630
Do understand those policies don't
mean server requires security,

88
00:04:44.630 --> 00:04:48.130
server requests security,
don't have to be done on a server.

89
00:04:49.830 --> 00:04:53.078
They're most commonly implemented there,
but they don't have to be.

90
00:04:53.078 --> 00:04:56.430

783
00:39:30.156 --> 00:39:32.973
Connections to Microsoft Routing
Remote Access Server, and

784
00:39:32.973 --> 00:39:35.070
Connections to other access servers.

785
00:39:35.070 --> 00:39:38.300
Both of them have the red x there and
they say deny access.

786
00:39:38.300 --> 00:39:41.400
These are your default rules
that block everything.

787
00:39:41.400 --> 00:39:44.595
And then you have to go back in and
add your own rules, so

788
00:39:44.595 --> 00:39:46.624
I made a rule called allow admins.

789
00:39:46.624 --> 00:39:50.170
And it's actually just allowing
any authenticated users.

790
00:39:50.170 --> 00:39:52.680
But there has to be at
least one policy in place,

791
00:39:52.680 --> 00:39:54.860
otherwise you will not be able to connect.

792
00:39:54.860 --> 00:39:58.120
So if you're troubleshooting VPNs,
this is where you would go.

793
00:39:58.120 --> 00:40:01.550
Check your policies, but
this is gonna decide who's allowed.

794
00:40:01.550 --> 00:40:04.477
Maybe only the sales people are allowed
to make these remote connections.

795
00:40:04.477 --> 00:40:07.079
I don't want just anybody
of my users going home and

796
00:40:07.079 --> 00:40:11.000
thinking they can connect to the work
network when they're at home.

797
00:40:11.000 --> 00:40:15.280
Or just admins are allowed to connect
remotely, or just the help desk people so

798
00:40:15.280 --> 00:40:16.120
they can fix things.

799
00:40:16.120 --> 00:40:19.640
Nobody else is allowed to connect
to the network from the outside.

800
00:40:19.640 --> 00:40:22.310
All of that is controlled
through these policies.

801
00:40:22.310 --> 00:40:24.750
You can put restrictions like time and
day restrictions.

802
00:40:24.750 --> 00:40:28.890
You can do IP range restrictions.

803
00:40:28.890 --> 00:40:32.590
You can do windows group restrictions, but

804
00:40:32.590 --> 00:40:34.710
it really helps you secure
those VPN connections.

805
00:40:36.300 --> 00:40:38.593
>> Well I think we do have some
more information to cover.

806
00:40:38.593 --> 00:40:40.845
So that means we're really
at a part three, Mike.

807
00:40:40.845 --> 00:40:41.668
>> [LAUGH]
>> So thank you for

808
00:40:41.668 --> 00:40:45.700
being with us this long, and thank you
ladies and gentleman for staying tuned.

809
00:40:45.700 --> 00:40:47.315
But definitely don't change that channel,

810
00:40:47.315 --> 00:40:49.149
because we have more
information headed your way.

811
00:40:49.149 --> 00:40:52.260
I'm gonna go ahead and
sign-off as your host, Cherokee Boose.

812
00:40:52.260 --> 00:40:54.620
>> And I'm Mike Roderick.
>> See you next time here at ITPro.TV.

813
00:40:54.620 --> 00:41:01.990
[MUSIC].

814
00:41:01.990 --> 00:41:06.820
>> Thank you for watching ITPRO.TV.

episodes.description: Learn the difference between several types of counts as Mike and Cherokee cover them individually. Mike explains Built-in Local System Accounts, Built-in Local Service Accounts, Built-in Network Services Accounts and Created Service Accounts. Lastly, they discuss some common best practices to follow.
episodes.title: Windows Network Security Part 3
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.270 --> 00:00:02.495
Welcome to ITPro TV, I'm your host.

2
00:00:02.495 --> 00:00:08.343
[MUSIC]

3
00:00:08.343 --> 00:00:12.002
>> You're watching ITPro TV.

4
00:00:12.002 --> 00:00:14.936
>> Welcome to your GIAC
security essentials series.

5
00:00:14.936 --> 00:00:17.190
I'm your show host Cherokee Boose.

6
00:00:17.190 --> 00:00:18.480
This is actually a part three and

7
00:00:18.480 --> 00:00:22.260
we made it, and we were looking
at Windows networking security.

8
00:00:22.260 --> 00:00:26.010
With us today we have Mister Mike Rodrick
in studios, thank you for joining us Mike.

9
00:00:26.010 --> 00:00:28.040
>> Well you're welcome Cherokee,
thanks for having me back.

10
00:00:28.040 --> 00:00:31.460
Yeah I am kind of long winded today.

11
00:00:31.460 --> 00:00:32.427
>> It's all right there's
a lot to cover here.

12
00:00:32.427 --> 00:00:33.748
>> There is a lot of good stuff.

13
00:00:33.748 --> 00:00:39.420
So we're gonna talk now about
securing Windows server services.

14
00:00:39.420 --> 00:00:42.943
Just on some best practices,
we'll take a look at a couple of those, or

15
00:00:42.943 --> 00:00:46.377
talk about at least, a couple of
those built-in service accounts.

16
00:00:46.377 --> 00:00:47.238
And should we use them?

17
00:00:47.238 --> 00:00:48.830
Should we not use them?

18
00:00:48.830 --> 00:00:50.620
What are our alternatives?

19
00:00:50.620 --> 00:00:52.010
Some things we should know about them.

20
00:00:52.010 --> 00:00:55.520
But, before we do that, I did want to show
you one more thing if you're watching that

21
00:00:55.520 --> 00:00:57.200
previous episode and
you're thinking to yourself,

22
00:00:57.200 --> 00:01:01.720
man he opened up that new remote
access management console and

23
00:01:01.720 --> 00:01:04.610
then never showed it to us,
cuz it was so slow to open.

24
00:01:04.610 --> 00:01:08.240
I didn't forget, it's right here,
so let's take a quick peak at it.

25
00:01:08.240 --> 00:01:11.300
All right, a relatively new console, and

26
00:01:11.300 --> 00:01:14.930
it's called the remote access management
console, and it's, It's pretty nice.

27
00:01:14.930 --> 00:01:17.840
It allows me to monitor
my VPN connections.

28
00:01:17.840 --> 00:01:21.860
Got this dashboard that is showing
me that my operational status for

29
00:01:21.860 --> 00:01:24.240
app one is up and running.

30
00:01:24.240 --> 00:01:28.550
My services, my VPN addressing,
my connectivity all looking good.

31
00:01:28.550 --> 00:01:32.120
And I can see some information about
my clients that are connected.

32
00:01:32.120 --> 00:01:35.384
How much data's gone back and
forth how many connections and

33
00:01:35.384 --> 00:01:36.990
that's just the dashboard.

34
00:01:36.990 --> 00:01:41.310
You can go into the operational status
page and see your different VPN servers.

35
00:01:41.310 --> 00:01:44.450
I've got my remote client status and
I can see that client that we were

36
00:01:44.450 --> 00:01:47.090
using in the previous
episode is still connected.

37
00:01:47.090 --> 00:01:49.150
I can see the IP addresses down here.

38
00:01:49.150 --> 00:01:54.070
There are some protocol information
some authentication information.

39
00:01:54.070 --> 00:01:57.730
I can even right click on that guy and
choose details and

40
00:01:57.730 --> 00:02:00.650
get some more detailed
information about the connection.

41
00:02:00.650 --> 00:02:02.250
And where they're connecting from.

42
00:02:02.250 --> 00:02:03.540
How long they've been connected?

43
00:02:03.540 --> 00:02:05.870
What kind of rate data transfer
rates they're getting.

44
00:02:07.220 --> 00:02:10.810
So pretty neat information that you
can get there from this new console.

45
00:02:10.810 --> 00:02:13.340
Just wanted to point
that out to everybody.

46
00:02:14.490 --> 00:02:14.990
All right.

47
00:02:14.990 --> 00:02:17.490
So now, we'll talk about the-
>> Services.

48
00:02:17.490 --> 00:02:19.155
>> Yeah.
Service accounts.

49
00:02:19.155 --> 00:02:21.470
>> [LAUGH]
>> Securing Windows server services.

50
00:02:21.470 --> 00:02:26.890
A service something that runs that
provides some type of functionality,

51
00:02:26.890 --> 00:02:28.840
some type of functionality.

52
00:02:28.840 --> 00:02:34.650
Like the DHTP server service,
is a service that's designed to listen for

53
00:02:34.650 --> 00:02:38.150
and respond to DACP discover packets, and

54
00:02:38.150 --> 00:02:43.470
provide TCPIP configuration
automatically to machines on my network.

55
00:02:43.470 --> 00:02:48.600
DNS is a service that provides
name resolution, functionality.

56
00:02:48.600 --> 00:02:54.520
SQL, is a database service that we can
connect to and work with databases.

57
00:02:54.520 --> 00:02:56.250
Heck, Active Directory is a service,
right?

58
00:02:56.250 --> 00:03:00.190
But these services need
accounts to run under.

59
00:03:00.190 --> 00:03:03.560
They don't run in just kinda ether and
magic.

60
00:03:03.560 --> 00:03:05.460
They have to access resources.

61
00:03:05.460 --> 00:03:10.910
We need to log what they're doing, so
we need to assign an account to them

62
00:03:10.910 --> 00:03:16.870
that gives them the rights to run, the
right to access resources if they need to.

63
00:03:16.870 --> 00:03:20.435
We can track what's going on
with that particular service,

64
00:03:20.435 --> 00:03:24.400
IIS is another one that has many
service accounts that it uses.

65
00:03:26.120 --> 00:03:28.750
I know setting up exchange

66
00:03:28.750 --> 00:03:32.310
is one of those where you end up
creating lots of service accounts.

67
00:03:32.310 --> 00:03:34.540
Or you don't, you create one account and

68
00:03:34.540 --> 00:03:36.250
you do everything the way
you're not supposed to do.

69
00:03:36.250 --> 00:03:38.760
And use that same account for
all kinds of stuff.

70
00:03:38.760 --> 00:03:42.460
But anyway the point is these
things need accounts to run under.

71
00:03:42.460 --> 00:03:45.960
That gives them the authority to
start up and access resources so

72
00:03:45.960 --> 00:03:51.300
we can track them, we got accountability
by logging those service accounts.

73
00:03:51.300 --> 00:03:55.350
Windows has several built in
accounts that we can use for

74
00:03:55.350 --> 00:03:58.870
services, and as you install some
services windows picks one for

75
00:03:58.870 --> 00:04:02.710
you, you can usually go back in and
change that.

76
00:04:02.710 --> 00:04:07.630
Some services like SQL or
Exchange as you're installing those

77
00:04:07.630 --> 00:04:11.370
applications it's gonna tell you you
need to assign a service account.

78
00:04:11.370 --> 00:04:15.020
And so what you should do is,
as a best practice before you install it,

79
00:04:15.020 --> 00:04:20.400
you read through your prereqs and
you realize I'm gonna need three accounts.

80
00:04:20.400 --> 00:04:23.550
One of them is gonna need this level
of access, the other two are gonna need

81
00:04:23.550 --> 00:04:26.040
this level of access, and
you create all that ahead of time.

82
00:04:26.040 --> 00:04:28.140
And then, as you're going through
the installation wizard, it says,

83
00:04:28.140 --> 00:04:33.070
what account would you like to use to
be your, to run the MS SQL service,

84
00:04:33.070 --> 00:04:35.380
if it's a SQL server, and
you pick one of those accounts.

85
00:04:35.380 --> 00:04:37.770
What account are you gonna use for
the database service, and

86
00:04:37.770 --> 00:04:41.640
you go pick one of those
accounts that you created.

87
00:04:41.640 --> 00:04:43.450
So, let's talk about some
of those built in accounts.

88
00:04:43.450 --> 00:04:46.250
There is the built in local,
system account.

89
00:04:46.250 --> 00:04:49.155
There's the built in
local service account.

90
00:04:49.155 --> 00:04:51.688
There's the built in
network service account.

91
00:04:51.688 --> 00:04:55.588
And I guess those are the big three
that we wanna talk about that they call

92
00:04:55.588 --> 00:04:57.580
out on our objectives here.

93
00:04:57.580 --> 00:05:03.340
And first thing I wanna do is define what
these service accounts get as rights and

94
00:05:03.340 --> 00:05:04.340
permissions.

95
00:05:04.340 --> 00:05:09.330
Because if we're gonna use them we need to
understand what they're going to allow.

96
00:05:09.330 --> 00:05:11.570
Because we don't want to just.

97
00:05:13.230 --> 00:05:15.220
We want to follow the principle
of lease privilege.

98
00:05:15.220 --> 00:05:16.790
Right?
We talk about this all the time.

99
00:05:16.790 --> 00:05:21.000
We only assign the rights and permissions
that somebody needs to do their job, and

100
00:05:21.000 --> 00:05:26.130
nothing more because if we give them more
either intentionally or maliciously or

101
00:05:26.130 --> 00:05:29.270
unintentionally, they're gonna take
advantage of those extra rights and

102
00:05:29.270 --> 00:05:31.930
they're gonna do something that's
gonna cause problems to the computer

103
00:05:31.930 --> 00:05:35.250
to the network, other computers,
who knows what.

104
00:05:35.250 --> 00:05:36.660
We don't do it to be cruel.

105
00:05:36.660 --> 00:05:39.130
>> Right, you just dont want
to haphazardly be doling

106
00:05:39.130 --> 00:05:43.400
out administrative accounts because then
well it's gonna come back to you, right?

107
00:05:43.400 --> 00:05:44.540
>> Absolutely it is.

108
00:05:44.540 --> 00:05:46.550
I remember a great story.

109
00:05:46.550 --> 00:05:47.950
This was years ago, but

110
00:05:47.950 --> 00:05:52.110
I had one of my students back when I
taught primarily the server classes.

111
00:05:52.110 --> 00:05:53.762
He had taken my classes.

112
00:05:53.762 --> 00:05:55.045
Got his MCSA, got his MCSE.

113
00:05:55.045 --> 00:06:00.330
Went and got a job here locally,
came back to me a few weeks later.

114
00:06:00.330 --> 00:06:01.840
He said you're not believe this.

115
00:06:01.840 --> 00:06:03.770
I just had to come by and tell you.

116
00:06:03.770 --> 00:06:04.510
Cause we had talked.

117
00:06:04.510 --> 00:06:07.880
Of course I taught about the principle
of least privilege and things like that.

118
00:06:07.880 --> 00:06:11.250
And he said so at this network that I'm
now administering and that I'm in charge

119
00:06:11.250 --> 00:06:16.170
of every single user on the network
was in the domain admins group.

120
00:06:16.170 --> 00:06:17.240
>> Mike, you know what that tells me?

121
00:06:17.240 --> 00:06:21.400
That tells me that that was a previous,
the previous admin was just lazy because

122
00:06:21.400 --> 00:06:26.170
instead of individually going to that
system and installing a piece of software

123
00:06:26.170 --> 00:06:31.380
allowing them to have access to network
resources, they just said I'm gonna

124
00:06:31.380 --> 00:06:34.885
let you do whatever you wanna do, because
I don't wanna have to do it myself.

125
00:06:34.885 --> 00:06:35.470
[LAUGH]
>> Exactly,

126
00:06:35.470 --> 00:06:38.200
it's the lazy admin way
of getting things done.

127
00:06:38.200 --> 00:06:39.280
And it's a great story.

128
00:06:39.280 --> 00:06:41.740
And he was like how do
I go about fixing this?

129
00:06:41.740 --> 00:06:43.415
And I was like the first
thing you're gonna have to do

130
00:06:43.415 --> 00:06:44.715
is get administrative buy in.

131
00:06:44.715 --> 00:06:47.775
Because your users are now used
to having administrative rights.

132
00:06:47.775 --> 00:06:48.915
>> They're not going to
be happy about that.

133
00:06:48.915 --> 00:06:49.756
They can do anything they want.

134
00:06:49.756 --> 00:06:51.005
>> [LAUGH].
They can install software.

135
00:06:51.005 --> 00:06:51.625
Whatever.

136
00:06:51.625 --> 00:06:53.315
Soon as you take it away, yeah,
they're going to be unhappy.

137
00:06:53.315 --> 00:06:54.255
>> You're going to hear it.

138
00:06:54.255 --> 00:06:58.136
So you better have management backing
you up before you start anything.

139
00:06:58.136 --> 00:07:00.153
But anyway, that's another story,
we'll talk about that another day.

140
00:07:00.153 --> 00:07:05.662
So back to this, the same principle
needs to be applied here.

141
00:07:05.662 --> 00:07:08.392
If what I'm setting up a service or

142
00:07:08.392 --> 00:07:12.262
I'm installing an application that
needs to run under an account,

143
00:07:12.262 --> 00:07:15.322
the easiest way to do it would be
to just create a new administrator.

144
00:07:15.322 --> 00:07:18.001
Create a new account,
give it administrative rights,

145
00:07:18.001 --> 00:07:21.470
assign it to that application,
and bada-bing we're done.

146
00:07:21.470 --> 00:07:24.830
I'm not gonna have any errors,
that applications gonna have no problem

147
00:07:24.830 --> 00:07:28.160
running, accessing whatever it needs and
we're gonna be good to go.

148
00:07:28.160 --> 00:07:30.490
So it will work.

149
00:07:30.490 --> 00:07:34.390
But the problem is if somebody
compromises that service account.

150
00:07:34.390 --> 00:07:37.030
Now, they've got administrative access.

151
00:07:37.030 --> 00:07:38.940
>> Right,
with the privilege escalation attacks-

152
00:07:38.940 --> 00:07:40.405
>> And they don't even need the privilege

153
00:07:40.405 --> 00:07:42.300
escalation-
>> Cuz they're already an administrator,

154
00:07:42.300 --> 00:07:46.050
yeah so it is just a very bad,
bad thing, right?

155
00:07:46.050 --> 00:07:49.203
I must say there's lot of times
that you have to do this.

156
00:07:49.203 --> 00:07:54.561
I have seen some applications that require
at least local administrative access And

157
00:07:54.561 --> 00:07:58.040
you have to do it if you choose
to run that application.

158
00:07:58.040 --> 00:08:01.499
Maybe if I had a different application
that doesn't have those needs or

159
00:08:01.499 --> 00:08:04.700
some other way to monitor and
secure that application.

160
00:08:04.700 --> 00:08:07.490
But we always wanna follow that
principle least privilege.

161
00:08:07.490 --> 00:08:09.510
Let's talk about these different
accounts then that we can use.

162
00:08:09.510 --> 00:08:11.190
The built in local system account,

163
00:08:12.620 --> 00:08:17.150
which is one that sometimes will get
assigned by default applications.

164
00:08:17.150 --> 00:08:20.670
The local system account is
the local administrator basically.

165
00:08:20.670 --> 00:08:24.320
In fact it has a few more rights than
even the administrator does if you can

166
00:08:24.320 --> 00:08:25.680
imagine that.

167
00:08:25.680 --> 00:08:31.660
But it basically you can consider
it a local admin on that machine.

168
00:08:31.660 --> 00:08:37.200
So if I go to a service and
I assign that account then it's

169
00:08:37.200 --> 00:08:42.000
gonna have administrative rights on the
machine, which again we might or not need.

170
00:08:42.000 --> 00:08:43.930
As far as network access goes for

171
00:08:43.930 --> 00:08:47.710
the local system account,
it's gonna impersonate the local computer.

172
00:08:47.710 --> 00:08:52.140
So it can reach out that service account
can reach out talk to other machine

173
00:08:52.140 --> 00:08:56.330
on the network, but
it's gonna be as the computer account.

174
00:08:56.330 --> 00:09:00.950
So if you use computers in
your security groups and

175
00:09:00.950 --> 00:09:04.310
had added this computer account to a group
it would have those permissions and

176
00:09:04.310 --> 00:09:07.910
rights associated with that group, right?

177
00:09:07.910 --> 00:09:10.710
If you did this on a domaining controller,
please don't.

178
00:09:10.710 --> 00:09:13.430
There is a local system account
on the domain controller, but

179
00:09:13.430 --> 00:09:17.570
it's now a domain admin it has
full rights to Active Directory,

180
00:09:17.570 --> 00:09:20.420
which is probably not
going to be a good thing.

181
00:09:20.420 --> 00:09:25.290
These accounts the local system account
does have a password associated with it.

182
00:09:25.290 --> 00:09:27.720
We don't manage it, Windows manages it.

183
00:09:27.720 --> 00:09:30.990
Changes it about every
seven days on its own so

184
00:09:30.990 --> 00:09:33.720
we don't have to worry about that,
all right?

185
00:09:33.720 --> 00:09:37.630
And passwords for service accounts
are a problem that we have to deal with.

186
00:09:37.630 --> 00:09:39.520
We'll come back to that
concept when we get through

187
00:09:39.520 --> 00:09:40.600
talking about these other accounts.

188
00:09:40.600 --> 00:09:42.184
So don't let me forget Cherokee,
I like to do that.

189
00:09:42.184 --> 00:09:43.852
>> Okay [LAUGH].

190
00:09:43.852 --> 00:09:47.460
>> Then you've got so
that's the local system account.

191
00:09:47.460 --> 00:09:51.720
Then you've got the local service account,
sounds similar but it's not, right?

192
00:09:51.720 --> 00:09:57.510
It's an account that is basically
a member of the Local Users Group.

193
00:09:57.510 --> 00:10:01.200
So any rights that were signed,
permissions that are signed to

194
00:10:01.200 --> 00:10:07.070
the Local Users Group, this service
account would have those same rights.

195
00:10:07.070 --> 00:10:11.350
It does have network access but
it accesses it as anonymous.

196
00:10:11.350 --> 00:10:16.000
So if you have used anonymous, or
allowed anonymous access to anyone on

00:23:08.818 --> 00:23:10.111
So, let's see how we do that.

456
00:23:10.111 --> 00:23:11.631
I'm gonna clear our
screen out a little bit,

457
00:23:11.631 --> 00:23:13.072
just to get some of
the clutter out of here.

458
00:23:13.072 --> 00:23:16.200
And let's start with a gateway.

459
00:23:16.200 --> 00:23:23.770
So, what you do is you say,
route add default gw, like that.

460
00:23:23.770 --> 00:23:28.360
So, basically you're using
the route command to add a route.

461
00:23:28.360 --> 00:23:31.251
And if you have ever worked
with Cisco equipment, or

462
00:23:31.251 --> 00:23:35.982
any kind of networking equipment per se,
specifically, Cisco's is very similar in

463
00:23:35.982 --> 00:23:39.812
the way that this comes out,
setting up that gateway of last resort.

464
00:23:39.812 --> 00:23:43.268
If I don't know where to go, go here,
all right, and that's what we're doing,

465
00:23:43.268 --> 00:23:44.934
that's basically what we're doing.

466
00:23:44.934 --> 00:23:46.420
We set this gateway.

467
00:23:46.420 --> 00:23:49.070
When I wanna get out of my local network,

468
00:23:49.070 --> 00:23:51.070
here is the path I take
to get out of this thing.

469
00:23:51.070 --> 00:23:56.240
So, and that's typically your router
of some sort that has access to that.

470
00:23:56.240 --> 00:24:00.020
So, let's set it,
I can set it to anything I want, so

471
00:24:00.020 --> 00:24:05.913
if I want to make this 102.168.219.1,
I could do that, hit Return.

472
00:24:05.913 --> 00:24:09.277
And that is now my default gateway, okay.

473
00:24:09.277 --> 00:24:13.454
So if you set all the IP information
correctly, you go to get on the internet,

474
00:24:13.454 --> 00:24:16.860
and you're not getting anywhere,
you might wanna go ahead and

475
00:24:16.860 --> 00:24:21.229
make sure, what's my router's IP address
that gets me out to the internet, and

476
00:24:21.229 --> 00:24:23.680
let me add that as a default gateway.

477
00:24:23.680 --> 00:24:26.690
If we wanna do DNS, this is the only
thing that's a little weird,

478
00:24:26.690 --> 00:24:31.940
it's not a command per se,
it's modifying a configuration file, okay?

479
00:24:31.940 --> 00:24:38.360
And the configuration
file is resolve.conf and

480
00:24:38.360 --> 00:24:40.650
it lives in the etsy directory.

481
00:24:40.650 --> 00:24:45.270
So if I change directory to /etc and

482
00:24:45.270 --> 00:24:52.350
I do like a cat resolve.conf.

483
00:24:52.350 --> 00:24:53.950
There is stuff in there.

484
00:24:53.950 --> 00:24:56.170
And you will see I have
been playing around so

485
00:24:56.170 --> 00:24:59.170
has this name server in here
cuz I added that in there.

486
00:24:59.170 --> 00:25:03.050
If I wanted to add one of Google's
name servers, I could do that easily.

487
00:25:03.050 --> 00:25:06.690
I can either edit this file,
I can open it up in an editor.

488
00:25:06.690 --> 00:25:10.410
Add the line to that I am about to show
you and then save it, and close it.

489
00:25:10.410 --> 00:25:11.420
That would be fine.

490
00:25:11.420 --> 00:25:12.440
I like to do things shortcut.

491
00:25:12.440 --> 00:25:14.480
I'm gonna show you the shortcut way.

492
00:25:14.480 --> 00:25:18.290
So what I can do is append to
the file to the command line.

493
00:25:18.290 --> 00:25:24.240
If you type in echo and
you say hi there, it'll echo hi there.

494
00:25:24.240 --> 00:25:25.028
Basically, an echo.

495
00:25:25.028 --> 00:25:25.610
Just like that.

496
00:25:25.610 --> 00:25:33.040
So I'm gonna echo what I want echo,
and I'll say name server 8.8.8.8, and

497
00:25:34.240 --> 00:25:39.220
then I'll append that with two
greater than symbols together

498
00:25:39.220 --> 00:25:44.520
to resolve.conf, and hit Enter.

499
00:25:44.520 --> 00:25:52.120
And now if I can't resolve.conf you'll
see there's my name server addition.

500
00:25:52.120 --> 00:25:55.720
And now, every time you try to do name
resolution it will look at every one of

501
00:25:55.720 --> 00:25:58.050
these in this file and try them all.

502
00:25:58.050 --> 00:26:00.830
And if one of them comes back with
an answer, well there you go,

503
00:26:00.830 --> 00:26:03.400
you get to use name service and
it's nice and we like it.

504
00:26:03.400 --> 00:26:04.440
>> Very, very cool Daniel.

505
00:26:04.440 --> 00:26:07.300
A lot of great stuff there,
really good look at

506
00:26:07.300 --> 00:26:10.760
how you set that TCP/IP configuration
in a Linux world, right.

507
00:26:10.760 --> 00:26:13.010
I mean the basics are the same,
Windows, Linux.

508
00:26:13.010 --> 00:26:14.716
You need an IP address, a subnet mask,

509
00:26:14.716 --> 00:26:18.560
default gateways are definitely handy
if you wanna get off of your network.

510
00:26:18.560 --> 00:26:21.369
DNS, very helpful if you don't know
the IP address of everything you wanna

511
00:26:21.369 --> 00:26:22.130
connect to.

512
00:26:22.130 --> 00:26:25.150
But then how you go about configuring it,
Windows versus Linux,

513
00:26:25.150 --> 00:26:26.160
little bit of difference there.

514
00:26:26.160 --> 00:26:30.080
So if we get a real good inside on the
different ways we can go about configuring

515
00:26:30.080 --> 00:26:32.240
that in a Linux environment
from a command prompt.

516
00:26:32.240 --> 00:26:35.810
We saw ifconfig, the way we've done it for
many, many years.

517
00:26:35.810 --> 00:26:38.620
And the new IP, right,
that we can now use.

518
00:26:38.620 --> 00:26:40.330
A lot of these distros are including that,

519
00:26:40.330 --> 00:26:42.580
and it's gonna be the new
way to do things.

520
00:26:42.580 --> 00:26:45.120
It's kind of replacing good old ifconfig.

521
00:26:45.120 --> 00:26:48.920
As well as how to set that default
gateway, with the route command and

522
00:26:48.920 --> 00:26:54.240
set your DNS server address by
modifying your resolve.conf file.

523
00:26:54.240 --> 00:26:55.220
So we thank you for that, Daniel.

524
00:26:55.220 --> 00:26:55.770
We appreciate it.

525
00:26:55.770 --> 00:26:58.700
We hope everybody out there
enjoyed watching this one.

526
00:26:58.700 --> 00:27:01.590
Signing off for IT Pro TV,
I've been your host, Mike Rodrick.

527
00:27:01.590 --> 00:27:02.520
>> And I'm Daniel Lowrie.

528
00:27:02.520 --> 00:27:04.860
>> And we'll see you next time.

529
00:27:04.860 --> 00:27:10.793
[MUSIC]

530
00:27:10.793 --> 00:27:14.033
Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Mike continue to cover some Linux foundational knowledge. This time they focus on processes and the tools we can use to work with them. They start with TOP, as well as PS commands. Then they demonstrate examining background processes using Jobs, and how to kill a process.
episodes.title: Linux Overview Part 3
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:03.004
Welcome back to ITProTV,
I'm your host Don Pezet.

2
00:00:03.004 --> 00:00:10.601
[CROSSTALK]
>> You're watching ITProTV.

3
00:00:12.640 --> 00:00:15.975
>> Hello, welcome to another
exciting episode here in ITProTV.

4
00:00:15.975 --> 00:00:17.310
I'm your host Mike Rodrick.

5
00:00:17.310 --> 00:00:23.590
And today we're doing our GIAC security
essentials or G-Sec for short.

6
00:00:23.590 --> 00:00:25.060
And in this episode in particular,

7
00:00:25.060 --> 00:00:27.860
we're gonna be continuing
on with our Linux overview.

8
00:00:27.860 --> 00:00:30.090

9
00:00:30.090 --> 00:00:30.970

10
00:00:30.970 --> 00:00:34.030
>> Mike, I'm doing fantastic,
always glad to be back in the studio.

11
00:00:34.030 --> 00:00:38.440
Always glad to be talking about Linux

12
00:00:38.440 --> 00:00:40.860
I love it very much,
I've been using it for quite some time.

13

And we've had a lot of good times,

14
