three of our overview of Linux.

15
00:00:47.170 --> 00:00:50.200
Because we wanna make sure
that even the uninitiated

16
00:00:50.200 --> 00:00:53.780
have some foundational knowledge
of the Linux system itself.

17
00:00:53.780 --> 00:00:57.230
Be able to work with it because not
everybody was born with this information,

18
00:00:57.230 --> 00:00:57.910
believe it or not
>> [LAUGH]

19
00:00:57.910 --> 00:00:59.649
>> And we all had to acquire it in some

20
00:00:59.649 --> 00:01:00.776
way, shape or form.

21
00:01:00.776 --> 00:01:02.030
And hopefully that's
what you're doing today.

22
00:01:02.030 --> 00:01:05.240
If you have some Linux information
already, you've already worked with it.

23
00:01:05.240 --> 00:01:08.690
This is gonna be a good primer or
overview for you and

24
00:01:08.690 --> 00:01:13.490
stuff that you definitely need to know for
the GIAC GSEC exam.

25
00:01:13.490 --> 00:01:16.400
So that's the other reason we're
going over the specific things that

26
00:01:16.400 --> 00:01:18.680
we're talking today is because
that's what they want you to know.

27
00:01:18.680 --> 00:01:24.170
So without further ado let's go back into
Linux, get your minds wrapped around it.

28
00:01:24.170 --> 00:01:29.050
Prepare, body mind and soul,
to receive the Linux information.

29
00:01:29.050 --> 00:01:32.480
We've talked distros,
we've talked networking.

30
00:01:32.480 --> 00:01:34.975
Now let's talk about processes.

31
00:01:34.975 --> 00:01:38.520
These are things that we
do on our computers, right?

32
00:01:38.520 --> 00:01:42.780
If I have a computer running, I don't
just turn it on to look at it and go wow,

33
00:01:42.780 --> 00:01:45.380
that was a nice couple of grand
I just spend on that machine.

34
00:01:45.380 --> 00:01:46.430
It sure is pretty.

35
00:01:46.430 --> 00:01:48.130
I want it to do things, right?

36
00:01:48.130 --> 00:01:52.499
And typically that's in the form of
a process when I start a service or

37
00:01:52.499 --> 00:01:56.650
I want a program,
it creates a process in the Linux system.

38
00:01:56.650 --> 00:02:00.530
There's actually a directory
called proc which is for proxy.

39
00:02:00.530 --> 00:02:04.120
We're gonna talk about directories but
let's stay in here and now but

40
00:02:04.120 --> 00:02:05.620
I just wanna throw that actually.

41
00:02:05.620 --> 00:02:07.770
It was a little taste of what's to come.

42
00:02:07.770 --> 00:02:11.400
There's a directory called proc and when
you create and when a new process starts.

43
00:02:11.400 --> 00:02:15.230
Actually creates a file inside
a proc that temporarily

44
00:02:15.230 --> 00:02:16.930
exist there as long as
the process is running.

45
00:02:16.930 --> 00:02:19.621
Once the process is done,
the file goes away.

46
00:02:19.621 --> 00:02:22.955
And that's because not every process is
meant to run from start to finish in your

47
00:02:22.955 --> 00:02:23.880
computer.

48
00:02:23.880 --> 00:02:26.332
And Linux [INAUDIBLE] see things as files.

49
00:02:26.332 --> 00:02:30.480
It's just interesting
aside on how Linux works,

50
00:02:30.480 --> 00:02:33.550
it wants to see everything as a flat file.

51
00:02:33.550 --> 00:02:36.352
So there you go,
your Linux trivia for today.

52
00:02:36.352 --> 00:02:39.370
>> [LAUGH]
>> That's why we have the proc directory

53
00:02:39.370 --> 00:02:41.260
and that's what's happening
when processes run.

54
00:02:41.260 --> 00:02:44.160
Now we need to be able to work with
processes, not just fire them off.

55
00:02:44.160 --> 00:02:49.320
Obviously if I wanna run nmap or
if I wanna start telnet daemon or

56
00:02:49.320 --> 00:02:51.280
something like that,
I wanna be able to do it.

57
00:02:51.280 --> 00:02:54.290
But I also wanna be able to manage it,
work with it, see what's happening.

58
00:02:54.290 --> 00:02:56.367
What is my computer running right now?

59
00:02:56.367 --> 00:02:58.964
>> Yeah, I was gonna say, that was one
of my first questions is what's going on

60
00:02:58.964 --> 00:03:00.250
already that I don't know about.

61
00:03:00.250 --> 00:03:05.010
>> Right.
And to the newer, uninitiated person

62
00:03:05.010 --> 00:03:09.180
into maybe not so much security but just
computers in general, they don't realize

63
00:03:09.180 --> 00:03:13.000
there's a whole lot of stuff happening
just from firing up the system.

64
00:03:13.000 --> 00:03:14.290
A lot of times for

65
00:03:14.290 --> 00:03:18.460
us to get a good baseline on how
the system normally performs.

66
00:03:18.460 --> 00:03:21.790
A good way for us to do that
is to see what is running and

67
00:03:21.790 --> 00:03:25.085
how we do that is a nice
little command called top.

68
00:03:25.085 --> 00:03:27.860
T-o-p like a top hat, right?

69
00:03:27.860 --> 00:03:35.300
It gives you I wanna say live,
it is live in a certain way.

70
00:03:35.300 --> 00:03:36.250
You can increase or

71
00:03:36.250 --> 00:03:41.620
decrease how it looks to see what
is running at that point in time.

72
00:03:41.620 --> 00:03:45.690
I think it starts off by default
every second, it checks to see

73
00:03:45.690 --> 00:03:49.830
what processes are running and then
displays that to your terminal screen.

74
00:03:49.830 --> 00:03:52.300
So let's jump to my computer and
let's see what that looks like.

75
00:03:52.300 --> 00:03:55.410
So I am in my terminal.

76
00:03:55.410 --> 00:04:00.200
If I just type in top and hit return,
I get this cool little output.

77
00:04:00.200 --> 00:04:02.820
And look,
it actually did something, right.

78
00:04:02.820 --> 00:04:04.420
You saw it kind of flicker, things change.

79
00:04:04.420 --> 00:04:08.000
There it goes again and one second
passes and maybe one or two seconds.

80
00:04:08.000 --> 00:04:11.540
But basically, in one second,
it passes the checks and

81
00:04:11.540 --> 00:04:16.000
then refreshes the screen, giving you
that output in as real time as possible.

82
00:04:16.000 --> 00:04:19.600
One second should be sufficient for
most uses, but

83
00:04:19.600 --> 00:04:21.225
you can increase and decrease that.

84
00:04:21.225 --> 00:04:25.300
>> So for us Windows faithful, would
you compare that to say Task Manager?

85
00:04:25.300 --> 00:04:26.640
>> Yeah, yeah, that's exactly right.

86
00:04:26.640 --> 00:04:30.830
If you used to task manager opening
that up, seeing what's running.

87
00:04:30.830 --> 00:04:33.710
Yeah, there it is,
shows how much CPU is being used,

88
00:04:33.710 --> 00:04:36.610
how much memory is being used,
what the process name is.

89
00:04:36.610 --> 00:04:39.000
You'll notice that's basically
what we're seeing here.

90
00:04:39.000 --> 00:04:43.320
Let's take a look at the interface and
see what we can gleam from this.

91
00:04:43.320 --> 00:04:47.530
You can see that there
are 136 total tasks running.

92
00:04:47.530 --> 00:04:49.980
It's giving us what
the screen can show us.

93
00:04:49.980 --> 00:04:54.760
If my screen was bigger or
if I increased the resolution

94
00:04:54.760 --> 00:04:59.120
to where the fonts were smaller,
it would show me more information.

95
00:04:59.120 --> 00:05:04.410
So it's just showing me what I can
actually page out at this point in time.

96
00:05:04.410 --> 00:05:07.550
I think if I actually grab this and
pull it down.

97
00:05:07.550 --> 00:05:09.700
You'll notice we can
actually see more stuff now.

98
00:05:09.700 --> 00:05:13.500
So just a little tidbit if you're
working in a graphical environment.

99
00:05:13.500 --> 00:05:18.660
If you're not, if you're just in a shell,
then you'd have to decrease the font or

100
00:05:18.660 --> 00:05:22.050
do something with resolution, so
that you can see more information.

101
00:05:22.050 --> 00:05:24.970
Or know what it is you're looking for.

102
00:05:24.970 --> 00:05:29.070
And we're not gonna get into how
every nook and cranny of top works.

103
00:05:29.070 --> 00:05:31.680
We just want you to know what it is,
how it works and

104
00:05:31.680 --> 00:05:34.930
why you would want to know about it for
security purposes.

105
00:05:34.930 --> 00:05:39.410
Because what happens we get malware and
if you're in a Windows environment and

106
00:05:39.410 --> 00:05:43.270
someone complains about their computer,
it's running a little slowly today.

107
00:05:43.270 --> 00:05:45.230
I can't seem to get
anywhere on the Internet.

108
00:05:47.010 --> 00:05:51.020
You bring up task manager and
you look, what is that process?

109
00:05:51.020 --> 00:05:53.470
>> Does that look familiar?

110
00:05:53.470 --> 00:05:58.520
>> Does it look familiar or it has some
like ominous name, that can be a key.

111
00:05:58.520 --> 00:06:00.920
So that's the same thing we're gonna
do here, run it for the purposes.

112
00:06:00.920 --> 00:06:03.480
We want to look at top,
see what's going on.

113
00:06:03.480 --> 00:06:06.900
You'll notice we have this PID field,
that's the process Id.

114
00:06:06.900 --> 00:06:09.240
So each process gets an identifier.

115
00:06:09.240 --> 00:06:12.520
So they can tell the difference
with one process in another.

116
00:06:12.520 --> 00:06:15.750
So if I start up the same process twice,
all right.

117
00:06:15.750 --> 00:06:19.560
If it is just had Firefox,
Firefox as my brand browser.

118
00:06:19.560 --> 00:06:21.280
Okay, which one is which?

119
00:06:21.280 --> 00:06:22.520
I have no idea.

120
00:06:22.520 --> 00:06:24.280
So process Id helps us out with that.

121
00:06:25.570 --> 00:06:28.480
Their user, which is the user
that is running that process.

122
00:06:28.480 --> 00:06:31.510
You'll notice I got a lot of route going
here because I'm logged in as route.

123
00:06:31.510 --> 00:06:35.190
Everything, all the services I've
started are starting as route.

124
00:06:35.190 --> 00:06:38.850
Let's see here, what else is
some good stuff for us to know.

125
00:06:38.850 --> 00:06:42.730
CPU time and memory percentage, right,
these two guys right here very important.

126
00:06:42.730 --> 00:06:47.010
How much CPU is being used up,
how much memory is being used.

127
00:06:47.010 --> 00:06:52.490
Well, the cool thing is,
is that it refreshes to descending.

128
00:06:52.490 --> 00:06:56.690
It starts with the greatest
use down to the least use.

129
00:06:56.690 --> 00:07:00.170
So whoever your top offender is by
default is what's going to show us.

130
00:07:00.170 --> 00:07:02.820
And both CPU and memory.

131
00:07:02.820 --> 00:07:05.340
What else, how long it's been running.

132
00:07:05.340 --> 00:07:10.010
You'll notice, I guess we're running at
two seconds here, that one four seconds.

133
00:07:10.010 --> 00:07:14.520
But that's how long it's been running,
five minutes and 19 seconds and it's XORG,

134
00:07:14.520 --> 00:07:18.920
is the number, and that's the command,
the name of the command that is running.

135
00:07:18.920 --> 00:07:22.960
So now I can look through here, I see
all sorts of stuff running, system D,

136
00:07:22.960 --> 00:07:25.570
that's my main server,
we talked about that.

137
00:07:25.570 --> 00:07:28.810
Just trying to see anything interesting.

138
00:07:28.810 --> 00:07:30.890
Top just showed up there, right?

139
00:07:30.890 --> 00:07:33.160
It started top, it's doing something.

140
00:07:33.160 --> 00:07:36.290
It actually took up some CPU cycles and
showed up in that iteration.

141
00:07:36.290 --> 00:07:38.250
So it showed up, I can know that.

142
00:07:38.250 --> 00:07:42.640
Top is great for seeing what is running
right now, how much it's using.

143
00:07:42.640 --> 00:07:45.000
Like I said,
you can get more fine tuned with it,

144
00:07:45.000 --> 00:07:47.430
change the amount of time it runs.

145
00:07:47.430 --> 00:07:50.310
Make it wait more time or less time.

146
00:07:50.310 --> 00:07:53.434
Make it always show this
process at the top.

147

00:20:11.018 --> 00:20:15.584
just remove our ampersand,
if I can get back to that.

365
00:20:15.584 --> 00:20:17.634
Now what do I do, right?

366
00:20:17.634 --> 00:20:20.900
And I do this all the time,
I'm sure you will as well.

367
00:20:20.900 --> 00:20:26.771
What you can do is just come into
your thing, you're terminal here,

368
00:20:26.771 --> 00:20:31.024
and hit CTRL+Z, and
you'll notice it stopped,

369
00:20:31.024 --> 00:20:36.204
it's not done, it's not gone,
it is paused, basically.

370
00:20:36.204 --> 00:20:41.102
So if I run jobs, it's just kinda
sitting there, it's still there, but

371
00:20:41.102 --> 00:20:45.614
it's not doing anything,
it's not accepting input or anything.

372
00:20:45.614 --> 00:20:49.458
It's kind of in limbo state, so
if I do that CTRL + Z keyboard,

373
00:20:49.458 --> 00:20:54.029
I can still pause, regain my terminal,
do some things that I need to do, so

374
00:20:54.029 --> 00:20:59.328
if I accidentally didn't start it in the
background, I'm like, well, I'm too deep

375
00:20:59.328 --> 00:21:04.263
into this to kill it and start all over,
maybe I'm running a root force scanner or

376
00:21:04.263 --> 00:21:09.960
something like that, or a password
cracker, I'm like, man, why did I do that?

377
00:21:09.960 --> 00:21:13.775
I can do a CTRL+Z, it'll pause that right
where it's at, I can use my terminal,

378
00:21:13.775 --> 00:21:17.112
do what ever I need to do, and then I
can bring it back to the foreground.

379
00:21:17.112 --> 00:21:19.610
How do I do that,
how do I bring it back to that foreground?

380
00:21:19.610 --> 00:21:24.876
Easy, you type in fg at the terminal for
foreground, and Return,

381
00:21:24.876 --> 00:21:30.061
and off it goes, and now you'll
notice I lost my terminal again.

382
00:21:30.061 --> 00:21:30.808
>> Right.

383
00:21:30.808 --> 00:21:35.505
So, that was stupid of me, I just did the
exact same thing that I'm kicking myself

384
00:21:35.505 --> 00:21:38.720
for doing, I put in there,
I lost my terminal control.

385
00:21:38.720 --> 00:21:42.766
All right, CTRL+Z, pause it back,
I could continue doing that, CTRL+Z,

386
00:21:42.766 --> 00:21:46.934
whatever I need to, and going back to the
terminal and doing whatever I need to and

387
00:21:46.934 --> 00:21:50.919
then jumping back to IceWeasel, or
my password cracker, for instance, but

388
00:21:50.919 --> 00:21:52.433
I need to get smart, right?

389
00:21:52.433 --> 00:21:56.479
Sometimes I don't wanna continue
to switch back and forth,

390
00:21:56.479 --> 00:22:01.654
I wanna restart the process but I wanna
put it in the background so I just do bg.

391
00:22:01.654 --> 00:22:06.039
And now IceWeasel, you notice that
little ampersand jump back over here,

392
00:22:06.039 --> 00:22:10.590
right there, put that process
right back into the background.

393
00:22:10.590 --> 00:22:15.752
So fg for foreground, bg for background,
you can also kill processes this way.

394
00:22:15.752 --> 00:22:20.414
And yeah, you'll notice it's still giving
me errors, I would have to finagle

395
00:22:20.414 --> 00:22:24.670
the command itself, to dump errors
away from the terminal to not see it.

396
00:22:24.670 --> 00:22:27.982
But I can still use,
it didn't take over my terminal, so

397
00:22:27.982 --> 00:22:30.540
that was actually good that that happened.

398
00:22:30.540 --> 00:22:33.909
Just because you're seeing errors from
stuff that's running in the background

399
00:22:33.909 --> 00:22:37.327
doesn't mean that you don't still have
control of your terminal, you do, it's

400
00:22:37.327 --> 00:22:40.763
still there, you just have to press Enter
a couple times or something to see that.

401
00:22:40.763 --> 00:22:45.270
I can't believe it, sometimes I've done
it where I'm like, what's going on here?

402
00:22:45.270 --> 00:22:48.450
That's right, I have a background process
running and it's errors or something.

403
00:22:48.450 --> 00:22:50.388
>> I came to you one time
with that same thing.

404
00:22:50.388 --> 00:22:51.978
I was like, I don't know what's
going on here, what did I do?

405
00:22:51.978 --> 00:22:55.898
And you're like, hit Enter a couple
of times, there we go, that was easy.

406
00:22:55.898 --> 00:23:00.249
>> Yeah, I love simple fixes like that and
hopefully you do as well.

407
00:23:00.249 --> 00:23:02.129
All right, let's see,
where we are at here?

408
00:23:02.129 --> 00:23:05.031
We have done TOP,
we've done PS, we've done Jobs,

409
00:23:05.031 --> 00:23:08.460
and let's kill a process,
let's kill what's going on here.

410
00:23:08.460 --> 00:23:14.400
So if I do Jobs, I can see that
IceWeasel is running, IceWeasel works,

411
00:23:14.400 --> 00:23:19.356
IceWeasel, Jobs works a little
differently than like PS.

412
00:23:19.356 --> 00:23:22.720
So when you're on PS,
it tells you the process ID.

413
00:23:22.720 --> 00:23:27.494
Here we get this, it says 2,
okay, that's the number and

414
00:23:27.494 --> 00:23:32.948
order in which Jobs is counting
the things that we've run, right?

415
00:23:32.948 --> 00:23:35.681
This is the second iteration,
so it will be 2.

416
00:23:35.681 --> 00:23:39.336
As far as this is concerned, if you
wanna tell it 2, you have to do %2, and

417
00:23:39.336 --> 00:23:41.350
that's basically saying, number two.

418
00:23:41.350 --> 00:23:44.990
I guess the number sign was taken in
something else so they couldn't use it, so

419
00:23:44.990 --> 00:23:46.110
they use percent sign.

420
00:23:46.110 --> 00:23:51.439
So all you would have to do is say kill %,
where's my %, there it is.

421
00:23:51.439 --> 00:23:58.177
Link file, and then 2, and then,
if I did Jobs, you'll see this terminated.

422
00:23:58.177 --> 00:24:01.097
Give it a second or two for
it to actually terminate Jobs again, and

423
00:24:01.097 --> 00:24:04.210
then there's no output because
that job was terminated.

424
00:24:04.210 --> 00:24:09.085
So, %1, %2, whatever the number is,
if you want to just kill the first job,

425
00:24:09.085 --> 00:24:11.713
%1, %2, %3, and so on and so forth.

426
00:24:11.713 --> 00:24:16.843
If you get to where it's a stubborn
process and it's not dying,

427
00:24:16.843 --> 00:24:21.593
add a dash nine to that, so
like kill -9 %2, like that,

428
00:24:21.593 --> 00:24:24.457
it's going, it's going bye bye.

429
00:24:24.457 --> 00:24:27.261
>> [LAUGH]
>> It also works with your PIDs, so

430
00:24:27.261 --> 00:24:30.731
if you have, I don't know any
process IDs off the top of my head,

431
00:24:30.731 --> 00:24:32.874
let's start IceWeasel real quickly.

432
00:24:35.189 --> 00:24:37.610
[LAUGH] I just cannot
do it to save my life.

433
00:24:37.610 --> 00:24:39.738
>> [LAUGH]
>> My fingers are so lethargic today.

434
00:24:39.738 --> 00:24:43.696
You'll notice I've got a process ID there
of, and of course I just killed it.

435
00:24:43.696 --> 00:24:46.520
>> [LAUGH]
>> Come on, Lowrie, you can do this.

436
00:24:48.690 --> 00:24:54.758
Let's go back here and do ps-ax,

437
00:24:54.758 --> 00:24:59.788
grip ice grip, IceWeasel.

438
00:24:59.788 --> 00:25:03.989
There we go, there it is,
there's the process ID,

439
00:25:03.989 --> 00:25:08.199
also got it when I started it,
and I can do kill -9.

440
00:25:08.199 --> 00:25:12.603
If it's stubborn use the -9,
don't use it unless you need to,

441
00:25:12.603 --> 00:25:17.890
cuz it's a little harsh on the system but
2707, process ID, hit return,

442
00:25:17.890 --> 00:25:23.120
and then run my same command again,
and you'll see that it is gone.

443
00:25:23.120 --> 00:25:26.350
So that's how you kill processes, that's
how you find processes, that's how you

444
00:25:26.350 --> 00:25:29.592
work with processes, get them in, get them
out, whatever you need to do with them.

445
00:25:29.592 --> 00:25:34.620
That should give you all the necessary
tools to work with your processes.

446
00:25:34.620 --> 00:25:37.694
>> All right, well thank you for that
information Daniel, great stuff there.

447
00:25:37.694 --> 00:25:41.282
When it comes to the world of security,
one of the things that we have to be able

448
00:25:41.282 --> 00:25:45.094
to do is figure out what's running on that
system and make sure it's the stuff that

449
00:25:45.094 --> 00:25:49.020
we want running and stuff that we don't
want running is not running, right?

450
00:25:49.020 --> 00:25:50.632
Find those hidden processes,

451
00:25:50.632 --> 00:25:54.982
that malware that has maybe been running
in the background and you didn't know it.

452
00:25:54.982 --> 00:25:58.064
Now we know our commands,
we've got TOP, we've got PS, and

453
00:25:58.064 --> 00:26:01.741
we've got that Jobs to check our work
with our background processes, and

454
00:26:01.741 --> 00:26:05.176
we know how to pause them or stop them,
and then, kill them, and then

455
00:26:05.176 --> 00:26:09.306
forcefully kill them if we really want to
pull out that nine mill and take them out.

456
00:26:09.306 --> 00:26:12.209
So, dash nine with that kill, we love it.

457
00:26:12.209 --> 00:26:13.180
Thank you then for that Daniel.

458
00:26:13.180 --> 00:26:16.352
I hope everybody out there enjoyed
watching this one, signing off for

459
00:26:16.352 --> 00:26:18.460
ITProTV, I've been your host Mike Rodrick.

460
00:26:18.460 --> 00:26:19.248
>> And I'm Daniel Lowrey.

461
00:26:19.248 --> 00:26:20.292
>> And we'll see you next time.

462
00:26:20.292 --> 00:26:27.805
[MUSIC]

463
00:26:27.805 --> 00:26:31.055

>> And, Daniel, I tell you, this is one

36
00:01:24.580 --> 00:01:28.764
we've gone over setting your TCP/IP,

37
00:01:28.764 --> 00:01:30.350

38

We looked at services, and top, and

40

Very similar to Windows,
different interface obviously,

41
00:01:38.000 --> 00:01:39.230
a little different layout.

42
00:01:39.230 --> 00:01:42.730
But when it comes to this,
it's a lot different.

43
00:01:42.730 --> 00:01:46.560
>> Yeah, this is where definitely
Linux is a departure from

44
00:01:46.560 --> 00:01:49.710
probably any type of Windows
system you've ever seen before.

45
00:01:49.710 --> 00:01:53.578
And if you've been in Windows, which I
hope you have, you probably are using

46
00:01:53.578 --> 00:01:57.166
a computer maybe to watch me right now,
and it might have Windows on it.

47
00:01:57.166 --> 00:02:00.325
Windows is a large share of the desktop
market and for good reasons,

48
00:02:00.325 --> 00:02:02.275
it's a great desktop operating system.

49
00:02:02.275 --> 00:02:06.502
Linux is, what we're talking about
when it departs is its file structure.

50
00:02:06.502 --> 00:02:08.525
When you look at the file structure,

51
00:02:08.525 --> 00:02:12.310
if you go into a Windows file structure
you typically see the C drive,

52
00:02:12.310 --> 00:02:15.675
maybe any CD-ROMs or
floppy disks if that’s still around.

53
00:02:15.675 --> 00:02:17.693
>> [LAUGH]
>> If that's lurking in your system.

54
00:02:17.693 --> 00:02:19.872
You've got maybe a USB drive stuck in.

55
00:02:19.872 --> 00:02:21.784
They've all got drive letters, and

56
00:02:21.784 --> 00:02:25.190
underneath that is its
hierarchy of files and folders.

57
00:02:25.190 --> 00:02:28.720
And there's some structure to that,
and it's native to Windows.

58
00:02:28.720 --> 00:02:30.350
That's the way they set it up.

59
00:02:30.350 --> 00:02:33.930
There will be a user's folder
underneath the C area, right?

60
00:02:33.930 --> 00:02:36.530
There'll be a Windows folder,
that kind of thing.

61
00:02:36.530 --> 00:02:40.520
Linux kind of does the same thing,
but here's the tricky part about it,

62
00:02:40.520 --> 00:02:43.560
is because Linux is just a kernel and

63
00:02:43.560 --> 00:02:45.700
the file system that they
put on it could be anything.

64
00:02:45.700 --> 00:02:47.225
You can make it anything you'd like.

65
00:02:47.225 --> 00:02:50.270
>> [LAUGH]
>> And, hey, it's my class, right?

66
00:02:50.270 --> 00:02:52.410
And you can see that
might lead to a problem.

67
00:02:52.410 --> 00:02:54.710
If I make my file system
have this directory,

68
00:02:54.710 --> 00:02:57.455
and that directory, Dan's directory,
and Mike's, directory and

69
00:02:57.455 --> 00:03:01.325
then we jump into another system that
Mike created and he created directory 1,

70
00:03:01.325 --> 00:03:04.005
directory 2, well,
there's no consistency between the two.

71
00:03:04.005 --> 00:03:06.840
Well, the good news was they saw
that as an issue very early on,

72
00:03:06.840 --> 00:03:08.965
and said you know what we needed to do?

73
00:03:08.965 --> 00:03:10.865
We need to basically standardize.

74
00:03:10.865 --> 00:03:12.765
And this comes a lot from Unix as well.

75
00:03:12.765 --> 00:03:17.785
Unix had a tried and true method of doing
this, so they said let's continue that.

76
00:03:17.785 --> 00:03:20.280
Remember, Linux was supposed
to be very Unix like.

77
00:03:20.280 --> 00:03:21.818
And it's the way it operates.

78
00:03:21.818 --> 00:03:25.100
So, and
we're borrowing these things from Unix.

79
00:03:25.100 --> 00:03:28.980
So, we get a hierarchy, a file structure,
that you are going to typically see.

80
00:03:28.980 --> 00:03:30.200
It's very standardized.

81
00:03:30.200 --> 00:03:32.940
It won't be identical,
it might be identical,

82
00:03:32.940 --> 00:03:36.190
but I can't guarantee that
from system to system.

83
00:03:36.190 --> 00:03:42.970
But I will give you at least a many of the
directories that you will probably find

84
00:03:42.970 --> 00:03:46.790
in just about any flavor of Linux that
you download, install, and try to run.

85
00:03:46.790 --> 00:03:47.870
So let's take a look at that now.

86
00:03:47.870 --> 00:03:51.182
Let's let's jump into my system and
take a look at the file system.

87
00:03:51.182 --> 00:03:53.510
I'm gonna show you a really
quick command here so

88
00:03:53.510 --> 00:03:56.290
that you can see things
inside your system.

89
00:03:56.290 --> 00:03:57.120
It's called LS.

90
00:03:57.120 --> 00:04:02.890
It's basically to list out what's
in the directory, ls like so.

91
00:04:02.890 --> 00:04:05.147
And I can see the files and
folders, directories,

92
00:04:05.147 --> 00:04:06.680
that are in the directory I'm at.

93
00:04:06.680 --> 00:04:10.390
If you wanna see what directory you
are in you can do pwd really quickly,

94
00:04:10.390 --> 00:04:11.900
which is print working directory.

95
00:04:11.900 --> 00:04:15.307
I can do that, and I can see that
I'm in this /root directory.

96
00:04:15.307 --> 00:04:20.290
And that is, comes underneath
the main root directory, and

97
00:04:20.290 --> 00:04:21.545
this is where it gets fun.

98
00:04:21.545 --> 00:04:23.070
>> [LAUGH]
>> This is where Linux gets,

99
00:04:23.070 --> 00:04:25.700
they're a jolly bunch of people,
I'll give them credit.

100
00:04:25.700 --> 00:04:28.780
They love a good joke, they love
a good laugh, and this is one thing.

101
00:04:28.780 --> 00:04:32.520
I don't know if they did this purposefully
or if it just worked out this way.

102
00:04:32.520 --> 00:04:37.030
But there is the root directory and
then there is roots directory.

103
00:04:37.030 --> 00:04:38.050
>> Yeah.

104
00:04:38.050 --> 00:04:41.930
>> If you caught the subtle
nuance there on the difference.

105
00:04:41.930 --> 00:04:44.120
>> There was a possessive there
in that second one, right?

106
00:04:44.120 --> 00:04:44.720
>> Exactly.

107
00:04:44.720 --> 00:04:45.770
>> I think I heard it.

108
00:04:45.770 --> 00:04:47.280
>> Yeah, Mike nailed it,
he's a grammarian.

109
00:04:47.280 --> 00:04:49.200
I love him for it because that's right,

110
00:04:49.200 --> 00:04:51.440
there was a possessive on
the end of that last one.

111
00:04:51.440 --> 00:04:53.320
There is root's directory.

112
00:04:53.320 --> 00:04:58.540
A root is a user,
is the all-powerful user of the system,

113
00:04:58.540 --> 00:05:00.860
and root has their own directory, okay?

114
00:05:00.860 --> 00:05:05.115
The root directory is the beginning
of the file system, and

115
00:05:05.115 --> 00:05:09.470
it's just symbolized by
the forward slash symbol, right?

116
00:05:09.470 --> 00:05:10.020
I think it's forward.

117
00:05:10.020 --> 00:05:11.510
Yeah, the forward slash symbol.

118
00:05:11.510 --> 00:05:14.260
So, I always get the forward slash and
backslash mixed up.

119
00:05:14.260 --> 00:05:16.590
So let's take a look at
